Motion (by Senator Hill, on behalf of Senator Panizza)—by leave—agreed to:
That the orders of the Senate of 3 November 1992, relating to time limits for questions and answers at question time and motions to take note of answers, continue to have effect as sessional orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the Prime Minister's promise in the One Nation statement last February that, `Within four years the Federal Budget will return to surplus'. I also refer the Minister to the fact that, far from moving towards a surplus, the Budget deficit this financial year will be a minimum of a staggering $14 billion, or 50 per cent greater than last year's excessive $9.3 billion, showing once again that a Labor government cannot be trusted to handle money. I ask whether the Government intends to honour the promise made in the One Nation statement to return the Budget to surplus within four years.

—Senator Short refers to a staggering $14 billion as his estimate of what the Budget deficit might be. The important point about that, as Senator Short well knows, before talking about the Labor Government's capacity to handle money—
—Incapacity!

—Whatever you want. Before Senator Short starts talking about that, he should look at the deficit as a percentage of GDP. It is all very well to blow hard about all that stuff, but as a percentage of GDP it is not nearly as dramatic as Senator Short would like to make it. The Government maintains its commitment to return the Budget to surplus, given all the circumstances which the economy is confronted with, by the mid-1990s.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of that failure by the Minister to answer my question at all, I ask whether he agrees with the view of the Prime Minister in his interview on Lateline last week that, `Since when do we have to go back to surpluses?', and, `Since when are they holy writ?'. If so, will he also comment on the statement by the OECD last week, in respect of the United States economy but with equal relevance to the Australian economy, that, `There is no scope for fiscal stimulus without compromising all pretence of controlling the Federal Budget deficit in the near future'?
—The United States' situation is much worse than ours. That was recognised at the time of the presidential election in the United States where more than 50 per cent—
—They are in much better shape than we are.

—Senator Short thinks that, does he? Senator Short's wisdom on this subject is that they are in much better shape than we are. If Senator Short looks at the Clinton program he will see that it shows just how committed the President-elect is to implementing many of the things that we have been implementing in this country over the last few years.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short quotes selectively from the OECD. It is only a fortnight since the OECD, contrary to anything which the Liberal Party has been advocating, advocated additional fiscal stimulus in a number of economies because of the situation in which economies found themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time has expired.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the economic benefit to Australia from the breakthrough in trade talks between the US and the EC on the Uruguay Round? Does this mean that the Uruguay Round can now be brought to an early conclusion?

—The Government is delighted that the United States and the European Community have finally been able to resolve their differences on agricultural issues. This opens the way for agreement on a successful Round outcome among all 105 GATT countries, although a great deal of work does need to be done to turn this preliminary agreement into solid, bankable Uruguay Round commitments. The parties will be meeting in Geneva in the next week or so to commence the work necessary to bring the Round as a whole to a successful conclusion. There will be quite a lot of negotiation to put together the schedules of specific commitments on agriculture and other goods and services. When that happens, of course, the whole package will be able to take effect.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the economic benefits that will flow when it does take effect, the first and most important result of the Round's conclusion will be a much needed boost to business confidence in a period of what has been worldwide recession. That should be followed by a strong increase in global output over the next couple of years which we conservatively estimate to be worth around $200 billion a year. Global trade in services and intellectual property will be, more or less for the first time, fair, non-discriminatory and open while, of course, bringing agriculture under GATT rules will, among other things, progressively undo the gross corruption of markets by export subsidies which have so dramatically harmed the interests of Australian producers.

For Australia it is still our estimate that a successful outcome to the Round will deliver in excess of $1 billion in increased national income. In the farming sector the cut in the level of subsidised exports of 21 per cent over six years will mean higher world prices for important commodity exports such as wheat and coarse grains, beef, butter and cheese which together represent 10 per cent of Australia's total exports. In that sector alone, ABARE—the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics—estimates the trade gains could be in the vicinity of $900m. The savings from the reduction in global tariffs will be up to $750m in import duties. We also expect substantial benefits to flow from the increased access opportunities for the Australian service industry.

This is an appropriate occasion to put on record the debt of gratitude that this nation owes to a succession of trade Ministers from Australia who have done so much to put agriculture on the map so far as this Round is concerned, beginning with Mr Dawkins who, as trade Minister, was the single most important figure in the world in getting agriculture into the Round to start with. That tradition has been followed extremely effectively by his successors, Messrs Duffy, Blewett and Kerin.

Those efforts have successfully protected the interests of the agricultural exporting countries involved in the Cairns Group. Australia's chairmanship of the Cairns Group reflected the extremely influential role we played in starting these negotiations and that should be recognised, even by those churlish senators opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.
—I ask a supplementary question. Does the Government expect the French to veto the agreement which has been reached?

—We have seen a number of reports about the very strident pressures that French farmers are placing on their Government, and the French Government may attempt to veto the agreement in the European Council of Ministers. We have had no formal indication that the French Government will act in that matter. Indeed, President Mitterrand has specifically indicated that France would not exercise a veto.

PARA.TAB: It is to be assumed that France will continue to oppose the agricultural reforms but, in doing so, it looks as though it will not have any support from any other member of the European Community, at least the kind of support that would encourage it to dare to try to go down the track of stymieing the whole process. That is as it should be because there are significant benefits in a successful conclusion of the Round, not only in net terms for the French economy as a whole, quite apart from its impact on the farm sector, but certainly for all other members of the European Community as, indeed, for the international community—not to mention the developing countries. It would be an absolute tragedy if, at this stage, domestic political considerations were to intrude, and I do not believe they will in fact at the end of the day.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I ask: does he agree with the reported comments of the Victoria Cross winner, Sir Roden Cutler, that last night's Cabinet decision to include homosexuals in the defence forces will be disruptive, that it will lead to a serious decline in morale, and that it is the wrong decision at the wrong time?

—Mr President, when I took the oath for the Executive Council, I agreed to abide by Cabinet decisions. I agree with the decision made yesterday. I put a different view; that is well known. I accept the majority decision.

—I ask a supplementary question. In light of the Minister's response, how many more Cabinet defeats on key defence issues can the Minister's credibility tolerate? What confidence can the service chiefs and the defence forces now have in him?

—It is not possible, I suppose, to do a score of victories and defeats in Cabinet on defence issues, but most of my colleagues would acknowledge I have done pretty well in that regard. Senator Newman asked whether I have let down—or indicated I have let down—the defence chiefs. What I have done is put my views to Cabinet. I have put them in Cabinet. When questioned in this chamber, I have put my views.

PARA.TAB: I also have to acknowledge that, at least in this chamber, I have seen people put views very directly, including Senator Teague, Senator Newman, Senator Powell, Senator Zakharov, Senator Aulich and others. I respect both points of view that have been put because they have been put in a genuine way. I do not respect the views of Dr Hewson and Mr Downer on this matter. Unlike the rest of those opposite, they have never come out and made any public statement on where they stand.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true!

—Yes, it is. They have hidden behind the excuse of saying, `We will cop the advice of the chiefs of staff committee'. Senator Newman says that I have let down the chiefs and the armed forces. In the end they will say they would rather have a Minister who got up there and fought than one who ran away at the first sign of grapeshot, like those two.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister considering introducing `big bang' changes to the Australian system of industrial relations by throwing all workers out of the award system and taking away the protection of the Industrial Relations Commission? Does the Minister believe that individual workers generally have the bargaining power to be able to negotiate an individual employment contract with their employer on a win-win basis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government is about making changes to the industrial relations system. In order to make those changes, we believe in working with people to achieve enduring and quality change; we do not believe in working against people, confronting them, having perhaps a short term change which will be turned over and undone at the first sign of the changes in bargaining shares, leaving an aftertaste of bitterness and division within the community. We are on the side of making sure that changes are worked through the community and we are in a position of pointing to significant and quality changes that are beginning to transform the industrial relations culture of Australia. That is to say, we had made considerable progress until the advent of Jeff Kennett and his confrontationist, divisive, disruptive and economically damaging industrial relations approach in Victoria.
—And dishonest.

—Not to mention—picking up the interjection of my colleague Senator Collins—the dishonesty of it in misleading the electorate before the election as to what he would do and changing it within days of being elected.

PARA.TAB: For bargaining between parties to work, the balance of bargaining powers must be fair. It cannot be said that an individual employee bargaining with an employer, with the individual employee meeting that employer in the employer's office on their own, is a fair balance. That is not a fair bargaining practice; that is an unfair bargaining practice and is seen by most people as being so. So when I see references to `the contract or the sack: accept these terms or be dismissed', I recognise that as being the implication of what will happen in the privacy of an employer's office when an individual employee is offered the terms that that employer wants to foist on that employee.

I have no better reference than the transport authority in Victoria which at this moment is threatening to lock out all of its employees and engage only those who accept terms of individual contracts. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 17 November I saw this statement:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . employers and employees will not voluntarily enter into a workplace agreement unless it offers each party benefits not contained within the award.

When I see such things I recognise them as misleading statements. Individual employees and individual workers will be forced to accept terms and conditions below those of the award, because they will have their employment threatened.

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard, who is the author of that quote, is misleading the community in pretending that his industrial relations policy is benign when it clearly is not. His industrial relations policy is a low wage policy aimed at forcing people out of work or into substandard employment conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware of, and will he ask our Indonesian Embassy staff to check on, what charges have been laid by the Indonesian Government against Xanana Gusmao; where Mr Gusmao is being detained, and whether he is being held under conditions which would be considered acceptable under international standards; and whether the Red Cross has been granted access to Mr Gusmao, under what conditions, and when representatives of the ICRC will be able to see him?
—On the information available to us, I understand that charges have not yet been laid but a military spokesman has said that any charges will depend on the outcome of the investigation.

PARA.TAB: As to the location of Xanana Gusmao at the moment, we were informed on Saturday that he was being detained in Dili. We have had no information of any change of location since then and no reason to believe that he has been taken elsewhere, but I cannot be totally confident of that, obviously, in the absence of further information.

As to the conditions under which he is being held, I asked our Ambassador on Saturday to contact the Indonesian Government at the highest available level, which he did, to seek assurances that Xanana would not be ill-treated in any way. He received assurances at a very senior level that that would be so—that he would be treated in accordance with due process under Indonesian law and that he would not be ill-treated. Having received those assurances, which I very much welcome, I think we can be quite confident that there will be no ill-treatment.

As to the question of access by the Red Cross, the ICRC has sought access to Xanana; that has not yet been granted. Brigadier General Nurhadi, the Indonesian military spokesman, is reported as having said that access will be permitted but he has not specified when that will happen. Might I add to the public record that the Australian Government has specifically requested the Indonesian Government—this was done over the weekend—to allow the ICRC to have such access.

As to the role that is generally being played by the Government, all I can say is that we are continuing to monitor the situation and will continue to make representations as appropriate. We have continued to emphasise, in both public and private statements, our belief that this is an occasion for reconciliation, not for revenge in any sense of that term. I certainly hope that Xanana Gusmao's arrest will be taken by the Indonesian authorities as an occasion for the commencement of another serious attempt at reconciliation, and certainly that the Indonesian authorities will consider very carefully the implications for future harmony in the province of any punishment that may be imposed upon him.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to an answer he gave on 20 February 1991 relating to the enormous financial losses of the State Bank of South Australia and the failure of Labor governments, Federal and State, in that regard. The Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the magnitude of the State Bank's problems began to emerge progressively as its end December . . . accounts were being prepared. The Reserve Bank was informed of this during January 1991 and immediately engaged in discussions with the bank and its owner on measures to restore its capital and to maintain its viability.
I ask the Minister, if that were the case, why the Royal Commission report notes:
In August 1990, a Reserve Bank position paper on the seemingly perilous and worrying plight of the State Bank was directed to the Governor and the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank.
Further, given the blatant contradiction of the Minister's version of events by the Royal Commission, why did the Minister mislead the Senate?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept the assumptions in the question when Senator Hill throws in gratuitously the words `failure by the Federal Government'. That will emerge from my answer to the question. The phrase `seemingly perilous and worrying plight of the State Bank' was not the Reserve Bank's phrase; it is the Royal Commissioner's phrase. What happened was that it was not until January 1991, as the December half-year accounts for the bank were being compiled, that the likelihood of any large loss became apparent. Senator Hill can see that from reading the Royal Commission report. The estimate of the State Bank of South Australia of a full year loss escalated very quickly from about $200m in mid-January 1991 to almost $1 billion by the end of the month. That is when the dramatic events occurred. It is true that in August 1990 the Reserve Bank did have a position paper on the State Bank of South Australia, but it does not, as Senator Hill's press release said, refer to the `perilous and worrying plight of the State Bank'. Those are not the words of the Reserve Bank; they are the words of the Royal Commissioner.

PARA.TAB: Since about 1987 the Reserve Bank has been in dialogue with the State Bank of South Australia about various matters. It was in 1987 that the Reserve Bank drew the attention of the State Bank to the fact that the Chief Executive of the State Bank, Mr Marcus Clarke, was both a director and shareholder in Equiticorp, to which the State Bank of South Australia had a very large exposure. That was at the beginning of 1987. It is therefore surprising to me to find that Dr John Hewson at about the same time recommended Mr Marcus Clarke as a suitable candidate for the governorship of the Reserve Bank of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister that I said the statement was from the Royal Commissioner's report. Is the Minister now disputing the finding of the Royal Commission in this regard, particularly in light of the facts that at that time—back in August—the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank was asking the question, `When do we need to talk to the shareholders in view of the State Bank of Victoria question?', that the Governor was talking about the possibility of corrective action and, as the Minister knows, that there were to be major consultations in September between the bank and the Reserve Bank on the problems concerning the State Bank? In light of those statements, is the Minister saying that a major problem was not evident back in August 1990?

—I am saying—as has been consistently said and as Senator Hill will find in the Royal Commission report itself—that, as at August 1990, the Reserve Bank was concerned about the situation of the State Bank of South Australia. Senator Hill cannot make a silk purse out of a sow's ear as he tried to do when I referred to the magnitude of the State Bank problems which were revealed in January 1991. It was at the end of January 1991 when the Reserve Bank first advised the Federal Government of its concerns about the State Bank of South Australia.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce as the leader of the Australian delegation to the inaugural Australia-Indonesia ministerial forum held in Jakarta last week. I ask: what agreements were reached at the forum and what significance will the forum have for future economic relations between Indonesia and Australia? What can Australians expect to see flow from the forum's deliberations and conclusions?

—I and the Ministers comprising the delegation believe that it was an important forum in laying foundations for a much closer economic relationship between Australia and Indonesia. A series of agreements on economic and trade issues emanated from the forum and I believe that the result will be a much stronger bilateral relationship.

PARA.TAB: The forum took place as a result of the visit in April of this year by the Prime Minister to Indonesia—an immensely successful visit to Indonesia, I have to say. That led to the strengthening of the relationship between the two countries which was continued in the forum. My colleague Senator Evans, as the Prime Minister has pointed out, played no small part in adding ballast to the relationship over the years, particularly in his direct dialogues with Minister Alatas in Indonesia.

The importance attached by the Indonesians to last week's forum was demonstrated by the fact that a total of six senior Ministers attended the plenary sessions and took part in bilateral discussions. An additional four Ministers participated in bilateral meetings. President Suharto met with the Australian delegation and expressed his support for the aims of the forum in creating closer economic ties between the two countries. On Australia's part five Ministers, including myself and Senator Evans, travelled to Jakarta for the forum. I am sure Senator Evans will join me in expressing appreciation for the open and forthright manner in which our Indonesian counterparts approached the discussion.

As well as strengthening personal relationships between Ministers, the forum discussed a number of practical ways of enhancing cooperation. The outcome was substantial. Four agreements were signed and two working groups, one on trade, industry and investment and the other on agriculture and food cooperation, were established. The working group on trade, industry and investment will meet in February to look at a number of trade and investment issues. These include the growth of trade between Australia and Indonesia, specific opportunities for industry cooperation and cooperation on intellectual property issues.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of claims made in the editorial of the October newsletter of the Federation of Australian Scientific and Technological Societies, FASTS, concerning the Government's White Paper on science and technology? It reads:

QUESTION.PARA: It is difficult to understand the actions of Minister Free in bringing forth a White Paper which in the words of FASTS' president was `underwhelming'. It may be that by burying the problems the Minister hopes to please everyone—becoming a veritable Free-For-All. Or perhaps he is just living down his name `Agenda-Free'.

Does the Minister agree with his junior Minister that, in writing the editorial as quoted, the activities of the Executive Director of FASTS, Dr David Widdup, had `considerably damaged FASTS' reputation as a professional representative body and were motivated by personal and party political whims'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had some experience of dealing with the science community as represented by FASTS over a number of years. The temperature rises and falls like Canberra weather in the month of November. Let me just say a few things about the Government's White Paper because I think it is important. The Government this year delivered a $338m boost to science funding in the science White Paper including $235m revenue forgone through retention of the R&D tax concession—something which the Opposition was not committed to doing but followed shortly after the Government, thus making another hole in the Fightback funding.

PARA.TAB: Last year, the Government delivered an increase of $102m—or 6 per cent in real terms—for science in Australia. Since 1983, science funding has increased by 39 per cent in real terms. That fact is reflected in the performance of a whole range of Australian companies in export markets.

In August, after the publication of the science White Paper, the President of FASTS—this is Dr Widdup's boss—Dr Bartels, described the White Paper as indicating that the Government is taking science and technology seriously. At the same time, the Institution of Engineers Australia said in its journal:

ANSWER.PARA: The white paper . . . is a milestone in recognising the importance of science and engineering in the health of Australia's economy and establishes for the first time a national policy for science and technology.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to be interrupted by the scientific illiterates on the other side of the chamber, but let me say this: Australian science policy has been developed steadily over the last decade by this Government, both in terms of funding effort and outcomes. The outcomes are better than they have ever been in the history of this country. It is therefore not extraordinary that the proposals by President-elect Clinton are remarkably similar to those recently adopted by the Australian Government in terms of the methodology of funding science and developing science policy. The United Kingdom Government, preparing as it is a White Paper on science, has been studying the Australian policy very closely.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. That is very interesting, but does the Minister agree with Mr Free or not? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether this attack by the Minister for Science on FASTS in general and its Executive Director in particular reflects on his professional experience with either the organisation or Dr Widdup, the Executive Director?

—The debate between Mr Free and sections of the scientific community, as purportedly represented by FASTS, has been very much dictated by the fact that when the White Paper on science was published, FASTS and other organisations were warm, if not fulsome, in their praise of the White Paper. When Dr Widdup writes one of his perennial articles from time to time, which elevate him to an importance which he does not otherwise deserve—
—That is unkind.

—It is, and Senator Boswell ought to know. He comes here with his chin sticking out day after day. He ought to know what unkindness means. That is the major concern: the coalition cannot have it both ways by saying one thing at one time and another at another time.

—Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of reports that suggest that the growth of executive remuneration has increased by almost twice the rate of award wages in recent months? Does the Minister have any information that supports these conclusions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The undertaking that we have from the ACTU on behalf of wage and salary earners is that they will lock in the low level of inflation in the Australian economy and not push wage increases in a way in which that level of inflation now achieved will be put out of control. We want to see a low level of inflation as a permanent feature of the economy. Chief executives of companies have an obligation to Australia to set an example in doing this and not to take the position of saying, `Do as we say, not as we do'.

PARA.TAB: The latest information published by Cullen Egan Dell is that total remuneration for senior management rose by 5 per cent in the year to the September quarter 1992. This compares with an annual CPI growth rate of 0.8 per cent in the September quarter, a growth in average weekly earnings for the year to August 1992 of 3.1 per cent, and a Budget forecast of 3 1/2 per cent for increases in earnings in 1992-93.

Executive remuneration has grown, and continues to grow, at a faster rate than both average weekly earnings and the inflation rate. Growth in long term executive remuneration continues to be well above that of average earnings. Since March 1983, average male weekly earnings have risen by 75.2 per cent while base salary earnings for senior management grew by 135 per cent, which is nearly twice the rate of growth for employees. This is despite the low growth experienced by the majority of the community.

Certainly it seems that many senior executives in Australia do not believe that community standards apply to them. I will give two examples—the first is the Kennett Government. When the Kennett Government first came to power, it gave big salary increases—huge licks of increases—to senior public servants and cut the salaries and remuneration of everyone else in Victoria by removing the annual leave loading and by abolishing penalty rates. It introduced for itself increases in salary for Ministers and reintroduced the white glove silver service in the ministerial dining room. This is a good example of two different standards: one for you and one for us.

Regrettably, the other example I have to give relates to a former business enterprise, now partly privatised—the Commonwealth Bank—which is now not under my influence in terms of coordination. On 28 October it made a decision to increase the fees of non-executive directors by 44 per cent or $175,000 to $575,000. In its annual report, remuneration to bank executives rose from $12.5m to $29.7m. The most senior executive's pay rise was by $200,000 to about $590,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to an article in today's West Australian entitled `Terrorist Link to Unions Seen'. Does the Minister have a copy of the police report into the Victorian building industry, which claims that organised crime and international terrorist groups have infiltrated powerful unions in Melbourne? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The Minister said that Senator Crane `will indulge his bigotry'. That is a reflection on Senator Crane and it should be withdrawn. I ask you to rule in that way.
—I do not regard it as unparliamentary. I will leave it to Senator Cook as to whether he withdraws or not.
—Point of order, Mr President—
—Order! I am asking Senator Cook, for the well running of the Senate, whether he will to withdraw the word.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order.
—I am talking to Senator Cook.

—Mr President, you have invited me to be graceful. I shall be graceful. I will withdraw the reference to Senator Crane as being a bigot. However, Senator Crane would admit that he is single-minded and narrow on this view, and I would substitute those words. If I can turn to the answer I wish to give—

—On the point of order, Mr President, I rise because Senator Robert Ray has just risen and made another outrageous remark about my colleague Senator Walters. I want to make it perfectly clear to the Senate that Senator Walters is taking a very important point. —Order! In reply to the two points of order, I will check the Hansard. I will look at the way in which the expression was used and I will report back to the Senate.

—Thank you, Mr President. The reason that I expressed the view I have about Senator Crane is that he is prepared to smear a whole group of people on the grounds that they are union members. PARA.TAB: Mr President, I have not seen the article and I will not comment on it. I remind the Senate of these facts: we have set a framework in Australia in which unions are required to act in a democratic fashion. They are required to elect their leadership by secret ballot and disclose their finances to the Industrial Registrar. We have set a proper behavioural framework. Where unions have not engaged in proper procedures, we have taken action to deal with them. I cite the example of this Government's legislative deregistration of the Builders Labourers Federation. We did so because, among other matters, we regarded that some of the actions of that organisation, as a registered industrial organisation, touched areas of unlawful behaviour. So our record in dealing with these things from a point of principle and not from a point of prejudice is unsurpassed. I will, of course, look at any report that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Read it now then.

—I will not respond on my feet. I ask the honourable senator to behave himself. I will, of course, look properly and in an appropriate manner at any report. I am amazed that if there are such things, no-one has inquired of me before now. But I will take the honourable senator's question on board and reply more fully when I have satisfied myself, not on the basis of a newspaper report but on the basis of the facts.
—I ask a supplementary question.
—Go on, get it out!

—I will get it out and the Minister will listen to every word of it. That was a most extraordinary answer. Three-quarters of it was a personal attack on me. When will the Minister get this report that was referred to in the West Australian and report back to the Senate as to its contents and as to whether there has been any illegal action?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will treat this report with the seriousness which it deserves.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the release this week of a statement entitled `World Scientists' Warning to Humanity', signed by 1,500 leading scientists, including 99 of the 196 living Nobel laureates. The statement calls for such measures as a shift from fossil fuels to non-polluting energy sources, the more efficient use of natural resources, and the stabilisation of the world's population. Will the Minister ensure that this sobering statement, which shows an unprecedented degree of agreement within the international scientific community, be made the subject of a full Cabinet discussion? If not, why not? Secondly, given that the Minister himself could not even get Cabinet colleagues to approve the revenue neutral proposition that sales tax on cars be varied according to their fuel efficiency, what hope is there that the full recommendations of the ecologically sustainable development working groups will be finally implemented?

—I did see the press reports of the statement to which Senator Coulter refers. I agree with him that it is a very significant statement, signed by a wide range of important and distinguished scientists. These matters have been considered on a number of occasions by Cabinet in terms of, for example, measures which can be taken to alleviate greenhouse effects. They are not treated lightly in Cabinet. They have been the subject of a number of discussions. So, too, have the questions of ecologically sustainable development received wide consideration by Cabinet and will be receiving further consideration. I have no doubt that in the course of that further consideration the statement by the distinguished scientists will be adverted to or discussed and taken into account.

PARA.TAB: Following the Rio conference and so on, and following the establishment of ecologically sustainable working groups which are now being considered by government, I do not think that, compared with many countries, we have been slow to take action in respect of these matters. That action will continue. I am not in a position to foreshadow outcomes at this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why then did the Government reverse its position on the greenhouse limits, the 20 per cent reduction by 2005? Will that decision by the Government be reversed in the light of this statement by these leading scientists?

—The answer to that question is no, it will not be reversed on the basis of a statement by a group of scientists. All these issues were canvassed in the run-up to the Rio conference and again at the Rio conference. The fact that scientists have made a statement about these issues will not, I think, change the Government's view. It was our concern, as we are a substantial producer of fossil fuels, that we should not be the leader of the world in respect of the greenhouse targets originally discussed. But I do not think it is fair to say that there was any significant change in the Government's position at any point in time. Some of the terminology in early papers was a bit fuzzy perhaps, but I do not think it is true to say that there was a change in the Government's position.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Family Support to the recent Australian Bureau of Statistics figures showing that one quarter of Australia's 4.5 million families have no member in employment, and that the number of families in which both partners are unemployed has increased by almost 2 1/2 times over the past two years. How does the Government account for the drop in the standard of living that Australians have suffered under this Labor Government?

—I have not seen that report. The report I have seen, which goes very much to the issue of support for families and family income, was one issued recently by the Institute of Family Studies. That report goes to the question of what levels of government support there have been for low income families and non-income families. This independent report recognises that this Government appreciates the human side of being unemployed and recognises the Government's strong agenda for action and its commitment to maintain that agenda.

PARA.TAB: The Government's approach to helping unemployed families is starkly different to that of the Opposition. We provide adequate income support tied to active labour market assistance. Unlike the Opposition, we will ensure that income support is maintained. We also will ensure that when the unemployed achieve jobs they will not have their wages reduced to a level as low as the Jobsearch allowance or Newstart payments.

Over a number of years we have achieved adequacy benchmarks for child payments. Those benchmarks mean that needy families with children get targeted assistance. We have also ensured that that assistance is indexed and that the value of that assistance is maintained. These are the most important benchmarks that have been achieved by the Government: the targeting of assistance, the maintaining of indexed payments and the maintaining of real value of those payments.

For instance, over the life of this Government child payments for low income families have risen in real terms by 74 per cent for children under the age of 13 and by 146 per cent for children between 13 and 15 years. As opposed to that, the policy of the other side, though crying false tears about the unemployed, is geared very much to ensuring that the benefits and the job opportunities that might be presented to those people who are unemployed are reduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Of course, the best type of welfare measure—and the Minister has been concentrating on welfare measures—is to give people jobs. Given the statement by Mr Hawke when he was Prime Minister that no Australian child shall be living in poverty under an ALP Government after 1990, can the Minister account for the doubling since 1990 of the number of families in which there are two or more children, aged 14 years and under, whose parents are unemployed?

—To be honest in this debate, one has to approach it not as a parasite, not as a pariah on those who are unemployed in this society. As a government, we recognise that they should not be used as political fodder, as the Opposition obviously intends to do. Reports recently have indicated that this Government's measures have ensured that the percentage of those living below the poverty level as a proportion of our community has decreased. I think that should be recognised. The problem that Senator Tierney and the Opposition have is that they are out of time. They are proposing a policy to the electorate that is geared to the 1980s, not the 1990s. How will they create jobs when they are to reduce Commonwealth expenditure by $10 billion?
—Order! The Minister is out of time!

—I address my question to the Minister for Justice. Will the Minister advise the Senate of the outcome of discussions designed to achieve cooperative arrangements between law enforcement authorities and community organisations with regard to a national approach to crime prevention. Has that approach been supported by police Ministers from all States? What benefits will it bring to the community?

—I am delighted to say that there is now a nationwide realisation that there has to be a community based approach to crime prevention and community safety issues. Certainly the police Ministers, in convening a special meeting in Melbourne late last week, gathered together a group of people, not only from business, such as the Insurance Council of Australia, but also from many community organisations with wide neighbourhood networks—I am thinking of the Australian Council on the Ageing, the National Council of Women, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia and so on—together with experts in criminology and other fields. We discussed the whole question of a strategy which would involve a change in the expectations and culture of the community in relation to the incidence of crime.

PARA.TAB: It is quite clear that the matter cannot be left to a simple reliance on the police forces and other elements of the law enforcement community, whether one is talking about the criminal justice system, corrections, prisons and so on. I know that we have guests from the United States in the gallery, but I do believe that rather than spending a tremendous amount of funds on imprisoning people as an answer to the question of crime and the incidence of criminal activity in our community as has occurred in some nations around the world, our approach has to be community based—based in the neighbourhood networks which can galvanise their energies and harness their enthusiasm in coming up with crime prevention and community safety programs which will prevent the incidence of crime in the first place.

I believe that this is not simply a question for police Ministers or law enforcement agencies. Indeed, the better cities program, for example, and the designing into criteria for urban planners of strategies which can help reduce the incidence of crime—simple matters such as lighting and access—are all important ways in which the community can help to deal with that particular matter. It does involve a change of culture and expectations. It is akin to the way in which the Australian community over the last decade or so has reacted to the whole question of the incidence of disease and injury in the community by looking to health measures—preventative measures in the field of health and safety—as a way of minimising the incidence and occurrence of disease and injury in the community.

Something similar has to occur in relation to the incidence of crime. I believe that with the support of Labor Ministers from Western Australia, South Australia, Queensland and the Australian Capital Territory, and Liberal Ministers from Victoria, New South Wales and Tasmania, and the Country-Liberal Party Leader from the Northern Territory, we have a very firm non-partisan Australia-wide basis for tackling this change of culture and expectation that is required.

I believe that we can harness the energies of community organisations in the neighbourhood networks in this task of preventing crime occurring and ensuring the safety of communities. I look forward to working cooperatively with those organisations over the coming year to get a nationwide strategy in place with full support from all political organisations throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that the Department of Defence decided that the Australian Army signallers who went to the western Sahara as part of a UN peace force would carry their Steyr rifles for their personal protection, as is the usual practice of Australian UN peace forces? Secondly, did the Moroccans disarm the Australians and deny them the retention of their weapons, and does that situation still exist?

—On deployment to the western Sahara a substantial amount of Australian equipment was seized by the Moroccans in transit—not only rifles, but also communication equipment, et cetera. We have had to work our way around that problem. I did check when the first commander redeployed back to Australia whether any of these equipment deficiencies were in any way impairing our operations and it was his view that they were not. It has taken a lot of diplomatic effort to try to free that equipment up, not all of those have been successful so far. We have run into a great degree of intransigence and it is a matter of regret to me that the Moroccan Government has taken this action.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is not clear from the Minister's answer whether they have their personal weapons. Since it was decided as part of the risk assessment that they should have their rifles for personal protection, surely this is a position that is intolerable for the Australian Government. If the argument is that there is now a negligible risk, why were civilian communicators or the police force not sent, as was done in the case of Cyprus?

—I will check what final arrangements have been made in terms of arms carrying. On the second part of the question, I think the threat assessment has lowered at this stage. As Senator MacGibbon knows, we were committed to stay in the western Sahara only until March next year. We have made major efforts, as has Senator Evans, to try to get the UN to focus on a resolution of the western Saharan problem. The initial deployment was meant to be for 35 weeks. It was meant to settle down both sides and supervise so that a referendum could occur. Negotiations have travelled at a snail's pace. We have put pressure, through our representatives in the United Nations, to try to bring about some resolution, either to hold the referendum or to finalise United Nations' involvement in western Sahara.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 November, Senator Coulter asked a number of questions relating to Magnetic Island. I now have information from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories relating to those questions. I seek leave, because of their length, to incorporate the answers in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answers read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Why were letters from Simon Woodley, Environment Section of GBRMPA, dated from late July to 4 August 1989, not put before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal when it heard an appeal by Island Voice against permission to construct the Magnetic Keys Development on Magnetic Island?
2. Is it not likely that if these letters had been produced before the AAT, the Tribunal may have reached a very different conclusion?

3. The recently released Whitehouse Inquiry concluded that "No adequate insurance policy covering rehabilitation in the event of financial failure was taken out. . . as required by the terms of paragraph 3.1 of the Deed of Agreement" and "The reason why the insurance coverage required by the Deed of Agreement was not taken out is unclear". Can the Minister now shed more light on why, having pursued the matter of insurance most assiduously GBRMPA suddenly dropped all requirements for insurance with the disastrous economic and environmental results which are now all too apparent?

1. The letters from Mr Woodley from July and August 1989 were not placed before the AAT when it requested documents on the Magnetic Quays case as the request for documentation was issued by the AAT in early April 1989 and the relevant documents presented to the Tribunal in late April 1989, ie. before Mr Woodley's letters came into existence.

Subsequent hearings were concerned with the question of legal standing of Island Voice regarding the appeal of the Authority's decision and consideration of applications for Stay of Works in which such correspondence was not relevant nor do I believe it was requested by the Tribunal.

2. The Tribunal did not reach a finding on the Magnetic Quay issue as Island Voice withdrew the appeal from the AAT before the Tribunal had the opportunity to consider the matter. The Tribunal had sat and given legal standing to Island Voice regarding the appeal of the Authority's decision, and had considered several applications for Stay of Works. If the appeal had gone ahead, all relevant documents, including the referenced letters, would have been provided as requested.

3. Mr Whitehouse's report is critical of the adequacy of insurance for the Magnetic Quay site and as a result of his findings the insurance matter was referred to the Attorney-General's Department for advice. Attorney-General's Department supports the Authority's consistently stated position that because removal of the breakwalls was not regarded as a practical proposition, the insurance did not cover that eventuality. The Attorney-General's Department also supports the Authority that having regard to the terms of the permit and the Deed it would have been inappropriate for the Authority to insist on "performance insurance" (of the type designed to ensure that developments are completed in circumstances, for example, where a construction company for financial reasons is unable to complete a project), as it had already determined that a performance bond in the form of a bank guarantee to the value of $500,000 would be appropriate to ensure that the project would be carried out in an appropriate manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in response to the questions without notice asked by Senator Childs and Senator Crane on 24 November 1992 relating to industrial relations and unions.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to a question by Senator Childs, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, made a remark that the Government was in a win-win situation with workers and employers. I find this absolutely extraordinary. Here we have a Government that has presided over a situation where there are over one million people out of work under the Government's failed accord. Yet the Minister for Industrial Relations comes in here, day after day, answering dorothy dix questions, supporting a policy which has failed. Senator Cook has a habit of doing this on a daily basis. He ignores the fact that the Government has run out of policies. It has no policies whatsoever, but its Ministers have a habit of coming in here and criticising part of Fightback, which is here to engender and to create employment within the community.

PARA.TAB: I make the point very strongly that the Jobsback policy is to do with freedom to the people. Senator Cook talked about working with the people and not against them. How about being honest for a change? How about being honest and coming out and saying he is not working for the people; he could not give a damn about the people. He is working for his trade union mates. He has an obligation back to them.

I have a checklist of members of the Ministry and Parliamentary Secretaries. I think that 19 of them are card carrying members of the trade union movement. That is where the Government's loyalty lies. It has no option but to support the trade union movement. Every time we get this childish scare campaign—

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing?
—Listen to me for a change.
—Order! There are too many interjections.
—About 70 per cent of the people in the private sector in this country work under enterprise based agreements with no union involvement whatsoever. We do not see them being screwed into the ground.
—They are.

—They are, those opposite say. Here we have Senator Sherry, a trade union apparatchik who has a vested interest in supporting his own power structure. The concern of the Labor Party is that it is the political arm of the trade union movement. This is shown quite categorically just by these few numbers I was able to pull out in respect of those people who are card carrying members of a very tiny group in this country—not the workers but the people who lead these militant unions themselves.

PARA.TAB: What the Jobsback program is all about is to put the trade union movement in the same competitive atmosphere as that which exists throughout Australia for every other industry and on the international market. The trade union movement will know—as will Senator Childs because he was involved in this years ago—that if we offer a good product people will buy it. Jobsback provides for people voluntarily, not by compulsion, to be a member or not to be a member of the trade union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you don't accept, you don't have a job.

—Senator Sherry goes into an absolute frenzy because we are saying that people have freedom of choice. We are offering the Australian people, the Australian workers, freedom of choice. This throws the whole labour movement into a total frenzy because, without the locked in membership of the trade union movement, those opposite are nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard a somewhat sad and pathetic effort by the Opposition here to turn this debate away from the issues of merit and into a personal attack on the trade union movement and on the associations that some members of Cabinet and the Executive may have as individual members of unions and who have retained those links whilst in government. Resort to the facts will always cripple an argument of this superficiality. The argument that is put is that somehow or other wages as negotiated by the union movement are the cause of the level of unemployment in Australia. Let us just go to the facts. We took over government in this country in 1983.
—Who is `we'—the union movement?

—The Labor Party. At that stage, there was double-digit unemployment, double-digit inflation and negative industrial growth in the economy. We then negotiated, at peak level, an accord with the trade union movement that guaranteed moderate wage outcomes, tax cuts and an increase in services provided by the State to the community so that the relative position of families would not be worse as a result of their having less income from wages. We then negotiated that package. What did it do? It meant that, during the whole period from 1983 until the recession, wages outcomes were moderate, the growth rates in the Australian economy were dramatic, and the level of employment increased amazingly so that the participation rate—which measures the number of people looking for work in the economy—rose well above the levels it had been cowed into during the period of the Fraser Government when those opposite were in power.

PARA.TAB: So, during a time of rapid growth in employment and rapid economic growth when the trade union movement's bargaining power was at an optimum, wage increases for the first time in our history were moderate and consistent with the macro-economic goals of the economy. Thus it was that we were able to develop an economy working in partnership with social forces—not dividing the community through fighting and warring with it, but working in partnership with the social forces to establish an outcome for Australia in macro terms which was beneficial.

We were then hit by the effect of the international recession. We were then hit by the effect on our exports, particularly in agricultural goods, of closed markets in Europe which had a devastating effect; the economic enhancement program in the United States for wheat; the closure of Eastern Europe; the impact on Japan of these circumstances which meant lower prices for wool and wheat out of Australia; and we—and we have admitted this—kept monetary policy too tight for too long. In those circumstances Australia moved into a recession—just like the rest of the world.

Now we have competing economic formulae. The way in which anyone indicates a true concern for unemployment is by laying down a human policy on how to deal with it and how to support the unemployed during their time of unemployment. We have a policy which does that; the Opposition does not. We have a policy which guarantees fair bargaining in the workplace with the resort to an independent arbitrator, if necessary, to resolve complex difficulties.

The Opposition proposes to turn workplace policy into a position of Australian versus Australian. Individual workers will be required to negotiate individual work contracts with their employer without resort to arbitration or to fairness and with no governing minimum standards which will guarantee fair economic outcomes. The Opposition's policy is one of total exploitation and division.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Senator Cook has the capacity to live in a dream world and talk total, unreal nonsense. It will be recalled that Mr Keating and Mr Hawke misled the people of Australia in 1990 with the greatest lie ever told, yet this Minister comes in here and says that the world depression created the problems for Australia.

PARA.TAB: We all know what created the problems for Australia. It was interest rates at 25 per cent. This Government was screwed by Mr Keating when he was Treasurer, notwithstanding the advice of people like Senator Button who repeatedly told him that his interest rates were too high. But Mr Keating when Treasurer took no notice of Senator Button or other advisers who were telling him that he was creating a situation where a massive depression would occur. That is what led this country into the depression, not the world crisis which we are now facing.

Let us look at the two countries of New Zealand and Australia and at what has happened over the past 12 months to wage rates in New Zealand. Believe it or not, there has been a one per cent real increase in wage rates in New Zealand, whereas in Australia there has been a 0.5 per cent decrease in real wages. Those are very interesting figures which the Labor Party ought to take into account.

Today we also heard Senator Cook talking about increases in executive salaries. I agree that increases in executive salaries at present are outrageous, but what is this Government doing about government business enterprise salaries which are paid at the executive level? It is doing absolutely nothing in an area where it may be able to exercise some degree of control. All Senator Cook is doing is trying to mislead the people by saying, `Look over here. Look over there. Don't look at the problem that we have created. Try to look at something else that is going on in this country, such as executive salaries'. I agree with Senator Cook that executive salaries are exorbitant, but what is he doing about the executive salaries in government business enterprises? He is doing absolutely nothing.

The wage increases for executive officers are occurring under an ALP Government with ALP policies and the ALP system in place. The ALP has been in government for nearly 10 years, and the Labor Party cannot now blame everything on what happened prior to 1983. The Labor Government is responsible for these policies and for the existing situation. It is responsible for the rate of unemployment and the exorbitant increase in executive salaries, or at least it carries the responsibility for not doing anything about these salaries by introducing some sort of bargaining process. It is the ALP's responsibility, because it is the one in government. It is about time the Government realised that the things it is complaining about are all the responsibility of the ALP and its policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate to defend the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Peter Cook. Firstly, I wish to make some comment about the fairly pathetic attempts made by Senator Parer and Senator Lewis to defend the Opposition's industrial relations policy. If that is the extent of their justification for the Opposition's proposals, no wonder they are behind in the polls.

PARA.TAB: Senator Parer made some extremely irrelevant remarks. It may be fact that 19 members of the Ministry are members of trade unions. It is almost as relevant as our looking through the list of Opposition members, picking those who are farmers and finding out whether they are in the National Farmers Federation. So what? We do not accuse those opposite of being a lobby group subservient to the National Farmers Federation just because there may be a dozen persons over there who may be in the Federation. So damn what? That is the sort of irrelevancy that those opposite bring into this argument and it is no wonder they are behind in the polls.

Members of the Opposition talk about freedom of choice. All they do is talk rhetoric about freedom of choice. Giving an employer freedom is not creating an equal bargaining position. How can those opposite expect an individual employee who may have just left school to sit down and argue, debate and come to a contractual arrangement with an employer? How can those opposite expect them to have the knowledge or the education, to come to an agreement with an employer on an equal footing? The employer may be supported by a lawyer and advised by an accountant, and Opposition members do not even want a union there to advise the employee. Yet they argue that that is fair and equal.

At the end of the day, if the employee does not accept the contract he or she does not have a job. Yet Opposition members argue that that is fair and equal. That is their concept of choice and freedom. Workers in this country can see through it. They do not want that sort of choice. They do not want that sort of freedom because it means that employers will have the upper hand and they will exercise it. Those opposite know it because that is what they want.

Those opposite talk about the overseas experience. They did make one legitimate reference; they made the legitimate reference to the fact that in most countries overseas there is this sort of system. There is so-called free collective bargaining. If that is the case, why is the United Kingdom in a worse recession than Australia? If there is freedom of the labour market, why is the United Kingdom not booming? Why is unemployment as high as it is in Australia? Why do we see the same situation in the United States?

Free labour markets do not mean reductions in unemployment. What they do lead to is a redistribution of wealth and that is what those opposite are all about—a redistribution of wealth away from those in the community who are on less than average weekly earnings to those who have power and are on high incomes. That is what they are all about—redistribution of wealth.

It is the same with the goods and services tax. We can see it on the faces of members of the Opposition. The opinion polls show that they cannot convince the Australian electorate and that is why they are going to lose the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Parer's motion to take note of this answer. I particularly want to deal with the aspect of the question I asked and the extraordinary personal attack on me that came from the lips of Minister Cook. I note that the Minister has left the chamber. I was going to remind him that when he is in this chamber and is asked a question, he is not with his union mates somewhere else.

PARA.TAB: Today I asked the Minister whether he had a copy of a report about infiltration of powerful unions and, if he had not, whether he proposed to obtain a copy and whether he would immediately investigate the allegation that had been made. PARA.TAB: Once again, what does this Minister do when he is asked a hard question? He attacks the individual. SPEECH.PARA: Some Japanese investors say they would be prepared to pay bribes to building unions to ensure projects are completed on time.
Mr David Edwards, the Chief Executive of the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry, said that building unions are powerful and not accountable to the membership. He then said:
