TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a brief contribution to this debate on the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) to a question at Question Time. In his contribution, Senator Lewis invoked, as Opposition members are keen to do, the situation in New Zealand. Having recently returned from New Zealand, I found somewhat extraordinary Senator Lewis's claim that after one year of the Employment Contracts Act in New Zealand wages are up.

PARA.TAB: I want to make it clear on what basis that claim was made. To do that we need to look at the source of the statistics. There are no statistics on the legislation in New Zealand for workplaces with fewer than 50 employees—and that is the majority of workplaces in New Zealand. Many of the larger work sites for which there are statistics, after just over 12 months of operation, are able to retain, and are retaining, union representation and are still bargaining collectively. So, if we are prepared to accept figures for the minority of the work force in New Zealand, we must realise that those figures are affected by the fact that collective bargaining has been able to continue in a good many of those instances.

As for the much vaunted so-called economic recovery of New Zealand, which is also often referred to in this context by Opposition members, it is true that there are some signs, in that inflation has been lowered and there has been some increase in exports. In the case of lowered inflation, as is the case in this country, one only has to speak to those families where the breadwinner is unemployed or to sole parent families about the joys of reduced and very low inflation. They will tell you that they cannot eat low inflation or put shoes on their kids with low inflation.

As to the increase—slight though it is—of exports from New Zealand, over the past 12 to 18 months there has been an extraordinary increase in the exports of virgin timber in often unsafe ships out of New Zealand, particularly into Asian markets. That is an unsustainable increase in exports which is only of short term value in developing the economy of New Zealand. It is a short term, exploitative economic and industrial relations policy that takes no account of the real lives of ordinary people. The Opposition would do well to look again, with both eyes open, at what is happening in New Zealand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleague and friend Senator Crane in his endeavours to ensure that the union movement in this country is not infiltrated by terrorist organisations. After all, that was the basis of the question which Senator Crane asked the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) today. It was also the basis of a rambling, ranting and thoroughly irrelevant response from the Minister—a response which has been continued by some of his colleagues on the opposite side of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: For the record, let us get this very clear. Senator Crane has said in this place—all of my colleagues thoroughly support him—that the activities of the corrupt and venal minority of troublemakers in the union organisation are a slur on the innocent and upstanding men and women of this country, many of whom are forced into the union movement against their will. That is the problem we have to face.

I see Senator Sherry on the other side of the chamber rolling his eyes and throwing his head and shoulders around, as though he did not have enough opportunity to do it when he was on his feet. Perhaps we should remind Senator Sherry that the organisations that he purports to represent have done absolutely nothing to improve the rights of the individuals that are part of those organisations. Senator Sherry would like us to believe that the people on his side of the chamber support freedom of association. Yet those are the people who in the dead of night rushed legislation through Parliament last year to limit the size of unions so that one could not legally belong to a union unless it had 10,000 members. So much for freedom of association, so much for human rights and so much for free choice! The people on that side of the chamber refuse to allow Australian workers to make a decision as to whether or not they want to belong to a union.

Senator Sherry and some of his colleagues would have us believe that there is no compulsion in joining a union. The experience of my brother when he was at school and working with a newspaper putting the colour inserts in at 11 o'clock on a Saturday night or 1 o'clock on a Sunday morning was quite the contrary. The print union said, `You, brother, don't have a union ticket. You either get a union ticket or you lose your job'. He said, `You can't do that; you don't employ me'. It said, `We'll fix you'. On top of that, it took him down for $150, which was two weeks of his net pay, and did absolutely nothing for him when the newspaper closed down. So much for free speech, so much for freedom of

SPEECH.PARA: association and so much for freedom of choice! That is what those unions are doing to the workers of this country; they are exploiting them.

PARA.TAB: We are saying that there is an alternative to the union bully boy tactics which we see on the other side—that is, to give employees and employers a reason to negotiate together to have a stake in the future of their enterprise. Lest anybody on the other side is under any misapprehension, when that was done in Queensland the workers at Power Brewery ended up earning $4,000 a year more than their unionised brothers in Castlemaine Perkins on the other side of town.

The runs are on the board, but the only people who are running at the moment are the people on the other side of the chamber who realise that they might end up out of a job because there will be no more place for union bully boys in the sort of Australia which we in the coalition propose. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much of the debate that has gone on so far has been on the basis of the article which appeared in the West Australian on Tuesday, 24 November 1992. Many allegations have been made. As Senator Crane has said, they come from a police report which has not been officially released, as this article says. Senator Crane relied very heavily on the opinion of the Chief Executive of the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Mr David Edwards, who is not disposed to our side of politics. He quoted him but did not quote the particular paragraph reporting what David Edwards had to say about the allegations—they are no more than that—that have been made in the chamber today. Senator Crane might read this with me. The article states:

PARA.TAB: Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry chief executive David Edwards said he had heard similar allegations about building unions but had not seen any proof.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for any of us to get up in this chamber and make allegations about people, associations or groups on the basis of facts that have not been established. It is always helpful if one is going to make allegations in this chamber or anywhere else against a group or against people that one does so on the basis of established evidence. I think much credit must be given to David Edwards—as I say, he is not a person who supports this side of the chamber—for saying that. When these allegations were put to him, he said that he had heard similar allegations but had not seen any proof. One thing that is clear today is that absolutely no proof has been brought into this chamber. Allegations have been made—inferentially, not explicitly—without any proof being put before this chamber. Someone who is intimately related with the union movement in Victoria—that is, Mr David Edwards—has said that he has seen no proof.

PARA.TAB: Mr David Edwards said that building unions were powerful and were not accountable to membership. Of course they are powerful. His opinion is that they are not accountable to the membership. But that is not what has been put today against the unions. What has been put is criminal activity. Mr David Edwards goes on to say that if there is evidence of this sort of activity, it should be investigated. What he is saying is that he knows of no evidence and, if there is any evidence at all, there ought to be an investigation.

What Mr Edwards is saying is exactly the opposite to what Senator Crane is saying. Senator Crane says that there ought to be investigations on the basis of allegations. What Mr Edwards is saying, and saying quite properly, is that there should be no investigations until there is at least some evidence to support that sort of thing. I say: great credit to Mr Edwards.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for the debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation because I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr President. In answer to a question I asked today the Minister, Senator Cook, said:

SPEECH.PARA: One thing we can be sure of when Senator Crane asks a question is that he will indulge his bigotry, prejudice and narrow-mindedness by holding the view that unions are bad and therefore must be removed from society.

That is an extraordinary statement. It is false and I will come to that. In my question today I asked whether the Minister had a copy of the report; if not, did he intend to get a copy of the report; and whether he would investigate the allegations. That was the basis of my question.

PARA.TAB: The Minister, in his answer, said that I indulge my `bigotry, prejudice and narrow-mindedness by holding the view that unions are bad and therefore must be removed from society'. Mr President, I have never said that. In fact, I have made comments to the contrary in this chamber. As people sitting on this side and the other side of the chamber would know, I did oppose the formation of mega-unions. In fact, last week when I addressed the Australian Services Union I said that under our policy the good unions would earn their stripes and grow and the bad unions would fall away. In fact, I am proud to be a member of the National Farmers Federation and the Western Australian Farmers Federation, which are unions made up of farmers. I make no bones about that. But for the Minister to claim that I hold the view—
Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is my freedom of choice. A 10,000 mega-membership is not required for that.

—Mr President, on a point of order: could I suggest that the honourable senator is going beyond the point of a personal explanation and is now debating again the substance of Senator Cook's response. Might I suggest that he be asked to bring his personal explanation to a conclusion.
—It is a personal explanation. Senator Crane should not debate the issue.

—If the Minister had not intervened I would have finished my personal explanation by now. He described me as `holding the view that unions are bad and therefore must be removed from society'. That is just not true. It is deliberately false. If the Minister had any principles at all, he would come into this place and withdraw that whole statement.

—Order! I said during Question Time that I would have a look at the Hansard. I have had a chance to look at it. In the circumstances I regard what Senator Cook said as being unparliamentary. However, he has withdrawn. I thought he said that the question was bigoted and prejudiced but, in fact, he did not say that; he said that Senator Crane was. Therefore, it is unparliamentary.

—Mr President, may I seek your guidance? I think that should be withdrawn unequivocally and unconditionally. The Minister only said that he would withdraw `gracefully'—not even `graciously'—and he is not particularly graceful, if you ask me. Could I seek your clarification as to whether he will be asked to withdraw it unconditionally?
—I asked him to withdraw the statement and he did. I regard it as concluded. He withdrew.

—Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 14 November 1992 of Alan William Jarman, a former member of the House of Representatives for the Division of Deakin from 1966 to 1983.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia should retain the current National Flag which has flown over the country since Federation. This flag
symbolises the world's oldest democracy
represents our history, our culture and our language
enjoys the support of the vast majority of the Australian people
symbolises the sacrifice of our armed servicemen and women
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should retain the current national flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bishop (from 167 citizens) and Senator O'Chee (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1.We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL FLAG.
2.We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the Nation's history.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Ferguson (from 41 citizens) and Senator O'Chee (from 11 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Bender's Quarry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned, noting that Senator Robert Bell has introduced a Bill into the Senate to ensure that no further blasting at Bender's Quarry is permitted without the consent of both Houses of Parliament, respectfully call upon the Federal Government to support the Bill.

PETITION.TITLE: Goods and Services Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned respectfully call upon all members of the Senate to vote against any legislation that introduces a goods and services tax.

PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of the Nullarbor Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned oppose the attempts by the Federal Government to World Heritage List the Nullarbor Region.
In doing so, we condemn the State and Federal Government for failing to consult with the residents of the Nullarbor in relation to the listing proposal.
Further, we affirm the excellent record of pastoralists, highway operators and the local communities in protecting the heritage and environmental value of the region.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia who are believers in the Lord Jesus Christ, who fear God and seek to practise the teachings of Jesus Christ and His apostles in the Holy Bible, draws to your attention that:
Marriage is a divinely instituted relationship, intrinsically based on the faithfulness of the husband and wife—it is a moral, physical and legal contract.
The present Family Law Act debases the marriage contract by recognising de-facto relationships and failing to recognise marriage breakdown on a moral basis.

The only scriptural basis for divorce is adultery. `Whosoever shall put away his wife, except it be for fornication, and shall marry another, committeth adultery: and whoso marrieth her which is put away doth commit adultery'. (Matthew 19 v 9)
Your petitioners therefore as in duty bound pray and ask the Honourable House that:
1. The Family Law Act be amended to recognise the moral (the greatest) component of the marriage contract, reintroduce adultery as valid ground for divorce, and
2. Clearly uphold the distinction and honour of the marriage relationship.

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request that:

PARA.TAB: Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia as our head of State.

PETITION.TITLE: British Commonwealth Occupation Forces, Japan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectively request that:

That all former members of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (B.C.O.F.) Japan, who have not established eligibility through other military service, be granted eligibility for the Service Pension, and all benefits thereto, including the issue of campaign medals.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to so grant this request by legislation enacted by Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:
The undersigned petitioners are citizens of Australia who humbly (but urgently) submit their Christian convictions regarding the practice of abortion.

We are all believers in the Lord Jesus Christ and our convictions are based on the absolute and unerring authority of God's word expressed in the Holy Scriptures. The following is therefore humbly submitted to the house:

PARA.TAB: Both conception and life are God-given.
"The Lord gave her conception. . . " (Ruth 4 v 13)

PETITION.PARA: ". . . himself giving to all life, and breath and all things" (Acts 17 v 25)
Abortion infringes God's life-giving rights. Therefore the practice of abortion is murder and a sin against God.

PARA.TAB: "Though shalt not kill" (Exodus 20 v 13)

PETITION.PARA: God's law (not human expedience) must prevail in this serious moral issue before Government.
To support the practice of abortion is also to jeopardise the Nation's welfare for which Government is responsible. (Proverbs 14 v 34)
Your petitioners humbly plead that the house cease to condone abortion by a
resolution to terminate medicare support of this unrighteous practice.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showed that:

1. Many Australians agree with the stated aim of the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship, namely to encourage the return of world class expatriate researchers, to support high quality research and to develop research skills fundamental to the nations national interest with the aim of boosting Australia's research and technology push.
2. We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship continue to be tenable at the Institute of Advanced Studies of ANU and CSIRO.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Adult Migrant Education Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and the Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled.

The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Adult Migrant Education Program (AMEP), including Workplace English Language and Literacy, must continue as a fully Government funded educational program with equality of access for all non-English speaking permanent residents.
We call on the Federal Government not to implement fees for adult English as a Second Language (ESL) programs. Many migrants who are not exempt cannot afford to pay fees.
We call on the Federal Government to remove the limit of 510 hours tuition, because most students need a minimum of 900 hours of English for work of further study.

We call on the Federal Government to restore access to all migrants and refugees regardless of length of residence in Australia and employment status, and to provide continuing funding for all adult ESL Programs to public education institutions, in particular AMES.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Select Committee on Superannuation has been one of the most active committees in the Parliament and has operated in a sea of change. During the past 14 months, the Committee has met on 74 occasions and tabled eight reports and issues papers during that time.

PARA.TAB: Its business before the end of 1992 will concentrate on the reforms relating to taxation, vesting, simplification and RBLs. The Committee has still to resolve the matter of fees, charges and commissions. This is a difficult area which will need close scrutiny. There is also the matter of preservation age changes which, as yet, have not been introduced into the Parliament.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's response to the report prepared by the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, following its inquiry into Australia's relations with Latin America. In so tabling the report I note that we are honoured by the presence in the gallery today of heads of mission from nearly all of the Latin American countries that are represented in Australia. I thank them for their patience in sitting through the nonsense that has preceded this tabling debate.

PARA.TAB: I would like, first of all, to compliment the Committee for its excellent work on this subject over the past two years. I would also like to acknowledge the efforts of the wide range of organisations and individuals who contributed to the Committee's hearings. Like the Committee, the Government was pleasantly surprised by the large number of submissions made to the inquiry. All of these have helped to generate a considerably greater level of interest in Latin America within political, business and academic circles in Australia.

The Government warmly welcomes the Committee's report. It provides a wealth of information on Australia's existing political, economic and cultural links with Latin America and, in doing so, exposes the depth and extent of the linkages which have been formed, if rather quietly, over recent years.

Prior to the Committee's inquiry, awareness of these links was not widespread. The geographical distance and cultural differences which separate Australia and Latin America have served to keep us somewhat in mutual ignorance of each other. However, I am confident that the Senate Committee's report, and the Government's response to it, together mark an important step in redressing this problem.

The report comes at a particularly appropriate time. This year marks the 500th anniversary of the arrival of Christopher Columbus in the New World, and it is quite fitting that Australians take stock of recent developments in Latin America which have transformed the nature of this region. Indeed, the changes which have occurred in Latin America over the last 10 years have been almost revolutionary in nature. Practically the whole of the continent is now governed by freely elected leaders and parliaments. This is a far cry from the situation only 10 years ago when much of the continent was ruled by the military. I should also note that governments in Latin America have made real progress towards ensuring that the human rights of all people in the region are recognised. Cuba now stands alone in rejecting the trend towards greater political freedoms and pluralism.

Latin America is also being transformed economically. Governments throughout the region are now introducing a wide range of new economic measures which are designed to free up internal markets and to open them to external trade and competition. As a consequence of this, Latin America is now characterised by economic frameworks which emphasise efficiency and productivity instead of state control. In addition, Latin American countries are moving to more closely align their economies with those of their regional neighbours. This is occurring through bilateral trade arrangements, such as that signed between Chile and Mexico, and through wider intra-regional organisations such as the Mercosur and the Andean Pact. This has not, however, caused Latin American countries to lose sight of the importance of multilateral trade liberalisation. We have greatly valued the partnership of several Latin American countries in the Cairns Group. All these developments necessarily mean that Australia can and should take a much greater interest in Latin America than has previously been the case.

As the responses to the Committee's 63 recommendations make clear, the Government is fully aware of these changes. Indeed, we have been following them closely, especially during the last three years. We continue to look for new ways to respond to these opportunities, particularly in terms of identifying potential new trade and investment linkages. It is pleasing to note that, partly as a result of the Government's promotional efforts, Australian companies have taken a higher profile in Latin America in recent years. This has been especially so in the minerals sector. The success of BHP's investment in the Escondida copper mine in Chile speaks for itself. I would encourage more Australian business people to travel to Latin America to see for themselves the opportunities which are available. The Government is keen to assist Australian companies in whatever way it can to develop economic links with Latin America. However, in the final analysis, as always, it is incumbent on these companies themselves to do the real work.

The Government also notes that the growing depth of the relationship with Latin America is not purely one-sided from Australia's point of view. Indeed, Latin American countries themselves are turning increasingly towards our own Asia-Pacific region. Like Australia, Latin America is actively seeking to diversify its trading and political linkages away from its traditional links with North America and Europe. The Australian Government welcomes Latin America's recognition that it too is an integral part of the Pacific Basin. A number of countries are already members of the Pacific Basin Economic Council, PBEC, and the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council, PECC. Some Latin American countries which border the Pacific have expressed a keen interest in eventual membership of the Asia Pacific Economic Council, APEC.

Australia has cooperated very closely with a number of Latin American countries in various multilateral matters. Indeed, Australia's multilateral ties to various Latin American countries have generally been more substantial than our links at the bilateral political level. I mentioned the Cairns Group, of which five of the 14 members are from Latin America. Six Latin American countries are consultative parties to the Antarctic Treaty and have established scientific research programs on that continent. The Government has also welcomed keen Latin American participation in the conference on disarmament, particularly in supporting Australia's efforts to secure an effective chemical weapons convention.

In concluding, I reiterate that the Government has recognised that, as a result of the political and economic changes which have taken place in Latin America, the future for this region does look considerably more optimistic than it once did. The Government recognises that there are excellent opportunities for closer cooperation across a broad range of political, economic and cultural activities. I again thank the Committee for helping to focus attention on those opportunities. I seek leave to move a motion.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) and, very broadly, the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia's relations with Latin America. I speak on behalf of the Liberal and National parties and also as Deputy Chairman of the Senate Committee that undertook this very sound, very constructive and timely inquiry. I, along with all the members of the Committee, thoroughly endorse the report.

PARA.TAB: Now that we have the Government's response, we can genuinely say that the Committee members and the Government are unanimous in regard to looking to greater substantial links between Australia and the Latin American countries—indeed, the whole region. At least 90 per cent of all the matters referred to in these two important documents have the full assent of the Australian representatives in this Parliament from both the Government and the Opposition. It is a bipartisan matter. The Minister said in his response:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government also warmly welcomes the Committee's report as providing a useful framework for public discussion on Australia's relationship with Latin America. The Government has found the Committee's analysis of recent trends in Latin America to be both well-informed and relevant to Australian interests.

The Government particularly welcomes the Committee's conclusion that Latin America as a region presents significant opportunities for Australia in a number of areas, particularly in the commercial sphere.

I endorse the Minister's statements. I briefly refer to the five mild criticisms that are set out on the second page of the Government's response. The first criticism is that the report tends to overlook a great deal of information about what the Government is already doing. I believe this is overly defensive on the Government's part. We have not overlooked the positive things the Government is doing that are referred to in our report and in the Government's response. But let it be clearly understood that we are not satisfied with the level of relations between Australia and Latin America. We are rebuking the Australian Government and, indeed, Australian business—especially those areas of business that can take up opportunities that are now presented—so that they change their inaction and ignorance, build upon the new open doors that are available and make sure that we live up to our opportunities. So if we have overlooked a certain amount of what the Government is doing and if the impression has been given that we are critical that the Government is not doing enough, then the Government has certainly got that message right.

PARA.TAB: The second mild criticism is that the report tends to look at the region in isolation from Australia's relations with the rest of the world. Certainly, our inquiry has been focused on Latin America. We have not tried to put Latin America in perspective with regard to Australia's relations with the rest of the world. However, we have said—for instance, in recommendation 14—that one per cent of Australia's exports are going to Latin America and that we would want to see that figure rise to 3 per cent by the end of this decade. That does give some perspective to the commercial links and possibilities that we see developing between Australia and this region. Of course, the great majority of Australia's commercial exchange is with Asia.

The third minor criticism is that we have not ranked our 63 recommendations. The Minister certainly got it right when he referred to recommendation 31: the Committee regards the setting up of a task force as a key recommendation. It seems that the Minister and the Government have fully accepted that key recommendation, and I welcome that. At least 50 of our recommendations can be treated alike: they all need to be implemented and they all need to be responded to in the positive way that the Government has done in this statement.

The fourth mild criticism is that we did not refer at any point in our report to the environment. I accept that criticism from the Government. We were so overwhelmed with the wide range of areas that we could report upon in this report that we did leave aside the important UN conference in Brazil and the priority increasingly given, and rightly so, by the Latin American countries to environmental concerns about the Amazon jungles, Antarctica, and practices in each country—both in the city and the countryside. Of course we want to endorse all that can positively be said about the environment. I welcome the Government's statement that it will include environmental matters in the work of the task force over the next two years.

As a Liberal senator seeking to represent free enterprise and to give maximum encouragement to free enterprise, I accept that we must involve the private sector in all that the Committee has recommended and all that the Government has responded to.

As our contributions are limited to these few minutes at this point, I have one clear proposal: now that we have the report and the Government response, I put to the Government that, with the cooperation of the Committee, there should be a translation of a summary of the report and the response of the Government into Spanish and that this new combined publication in the Spanish language be made available to the Latin American countries with the full assistance of all of the ambassadors from Latin America who are resident here in Canberra.

I recognise that those ambassadors are present in the gallery behind me, along with the principal officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade involved in Latin America and the members of the secretariat of the Committee. With their assistance and with the assistance of our five resident ambassadors in Latin America, I wish to see seminars held involving four elements—government, parliament, business and academics—one seminar to be held in each of the major cities of at least the eight countries during this coming year of 1993, from which there is some feedback, some response, and that reports of those seminars come to the Government and this Parliament so that we can hear a response from our counterparts in the Latin American countries to what we have determined in Australia. I hope that the Government will positively respond to this extra program, this extra suggestion, which I believe would be a very positive way of acting alongside the task force that is to meet in the next two years.

I quibble with the response to recommendation 31 to the extent that I believe we should have four quarterly meetings of the task force during 1993 and then two six-monthly meetings during 1994 rather than the four-only meetings that the Minister has just suggested. I hope that that point is negotiable, as I see the task force as being the principal coordinating body in carrying forward all that we have in the report and in the Government's response.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, and as Chairman of that Committee, I thank the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) for the Government response to the report of that Committee on Australia's relations with Latin America. I also thank particularly the staff of the Committee, the members of the Committee secretariat, who worked diligently and for long hours to help produce this report.

PARA.TAB: I thank all of the ambassadors from the Latin American countries who are resident in Canberra, including the four members of the diplomatic community who gave path-breaking evidence to the Committee in the course of this inquiry. I particularly thank the other seven members of the Committee for their diligence and hard work on a very long report—one that took some 14 months to complete but one which will be very worth while in the Australian body politic in the years ahead.

When I tabled the report in June this year, I registered the conviction of Committee members that Australia was in danger of missing out on trade and other opportunities in some 20 countries of an increasingly revitalised Latin America. We were hopeful that the Government would take up the report and its 63 recommendations in order to substantially improve relations between Australia and the republics of Latin America across a wide spectrum of activities. The challenge was to demonstrate that Australia has the capacity to project ahead, plan and put in place an appropriate framework for developing relations between Australia and a vital region but without neglecting the efforts that we rightly put into relations with Asia. It is with pleasure today that I note the Government's response to this report.

The first and most important response was to signal Australian Government recognition of Latin America as a region of importance to Australia—not in the same category of importance as Asia, nor with the same immediacy, but nevertheless as a vitally important region in the next decade. The policy framework, I am glad to note, has been set in the Minister's response. The Government's lengthy response itself will be a large body of useful opinion and information for the Australian community in a readily accessible form on many aspects of the Australian-Latin American relationship. Very importantly, it gives an up-to-date account of the action that the Government is taking.

I am pleased to note the Government's acceptance of what I believe are two major recommendations in the report. The first is recommendation 31, on the setting up of an interdepartmental task force for a period of two years to be chaired by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. This task force will be responsible for the vital role of canvassing and disseminating practical information and coordinating development of government policies on Latin America. I stress, from all the evidence that we on the Committee received and assessed, that the role of this task force in coordinating will be vitally important. There seemed to be a great lack of coordination between Government departments on some aspects of the relationship with Latin America. That will be an important factor to overcome.

The task force, of course, will also be a first point of reference on matters relating to Latin America. Indeed, some of the problems identified by the Committee, which form the basis of recommendations that the Government has accepted, will be coordinated by this task force. I refer, for example, to recommendation 2, on the collection and compilation of statistical data on Latin America, and recommendation 32, on the coordination of cultural and trade promotion activities.

The second important acceptance by the Government is that of recommendation 26 for a second weekly flight from Australia to Argentina and in reverse by Aerolineas Argentinas. As Chairman of the Committee, I expect that next April, at the end of the Southern Hemisphere summer, Aerolineas will continue with a second weekly flight each week of the year thereafter. A second weekly flight certainly would facilitate travel not only to Argentina but also to the immediate neighbouring countries of Chile, Brazil and Uruguay. I am pleased to see that the Government has not only indicated that it accepts this recommendation but has also already implemented it.

Overall, I welcome the Government's response. If we are to achieve a richer relationship with the republics of Latin America across a wide spectrum of activities, a great deal needs to be done. There is still an uphill battle to put in place the measures that will consolidate Australian-Latin American links—measures ranging from development of language skills, the issuing of visas and improving transport links, to the broader matter of increasing awareness in the Australian community and specifically the business community about the countries of Latin America. But I am confident that with the combined effort and goodwill of the Government, business and the academic community, and with the close cooperation of the Latin American representatives in Australia, we will in time achieve the aims that the Committee set out in its report.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak, albeit very briefly, to the Government response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia's relations with Latin America. I have only just got the response and therefore I cannot address it in detail, but I think that already it has demonstrated the value of the Senate Committee's work in this important area. Basically, it has forced the Government and the bureaucrats to address what I would describe as the underdeveloped relationship between Australia and the Latin American countries and the enormous potential to further extend the relationship to the benefit of both sides. So I rise, firstly, to give credit to the Senate Committee. I think its work in this area will have a long term benefit for Australia. This is another instance of the parliamentary committee system doing valuable but often unsung work for the benefit of the nation.

PARA.TAB: I reflect upon the fact that it seems to me that, in my 11 years here, really only in the last few years has the profile of Latin America risen, and I have wondered why. Firstly, I think it has occurred due to the endeavours of the Latin American missions in this country, particularly the heads of mission. In the last few years they have put in a real effort to educate Australia as to the opportunities that exist within their countries and to really demonstrate that Latin American countries are not so far distant nor so mysterious as they seem to be to Australians.

Their work has not only encouraged the Senate Committee, but also it has better informed this Parliament and, therefore, encouraged the Parliament to better inform the public. I give them and the Senate Committee credit. Thirdly, the successful realisation of opportunities by such Australian companies as BHP in Chile has really opened the eyes of other Australian companies and business enterprises as to these opportunities.

Success breeds success, and the benefit in dollar terms for Australia that is coming out of such investments is encouraging others. I am pleased to hear that not only are Australian mining houses now actively seeking joint ventures and investment in Chile, but also they are now pursuing new opportunities in Argentina, Colombia and Peru. Obviously, there will be enormous benefits for Australia in investing not so much its capital, but particularly its expertise and experience in mining development within Latin America in ways that will bring benefit to us all.

I commend the Committee and the fact that the Government has taken the Committee's report seriously and sought to address its recommendations in a constructive way. I support what Senator Maguire said and I commend him as Chairman of the Committee. I also commend my colleague Senator Teague, whom I would describe as an activist in terms of his personal endeavours in seeking to further develop this relationship.

Obviously transport links are critically important. I remember being in Venezuela and learning that Australian beer exported there has to travel via Yokohama city in Japan. That is just one demonstration of how far transport links have yet to develop in a way that will facilitate efficient trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did it taste different?

—I did not get to drink it; I was drinking the local product. That example is fairly typical. Transport links are underdeveloped. The direct air link to Buenos Aires is vitally important and I am pleased that a second flight is starting. As to the LAN-Chile link, I think there is approximately a 12-hour wait in Tahiti to meet up with a Qantas flight. Those sorts of things astonish me. Presumably there is some sensible reason for that, but it seems to me that if one is trying to encourage business linkages, one makes sure that flights such as that meet to facilitate efficient trade. Transport links need to be further developed.

PARA.TAB: The opportunities for business investment and trade within Australia need to be further promoted. I am pleased that Austrade is now operating its Latin American network out of Buenos Aires rather than from Miami in the United States. Nevertheless, Latin America is an enormous geographic region and one would hope that there will soon be a more complete network of Austrade representation that can further support Australian business endeavours. Education and communication of the opportunities also seem to me to be vitally important.

Fortunately, Australian business is starting to recognise the opportunities that are coming out of the development of the economies of the region, particularly the enhancement of the market process within the region. Some of the economic achievements in recent times have been astonishing and present real opportunities for us. Australian business is also encouraged by the return to civilian government by so much of the region and the democratisation process generally.

Really it is just a start, but, as the years progress, provided that transport links and education are improved and such facilitating organs as Austrade carry out their tasks, the relationships will become much more comprehensive and valuable to us in Australia. It demonstrates one further lesson: the danger in Australian foreign policy of orientating our direction simply towards the acknowledged opportunities in Asia; we run the risk of missing out on great opportunities that exist elsewhere in the world. Those opportunities within Latin America, as has been demonstrated by the work of the Senate and the response of the Government, are just another example of the benefits that can come from broad vision rather than narrow vision.

I commend all of those who have been involved and have participated in the work of building this relationship. I reiterate that there is still a long way to go, but I am pleased that at least a start has been made.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a pleasure to serve on the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade as we embarked upon this report to which the Government has responded today. It was an excellent report, which was comprehensive in its scope, and this is a fine response. There is no question but that the Government has taken the recommendations seriously and has sought to respond in the same comprehensive way.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Committee endeavoured to make an original contribution to our knowledge and understanding of the Australian relationship with Latin America, both as a region and in a bilateral sense on a country-to-country basis. The Committee achieved that. In large measure that is due not only to the diligence of the senators involved but also, as Senator Maguire said, to the outstanding contribution of our Committee secretariat, in particular Ms Ilza Svenne.

The Government's response across the board is encouraging. There is no question about that. The Committee's recommendations have been analysed in detail and the response is there in depth. Of course, changes have already been occurring in terms of the relationship. There is no doubt about that and much of that may be attributed to the extraordinary work of the Latin American diplomatic community here in Canberra, both as a collective and as individuals. I am pleased to see so many representatives of that community here in the gallery this afternoon as we debate the Government's response.

Not only has there been an improvement in relations on a business-like basis, but also a great many friendships have been formed. There is no question but that there now exists a de facto working alliance between the members of the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and the Latin American diplomatic community in terms of continuing the focus that the Committee began when it commenced its inquiry nearly 18 months ago.

It is true to say that the republics of Latin America and our own country have a great many elements in common in terms of common purpose, common objectives and common values—especially on matters of trade but not restricted to elements in the economic sphere. There is no question of the value of bilateral dealings with Latin America and also of the value of the relationships that have grown up through the Cairns Group of countries over the last five or six years.

It was significant—indeed, it was symbolic—of the changed relationship that when President Bush made his announcement during the American Presidential election campaign in Humboldt, South Dakota, of an extension of the export enhancement program, the two countries with which Australia cooperated most closely on that vexed question were Canada and Argentina. It is now a matter of history that there has been a breakthrough on the GATT and, hopefully, there will be a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round of talks. Much of that could not have been achieved without the close cooperation that has developed between Australia and a number of the republics of Latin America.

Our report ranged over issues such as trade, where the Committee recommended an improvement in the course of the decade of the 1990s from a one per cent share of Australian trade to a 3 per cent share by the turn of the century with Latin America; transport links, on which Senator Maguire has touched; investment links, on which Senator Teague has touched; education; and political and cultural exchanges.

On matters of politics, it is particularly useful for us to note that there has been a democratic revolution occurring and continuing to occur in Latin America—a reversal of the period 1964 to 1973 where, from the overthrow of President Goulart in Brazil to the overthrow of Allende in Chile, very brutal authoritarian regimes developed and stayed in power for some time. All that is now in the past. I saw it first hand as a member of an Australian parliamentary delegation to Argentina and Brazil just recently, meeting people as significant as the President and Foreign Minister of Argentina through to the leadership of the Congress in Brazil.

Some outstanding developments are occurring in a political sense. There is no doubt, for example, that in Brazil there is a great deal of pressure on the political system. But also today it is fair to say that the political system, the democratic system, is responding to the pressure in a way that Western democracies would find entirely acceptable. It is very pleasing to note that in much of the continent the military is consigned to its rightful place—the barracks.

In the very brief time allowed me, it is not possible to go into detail on the Government's response, but in particular the responses to recommendation 31 and recommendations 49 to 51 are pleasing; that is, on the task force and on the matters of ministerial, parliamentary and political exchanges. I do hope that the Australian Council for Political Exchange will be possessed of increased resources to ensure that political exchanges between Latin America and Australia grow on that level.
This report and the response of the Government should be seen as the start of the process, certainly not the finish. This should be seen as the beginning of an improvement in relations, not an end.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was proud to be part of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade looking into Australia's relations with Latin America. I join with my colleagues in congratulating the secretariat on a job very well done and also in acknowledging the work the Latin American missions in Canberra and Australia put into that effort. I should also acknowledge the very good work of our Chairman, Senator Maguire, and our Deputy Chairman, Senator Teague, both of whom, as has been indicated, contributed over and above the call of duty to this report.

PARA.TAB: As we embarked upon this inquiry, we did find initially some difficulty in getting information from within government departments and circles. We found some reluctance to respond, some lack of enthusiasm from various people in government departments who initially gave evidence and who did not seem to be willing to pursue matters further. I am pleased to learn from the Government's response that this has changed. Certainly the Government has put a deal of time into responding to the recommendations made.

As an aside, can I say that it is a ridiculous system where we were given this response half an hour ago and then are expected to debate and comment sensibly on it. I certainly have not had the advantage of going through the Government's response to any degree and of making any comments on it. I do however, by glancing through it, note and acknowledge that the Government has taken some interest in the recommendations and has seen fit to comment on all of them.

I was a little disappointed in the introduction of the Government's response. It does seem to be fairly defensive. It indicates that the Government was going along the right track as far as Latin America was concerned. It is, however, my understanding that the interest the Government took in Latin America certainly got a boost as this Committee worked through its reference and the Government did then become more and more interested. Up until that time, there was not much evidence of any real interest by the Government. Certainly, since the report has been issued, it has stirred more action from the Government and government departments. For that, I am most pleased, and that is a great recommendation of the Senate committee system.

The Government, in its introduction, made some reservations which I thought were rather disappointing. It indicates in its first reservation that there was a lot of information already around about the Government's existing activities in Latin America. As I mentioned, the Committee found some difficulty in getting together a lot of information about Latin America in its early days.

In the second of its reservations, the Government indicated that Australia's priorities are in Asia—the South East Asian and Pacific region. The Committee understood that from day one and we at no time suggested that Australia's main focus should move off the region in which we live. We did say, however, as other members of the Committee have mentioned, that the Government should be paying more attention to Latin America. We were hoping—we mentioned it in recommendation 14—that trade between Australia and Latin America would increase from one per cent to 3 per cent by the year 2000.

The third reservation from the Government seems to suggest that we should have prioritised the recommendations. As other honourable senators have mentioned, we consider all of the recommendations very important, and it was for the Government, of course, to respond to all of them—not only to some of them or in descending order of importance to it. Further in its response, the Government says that we should have made recommendations concerning private enterprise, not just government. I cannot quite follow that. Many of our recommendations—for example, our recommendation on the dairying industry, and recommendation 24 which relates to chambers of commerce and business councils—have a very significant relationship to private enterprise and do not involve just government.

I am very pleased that the Government has taken up recommendation 31 and instituted the task force. I am also pleased that, in spite of some initial reservations both from the Department and from the government business enterprise involved, Aerolineas Argentinas is now being allowed additional services between Australia and Latin America.

I am a bit disappointed with the response to recommendation 37, which was a relatively minor recommendation about having native Spanish speakers who do not have Australian teaching qualifications being employed as assistants in the teaching of the Spanish language. In recommendation 38, which concerns arranging teacher exchanges, the Government simply refers to some forum being set up under the Australian Educational Council and then comments that these matters are likely to receive attention from that forum. I had hoped that the Government would have been a bit more positive and said that those matters definitely would receive some attention and that the recommendations we made would be brought to the forum. The response just seemed a bit light.

There are obviously a lot of other matters that could be spoken about if we were not on a time limit and if we had had a little bit more of an opportunity to read these responses before we were required to debate them. But again, I thank the Government for its answers, such as they are, and recommend the report and the response to Australians generally and to people who are interested in trade. It certainly has brought Australia and Latin America closer together and augurs well for the relationships between our respective countries in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Film, Television and Radio School

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Film, Television and Radio School has had a distinguished existence in the last few years. For example, over 40 awards, including Silver Hugos at the 1991 Chicago International Film Festival, were won for two 1990 third-year student films. Twenty of the 68 internationally distributed AFTRS student productions were broadcast throughout the year, particularly in Europe. The third-year production in 1992, Road to Alice, won a special commendation at the Melbourne International Film Festival. The director of that film, Stavros Efthymiou, was named young film-maker of the year at the Edinburgh International Film Festival. So this organisation, which like all is suffering from some restraint in expenditure, is maintaining high standards while naturally having to cut its cloth to suit the changed times of the recession.

PARA.TAB: The Chairperson of the school, Ms Robin Hughes, made the point that it is vital to maintain and increase the quality of the work, despite a reduction in real funding. She also said that there needs to be a greater integration of all the many and various activities if the school is to maintain standards within its shrinking resources. She continued:

SPEECH.PARA: It is time now for a rationalisation of resources.
Certainly that is a point that the Opposition has been making in respect of this and other areas of the arts, without necessarily diminishing the quality of the work being done.

PARA.TAB: That is why I find it extraordinary that the recommendation of the coalition, in opposition, that there be greater efficiencies and some cuts in administrative spending within the arts is trumpeted by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) as being some kind of savage slash to arts funding. Yet here we have clear evidence of how a body, suffering from cuts in arts funding by this Government, is quite properly coping with that problem by rationalising its activities. In other words, it can be done and it is being done by these organisations, despite the extraordinary nonsense coming out of the Minister for the Arts every time we talk about the clear scope and need for rationalisation.
I commend the Australian Film, Television and Radio School for recognising that there is a capacity for rationalisation. It is proceeding with it. As Robin Hughes, the Chairperson, says:

SPEECH.PARA: We need to maintain a flexible stance that will allow us to continue to respond to the opportunities to develop a higher profile in the Asia Pacific region,—
that can earn revenue for Australia—

to use our excellent international reputation to enhance connections useful to the industry overseas, while at the same time never forgetting that our true and central purpose is to continue to produce for the Australian film, television and radio industry professionals of outstanding calibre.
According to Robin Hughes, the task for the coming year and future years, under what will clearly be tight financial conditions no matter who is in government, is:
to ensure that any changes that follow from this process serve only to enhance the quality of education offered to all students and users of the AFTRS.

I say amen to all that. All I hope is that the Minister for the Arts stops misrepresenting the coalition's rational arts policies, which do not cut by one cent the amount of money going to arts-based art. In other words, funding on arts criteria will be maintained in full. The only areas where there will be cuts are those which are frankly political, other arts grants which are not based on arts criteria or where there is clear scope for rationalising and tightening administrative costs, such as the Film, Television and Radio School is quite properly showing it can do and is doing.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advance to the Minister for Finance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer to a few items in this document. Firstly, the Australian National Maritime Museum is seeking additional funds of $784,000 in this Advance, which is maintaining a level of request that has been quite high in recent times for a specific set of reasons. As the request outlines, the Australian National Maritime Museum is seeking funds to cover a shortfall in revenue, accounts that were carried over into 1992-93 and additional supplementation agreed to during the 1992-93 Budget discussions, all of which were unforeseen at the time the Supply Estimates were formulated. It goes on:
As at 30 September 1992 revenue for the ANMM is down in excess of $200,000.

It obviously hopes that the main revenues for the Museum, which are due in the December-January period, will be stronger. This dramatises the fact that there is an absolutely vital need for the greater promotion of the benefits of this Museum and its attractiveness. It is an outstanding museum. I hope that there is a greater attempt to promote it in a much more commercial way than it has so far been promoted.

PARA.TAB: But this is now getting to be a pretty big bill. The Department of Finance agreed that the Maritime Museum would receive an additional $2m last year to cover a shortfall against its appropriations. But only about $1.3m was provided. So this year there has been an additional $674,000 included in the Additional Estimates to cover that.

Unfortunately, at the time the Supply Estimates were due, the Maritime Museum funding for 1992-93 had not been resolved. Subsequently, an additional $1.5m in unanticipated costs and half a million dollars in revenue shortfalls was agreed to. After taking account of the timing of the receipts and payments for the Maritime Museum, the Supply Estimates were understated by $726,000, which is currently coming up for review. I regret that the Museum is not doing as well as it deserves to. It will have to look to much more aggressive ways of raising revenue and to adopting a much more commercial approach.

The National Film and Sound Archive is also after more money. The total amount required is $690,000. However, I must commend the Film and Sound Archive for one element of this additional cost. It relates to having a computer upgrade and buying computers at an earlier date than it would normally have had to put up the money in order to get a discount of about $45,000. The Archive was advised that placement of an order for the computer upgrade before 25 September 1992 would result in a saving of $45,255 and a total price of $185,000, as against a price after 25 September of $228,755. This expenditure was unforeseen when the Supply Estimates were formulated. But I am pleased to see that a government department is prepared to make suitable arrangements to try to get that kind of discount for early purchase. It shows the flexibility that would be good for some other departments. I commend it.

The other point I want to raise very briefly relates to the Australian Customs Service, which wants $455,000. This requirement for extra funds arises from an unforeseen payment of $455,000 awarded to a New South Wales company by the courts. I would have thought it would be reasonable to tell us what that was, but we do not know. We are asked to provide the money without being told much about this. Was the Customs office wrong? We just do not know the basis on which this unforeseen payment is to be made. All we know is that the sum was not anticipated for payment during the Supply period. I think it is up to the Customs Service to let us know. It would be nice if the Minister could suggest that that be done in these applications.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Supporting Applications of Issues from the Advance to the Minister for Finance--October 1992

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a request for an act of grace payment to Queensland Alumina Ltd for $3.9m, representing interest on customs duty paid under protest by the company and subsequently refunded. I do not know the background to this but it is worth noting that the Government is recognising that it had a moral obligation to pay interest on the customs duty paid by Queensland Alumina under protest, which it subsequently refunded. PARA.TAB: I wonder what interest rate the Commonwealth paid on this debt. It is good to see that where the Government is demonstrated to have been in the wrong, it is providing interest on that debt. I would like to make the point that under our proposed GST arrangements any refunds of GST that have to be paid to people who have paid GST and which are not made within a very short period will be subject to interest rates. So if the Tax Office does not pay refunds promptly, it will have to pay interest. I am glad to see that at least other elements of the Government take that view, which is not a view currently in vogue in the Tax Office.

Another matter that I would very briefly like to raise is that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade requires $188,000 for the payment of compensation to the Government of Iran and the staff of the Iranian Embassy following the attack on the Embassy on 6 April 1992. This is to pay compensation to the Government of Iran in respect of damage to furniture, fittings and equipment and miscellaneous loss and damage to the Embassy and for the theft of $US65,000. This is what intrigued me. Has the $US65,000 been recovered? I do not remember hearing of that in the court case. I do not remember reading about it; maybe because I did not notice it. I did not note whether anyone has been prosecuted for the theft of that money. I wonder what stage the Government is at in seeking to recover that $US65,000. It may be that I have not followed it closely enough. It is one of those issues that should be taken up. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Health, Housing and Community Services

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual report of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, which is 385 pages long, has only just been tabled. It covers all the aspects of health, including health advancement, therapeutic goods administration, health care access, aged and community care, disability programs, children's services, housing and urban development, corporate services as they apply to that Department and information services and policy development in that Department. It is impossible in the five minutes that I have to consider this report to discuss all the aspects of it.

PARA.TAB: It has been the case that some departments have been able to provide us with at least a draft copy of their annual report by the time of Estimates. That was the case for one large department with which I was involved. It does not seem to have been the case with the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services this year. It has not even managed a draft annual report. The year before it did. It would have been most helpful if it could have done that. At least we now have the report before us.

Page 35 of the report mentions the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the effect that the co-payment—it was introduced for the dispensing of a prescribed drug—has had on reducing the number of drugs that have been dispensed. As I said, this report has only just been tabled but when I looked through it I could not find—I may stand to be corrected—anything about the Medicare co-payment. The Department talks about all the things it has done during the year but it did not talk about the fact that before Christmas last year we introduced in this Parliament a Medicare co-payment which was aimed at reducing overservicing in general practice.

The report does not—and I will stand corrected; I have flicked through the pages—emphasise that a number of studies commissioned by the Department were undertaken to look at what the Australian public thought about the introduction of a co-payment system for attending a general practitioner. Taxpayers' money was used on those studies which found that an overwhelming number of people believed it was appropriate that a small co-payment be made when visiting a general practitioner. People understood that there was a cost involved. They understood that they should not visit a general practitioner on just a whim; that there should be a need to do so.

Mr Keating needed a couple of votes this time last year—I can see that Senator Cook is smiling, because he knows that I am right. His arm was twisted up his back. Despite these findings and despite the acceptance by the Australian public, the concept of a co-payment was taken away. This was about buying a couple of votes in order to kick Mr Hawke out of the Lodge so that Mr Keating could move in. Those details are not reported anywhere in this annual report. However, I expected that we would have seen some reference to the concept being introduced and then the baby being thrown out with the bath water. As I said, I stand to be corrected, but at first glance it is not in the report. It is not listed in the index. If the report were really up front, I believe this would be in the index, as is the pharmaceutical benefits scheme.

This is another indication that Mr Keating was prepared to throw out something that was accepted by the Australian public—something that was going to reduce the strain on the public purse. Some of the money that was being used in over-servicing could have been redirected to some other aspect of health. But that concept was sold out because Mr Keating wanted to get one, if not two, votes for his leadership bid.

I think this says a lot about how frustrating it must be for some of the people in the Department. These people set up a scheme which had the support of the public and which was going to do something about reducing overservicing, only to have it thwarted for political reasons—the buying of a couple of votes for the leadership. That was appalling.

I think the Australian public know the sorts of things that Mr Keating is prepared to do. This annual report has reminded me of the sort of thing that happened this time—most probably the very week—last year when Mr Keating was negotiating to get rid of the co-payment concept so that he could obtain one or two more votes.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: The Corporations and Securities Panel is interesting in that it is designed basically to back up or support the Australian Securities Commission in determining improper behaviour. The panel was set up because the previous regulator of the market in respect of the control of Australian companies, the National Companies and Securities Commission, ran the risk of being perceived as prosecutor, judge, jury and executioner. The establishment of the panel is partly a move to have peer review of the difficult concepts of acceptable behaviour and market integrity.

PARA.TAB: Two problems emerge from this. One is that there are massive disagreements, apparently, within the business community about what really this panel should properly do. In fact, the panel has been able to complete only one examination—the Titan Hills determination relating to a takeover—and this was subject to much litigation.

The panel takes the view in its annual report that this examination was ultimately worth while because it established a lot of precedents under which it could operate. The interesting point is that whereas for 1991-92 $249,000 from the Securities Commission's budget was allocated to the panel, the annual report for that year shows that the panel's expenses were $231,753. So, as we can see, the panel almost expended what was allocated to it despite the fact that it really only had one investigation. As I said, obviously that one investigation was far more expensive than would normally be the case. In fact, as the report says, the operational expenses of $132,025 wholly comprised the Titan Hills determination. Hopefully, that situation will not exist when the work of the panel settles down. The other expenditure related to such things as members' annual fees.

So we have clearly a situation where it is going to be expensive to have this kind of additional panel. It is going to be interesting to see whether the panel will be able to get through in 12 months more than simply one determination. There clearly is a need in the markets for there to be some sort of peer review of the difficult concepts of acceptable behaviour and market integrity. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, I present the report of the Committee entitled The Family Law Act 1975: Aspects of its operation and interpretation, together with the transcript of evidence, submissions and minutes of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I have much pleasure in presenting this report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act. The report will probably become identified in time, as is the wont of this place, as the McKiernan report on family law. This is somewhat unfair as it is truly the work of 10 dedicated, hardworking members of parliament. It is in every sense of the word a committee report.

PARA.TAB: I would like to thank my colleagues on the Committee, particularly the Deputy Chairman, the honourable member for Kooyong, the Hon. Andrew Peacock MP. Much has been said and written, not all of it kind, about my deputy. Notwithstanding the idle chat and advice I received from colleagues on this side of the chamber about how I should work with Mr Peacock, at the presentation of this major report I have nothing but praise and gratitude to direct to him. His parliamentary experience and knowledge of the legislation was of enormous benefit to me personally and to the Committee as a whole. His loyalty and assistance during the inquiry greatly enhanced the Committee's ability to approach its difficult task.

I thank other Committee members, Senator David Brownhill, Senator Rosemary Crowley, Senator Margaret Reid and Senator Sid Spindler, and from the House of Representatives Mr Russ Gorman, Ms Carolyn Jakobsen, Mr Michael Lavarch and Mr Alisdair Webster, for their hard work and dedication to their task. Family law is an area about which people can have strong views. It is much to the credit of the Committee members that such a strong degree of unanimity was reached on the many issues under consideration.

I would also like to thank the staff of the secretariat, both present and past. The Committee experienced some difficulty in staffing for much of the first 10 months of its operation due to reasons unrelated to the Committee. Thankfully, earlier this year the Committee eventually achieved a stable secretariat. On behalf of the Committee, I would like to thank the staff, particularly the Secretary, Robina Mills, the legal adviser, David Wallace, Fiona Taylor, who found herself holding the fort alone in December and January, Donna Christophers, who developed the database for the Secretariat, and Lesley Cowan, who did a sterling job in supporting the secretariat and the Committee and who was responsible for putting the report into its final publishable shape.

Time does not allow me to further extol the quality of the secretariat. However, I make special mention of Robina, whose exceptional competence and ability I do not believe have been fully realised and utilised in this place. Further, I have ensured that David Wallace's significant qualities have been duly relayed to his superiors.

The subject matter of this inquiry made it a particularly difficult area in which to work.
