The number of submissions was extremely high by any standard, but it is not recorded in the report that staff were often fully engaged in dealing with the immediate demands placed on them with the telephone inquiries and responding to letters. I commend the way they went about their monumental and difficult workload and the quality of their work. I also record my appreciation for the support that they have given to me personally and to the rest of the Committee during the inquiry.

I must also thank my own electorate office staff who had the task of dealing with many of the complex and varied telephone calls asking about the inquiry. This was a particularly heavy task in the early stages of the inquiry and I suspect it is something that will be repeated in the coming months. Sue Reid, Stella Files, Ken Travers, Trish Cowles, Marianna Serghi and Anita Stergio have my gratitude.

The inquiry into the operation and interpretation of the Family Law Act 1975 was announced on 13 March 1991, with the establishment of the second Joint Select Committee. The inquiry was prompted by the concern expressed by some members of the Parliament, in particular by my colleague Senator Brownhill, acting on behalf of many constituents who had made representation to him.

The Committee's terms of reference required us to inquire into the court's counselling service and the role of mediation and marriage guidance, the resolution of custody, access and guardianship disputes, the enforcement of Family Court orders, the resolution of property disputes, including those between de facto couples, the exercise of discretion by the courts under the Act, the appropriateness of the current adversarial legal system for the resolution of family law disputes, the cost of legal proceedings in the family law area and whether the current restrictions on the full publication of proceedings in the Family Court should be eased. The Committee has previously reported to the Parliament on the matter of the retiring age of judges of the Family Court.

The terms of reference did not include any examination of the child support scheme or the child support legislation. However, so numerous were the complaints made to this Committee and to members in the course of their electorate office work that the Committee felt compelled to comment on issues relating to child support, both the operation of the legislation and the operation of the Child Support Agency. The Committee has not transgressed its terms of reference by making recommendations in relation to these comments, although it does urge the Government to take note of the concerns expressed in the report on the very important matter of child support and the current problems being experienced by many non-custodial parents.

Child support is an integral area of the family law system. It is a factor to be considered in deciding a property dispute. The amount of income and assets a non-custodial parent is left with after settlement can have a huge bearing on the extent and quality of any continuing relationship with the children. The Committee emphasises its support for the scheme and the principles underlying it. However, it is obvious that some fine-tuning is needed to avoid the many hardships currently being experienced by many non-custodial parents and, where remarriage has taken place, on their new spouses.

The Committee's major concern is that parents may not now be sharing equitably in the support of their children, that the custodial parent is sometimes seen to be faring very well under the new scheme at the expense of the non-custodial parent, many of whom appear to be becoming impoverished. The formula seems to be too inflexible and not capable of enabling relevant expenditure, such as existing mortgage payments, school fees and utilities payments, to be taken into consideration. The Committee also has concerns about the operation of the agency itself and points to the recent report of the Commonwealth Ombudsman, which when considering the client base of the Agency had the largest proportion of complaints and the third largest in terms of absolute numbers.

The Committee received a total of 1,031 submissions, including 89 confidential submissions. Submissions were received from a large number of individuals, people who had been both directly and indirectly involved in the proceedings of the Family Court, as well as from lawyers, academics, government departments and authorities, and community groups. The published submissions are contained in 32 volumes, amounting to some 6,000 pages.

In the course of the inquiry the Committee took public evidence in all capital cities as well as two regional centres. The Committee also visited several registries of the Family Court and the Noble Park Family Mediation Centre. Evidence was taken from 22 government organisations, 38 non-government organisations and 52 individuals in the course of 17 public hearings and five in-camera hearings. In all, the Committee met formally on 57 occasions for 192 hours, or the equivalent of five working weeks, taking evidence, undertaking inspections and discussions and formulating its report. These statistics give a real perspective on the scope of the task and the commitment this Committee gave to the completion of its task. They of course do not take account of the countless hours of informal inter-committee discussion, dialogue and representation. The Committee was obliged because of the workload involved to seek an extension of our reporting date, which had been established to be the first sitting day in August.

The Family Law Act, when it was passed in 1975, was considered to be a watershed in the reform of law relating to the dissolution of marriages, particularly the abolition of the notion of fault and the introduction of a 12 months separation ground for divorce. Now, 17 years on, areas of major concern appear to be the ancillary matters relating to children and property, as opposed to the principal relief matter of divorce. It is with those ancillary matters that the major dissatisfaction with the Act and with the Family Court appears to be focused.

The Committee found that as a general rule the Act itself was an effective vehicle for the administration of family law matters in Australia. Generally speaking, the Committee also found that the Family Court was not using the powers granted to it under the Act to the extent possible, nor was the Court making the best use of the flexibility of the Act. In particular, the Committee cites the introduction of new penalties for the enforcement of court orders which the Court has not yet begun to use to their best effect. The cross-vesting legislation, which allows the Family Court to hear a range of matters normally dealt with by other jurisdictions, similarly has not been made use of to the extent that it is possible under the Act.

The Committee notes that the Family Law Act has been amended 34 times since the Act was initially passed in 1975. The Act has now become unwieldy, and the Committee considers that it is time for the Act to be renumbered for ease of reference. The Committee has recommended that this happen as a matter of urgency.

The Committee received a number of submissions from people complaining about aspects of their experience with the Family Court where their complaints may possibly have been of sufficient seriousness to warrant some kind of independent investigation. The anomaly exists that complaints about the operation of the Family Law Court, including complaints about the Chief Justice, are in the first instance made to the Court itself. In this situation, it is difficult for the Court to be an independent arbitrator.

The Committee notes that the administration of the Family Court does not come within the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. The Committee feels that scrutiny by the Commonwealth Ombudsman is an effective feedback mechanism for government departments, as well the Parliament. The Committee in urging the Commonwealth Government and the Family Court to introduce a complaints handling mechanism for the Family Court suggests that the Ombudsman's Office may be the most appropriate agency to handle such complaints. If this is not the case, then some kind of alternative complaints handling mechanism should be introduced.

In relation to counselling, mediation and marriage guidance, the Family Law Act 1975 gives legislative recognition to the pivotal role that the provision of free, in-house counselling might play in assisting separating couples to reach their own decisions, without recourse to expensive litigation. The overriding emphasis in the new Act was to be on the reduction of bitterness associated with marital breakdown. Submissions to the Committee were mixed in their assessment of the value and effectiveness of the counselling service as it currently operates, although the vast majority of submissions were supportive of counselling per se.

The counselling service has a difficult task, which is compounded by the fact that not enough people are aware of the service prior to their approach to the Family Court to initiate proceedings for divorce. At this point many people may have already made the decision to divorce and the counselling service's role will be limited to minimising the bitterness too often associated with divorce and assisting the partners to come to an agreed position regarding their separation.

The Committee is concerned that the counselling service has not been able to operate as effectively as it might, nor has it been able to offer the range of services possible under the Family Law Act. Research has shown that early intervention counselling is the most successful and to that end it must be possible for people to access counselling services within and outside the court at the earliest opportunity.

Whilst counselling can assist in dealing with the effects of separation and divorce, and to some extent minimising the amount of litigation, the avoidance of litigation altogether is desirable. To this end, the Committee considered the role of mediation as a method of alternative dispute resolution within the area of family law. The Family Court has conducted a pilot mediation study and early results are encouraging. Such alternative dispute resolution methods must be encouraged and supported by government.

The role of marriage guidance was another related issue. The Committee encourages the greater availability of marriage guidance and, prior to that, to see relationship education and `life skills' become part of the school curriculum, particularly in high schools.

On the question of children, by far the most important issues considered by the Committee related to the resolution of disputes in which children were involved. Disputes were usually about who had custody of the children and what access arrangements were going to be put in place for the non-custodial parent. It was put to the Committee that more joint custody or shared parenting arrangements should be adopted. However, the Committee, while it is supportive of arrangements which facilitate the involvement of both parents in the upbringing of their children, was not able to recommend that joint custody be ordered more frequently than it is at present.

Children need to have security and stability, particularly in the period following parental separation and divorce. Joint custody, where parents have daily care and control of the children for substantially equal periods of time, may not be conducive to perceptions of security and stability. There is nothing in the legislation at present to prevent shared parenting if parents want to enter into such an arrangement. Joint custody requires cooperation and communication between the parents and probably a reasonably close physical location of the two residences.

Even if a shared parenting arrangement is undertaken, it is likely there will be one primary residence for the child or children. However, this is not to say that parents cannot have a significant involvement with and contribution to the upbringing of their children. This must be encouraged, but quite often it will only be achieved if both parents are able to come to terms with their divorced and separated situation and they must be able to communicate with one another regarding their children. I draw the attention of the Senate particularly to comments contained at paragraphs 5.31 and 5.32 of this report.

One deficiency in the Family Law Act is that nowhere does it spell out the different rights and responsibilities relating to both guardianship and custody. This deficiency has been the cause of some confusion and the Committee has recommended that the rights and responsibilities of guardianship vis-a-vis custody be spelt out in the Act.

An issue raised by many people during the inquiry involved the situation where one parent, usually the custodial parent, moved away from the area, either interstate or intrastate. Many non-custodial parents argued that access to their children following their removal was hindered or prevented altogether. The Committee appreciates the financial and other difficulties which may be involved in the exercise of access rights when the parents live a long distance away from one another.

The Committee takes the view that, in general, it is fair to expect that the custodial parent who moves a long distance away from the non-custodial parent should be required to contribute to the costs and travelling involved in access. However, the Committee notes that there may be cases in which it may be inappropriate to require the custodial parent to expend an equal share of the costs and time involved.

A disturbing matter for the Committee was where there were allegations of child abuse, particularly sexual abuse. Submissions made to the Committee provide evidence of widespread concern about the capacity of the Family Court to deal with custody and access cases when allegations of child sexual abuse are current. If the allegation is malicious, the accused party will be prevented wrongfully from having contact with the children. If the allegation is factual and the result of a real concern on the part of the other parent, then the children must be protected.

A major concern is that cases often hinge on conflicting evidence and the veracity of either party's evidence is difficult to substantiate in the absence of a criminal conviction. The manner in which allegations are investigated by State government departments, and the manner in which children are questioned, may affect the reliability of the evidence that is obtained and evidence can be frequently called into question. As it is often nearly impossible to assess the facts with absolute certainty, judges often feel that they have no option but to make a tentative finding, precluding or limiting access to children.

The Committee is aware that allegations of child sexual abuse and any resulting cancellation or limitations of access may have disastrous consequences for totally innocent parties. At the same time, poor handling of investigations can exacerbate the difficulties intrinsic in this type of case, with the result that the level of danger to the child is not fully appreciated by the court, and the child is returned to an abusive situation.

Another significant issue is whether children should be represented separately in proceedings in the Family Court and whether that separate representation should be ordered in all contested custody cases. The Committee concluded that children should always be separately represented in cases where there were allegations of child sexual abuse and in other cases at the discretion of the court. The Court has developed protocols with the States to better manage cases where there are allegations of child sexual abuse.

On the matter of domestic violence, a number of submissions to the inquiry have suggested that there is a need for changes to the manner in which some judges of the court, and magistrates with family law jurisdiction, approach the resolution of disputes over children in cases where domestic violence is involved. Some submissions have argued that the courts have not, in the past, paid enough attention to the effects of violence on children, and have therefore granted access in some cases where it is not appropriate. Others have suggested that, in some cases, the terms of access orders made by the Family Court have conflicted with the terms of protection orders issued by magistrates' courts to protect one party, usually the custodial mother, from further violence.

The Committee has noted that improved coordination between the Family Court and magistrates' courts may help to alleviate existing problems. The Committee also suggests that where police protection is necessary or where a custodial parent fears violence taking place when access occurs then it may well be inappropriate for an access order to exist at all.

The enforcement of Family Court orders, particularly access orders, is the focus of a great deal of anguish, concern and anger to many people. The Committee received several hundred submissions and hundreds of letters not only from parties to divorce but also from their friends, relatives and children, all complaining about the lack of action taken by the Family Court to penalise custodial parents who breach access orders or agreements. Many submissions expressed outrage at the fact that, while default on a maintenance order is immediately penalised and enforcement action taken, enforcement of access orders is almost non-existent.

The Committee heard from many parents, mainly fathers, who claimed that they were being unreasonably denied legitimate access to their children. The Committee also heard from custodial mothers who claimed that they had breached access orders because they feared a violent former partner, and could no longer tolerate persistent harassment from their ex-partner.

The Committee is concerned that many people have highlighted the Family Court's inability or lack of will to enforce access orders. The flouting of court ordered access is not only a breach of the law; it can also irrevocably damage the relationship between parent and child. The Family Court must recognise that the new penalties provided in the legislation could be appropriately and effectively used so that children are not denied contact with their non-custodial parent through selfish or vindictive acts on the part of the custodial parent. If access is refused or frustrated, the Committee considers that reversing the onus of proof is a just and proper course of action. It is then up to the custodial parents to justify the refusal and explain why they breached the law. This penal action would assist non-custodial parents to preserve contact with their children.

I turn now to property disputes. The Committee considered the mechanism by which the Family Court currently determines the settlement of property disputes and has made recommendations which seek to make such settlements fairer. In particular, the Committee has recommended that there be equity of sharing—that is, a 50 : 50 starting point in the division of marital property and any variation from this starting point to be dependent on specific circumstances. The Committee also considered in detail the issue of pre-nuptial contracts or financial agreements. We concluded that where two people wished to make such an agreement, the court must take that agreement into consideration in the division of property, provided that the agreement was not made under duress and was not in any way challengeable.

The subject of family farms was considered by the Committee. The Committee had a significant number of representations made to it by people who had lost all or part of their farm following a property settlement. In some cases, people affected were not even parties to the divorce. The forced selling of a farm not only requires the seller to accept the market price at the time, but also often takes away the livelihood of the operator of the farm.

The Committee has recommended that in such situations special consideration be given to farming properties, whether the property was acquired after marriage or whether it had been brought into the marriage by one party, and the necessity to retain the property as an income producing entity. The Committee notes that pre-nuptial contracts may be one way of ensuring the continuation of the farm within the family. The Committee recognises that there are other family businesses to which the above principle may apply, but we received insufficient evidence to formulate specific proposals in relation to other situations.

The inclusion of superannuation as a matter to be taken into consideration in the determination of a property settlement has been a vexing question in family law for some time. Superannuation has been dealt with inconsistently over the years. The Committee recognises that the inclusion of superannuation as part of the pool of property for division has some difficulties, given that it is a benefit which will be realised at a date in the future, and that the determination of the value of superannuation to each party is a matter of some complexity. Nevertheless, the Committee has recommended that superannuation entitlements be included as property.

The final issue in relation to property settlements is that of the position of de facto couples and the absence of jurisdiction in the Family Court to decide property disputes between such couples. The present situation is one of confusion and varies depending on the State in which a couple resides. Some States have legislation and some do not. Quite often it is the woman who is disadvantaged in a de facto situation where the partners separate. The Committee has recommended that the Commonwealth Government seek a reference of powers from the States in relation to the jurisdiction of de facto property disputes and then legislate so that such disputes be heard in the Family Court. We have specifically recommended that the Family Law Act not be amended in respect of de facto property disputes where children are not involved.

With relation to the adversarial nature of proceedings, many submissions to the Committee commented on the nature of proceedings in the Family Court and whether such an arena was the appropriate forum in which to hear disputes about relationships. The Committee comments on the formalised nature of the proceedings in the Family Court and notes that the increased and increasing formality is at odds with the spirit and intention of the legislators when the Act was passed in 1975.

The Committee is aware that an appearance or attendance at court can be an intimidating experience for many people, and that the court may not be the most appropriate forum for many of those to resolve what are, for the most part, emotional and personal problems. It is evident that there is added emotion in family law disputes, particularly where those disputes involve children. This being the case, it was necessary to consider whether alternative mechanisms or procedures are better suited than a strictly adversarial legal process to the resolution of family law disputes. The Committee concluded that, even though there have been criticisms of the adversarial system and that it may not be the ideal method for resolving family law disputes, the adversary system should be retained but with appropriate modifications for alternate dispute resolution and simplified procedure.

I will deal now with the costs of proceedings. The Committee is concerned about the effect that increasing costs are having upon access to justice in family law matters. A matter of fundamental principle is the accessibility and availability of professional services at an affordable cost for people approaching family breakdown or following any separation of parties. The Committee is concerned that there should be a balance between the cost of services of the legal profession and the availability of those services to the community. The Committee notes that 521 submissions made a reference to the high cost of being involved in family law disputes.

The Committee hopes that recommendations made by it and moves already afoot in the Family Court will simplify procedures and thereby reduce costs anyway. The Committee has recommended the development of a new costing system and the greater use of costs orders, particularly where it is apparent that one party has unnecessarily prolonged proceedings. Complaints about limited access to the court because of high legal costs and the problems encountered by self-represented litigants were made to the Committee. The court must strive to make itself more user-friendly and enable those parties who wish to represent themselves to do so adequately.

The current restraint on publication whereby, although proceedings may be reported, parties to proceedings may not be identified without the permission of the Family Court, has been criticised, especially by the media. However, the Committee has concluded that no significant evidence was placed before it to justify the relaxation of the policy behind section 121 of the Act. The Committee is concerned that the individual's right to privacy be respected.

In conclusion: the Committee's work continues as it fulfils its obligations to the Parliament to carry out an administrative review of the Family Court—recommendations Nos 2 and 3 of our report. Public hearings have already been conducted on this reference on Friday, 13 November and Thursday, 19 November 1992. The Committee anticipates reporting to Parliament on this matter in February next year.

Finally, I wish to thank another very important group of people. Throughout the inquiry, I more and more came to appreciate how fortunate I personally have been in my own marital and family relationships. I acknowledge the enormous efforts that Jean McKiernan and Jackie Watkins have put into our relationships, efforts that have been rewarded by an extended and loving family which now includes Lisa and Ron Moulday, Steven and Sandie McKiernan, Donna McKiernan, Jimmy McKiernan, Kim Watkins, Kate Watkins, Ben Watkins as well as Jean

SPEECH.PARA: and Jackie. I commend the report to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments on this report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operations and Interpretation of the Family Law Act. This is an important document presented to the Senate this afternoon. Of course, it is with some sadness that we bring the report to the Senate at a time when many families in our community are under much greater pressure than the normal pressure of keeping a family together, when we have well over one million people out of work—one million families affected by the consequence of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: In fact, it is worse than that, when one understands the number of families affected by perhaps one parent being out of work when both have worked previously, and the one out of work in that circumstance not being counted; and when one thinks of the number of people who are in part time employment who would, in fact, prefer full time work. We are talking about families at a time when there is particular pressure. We are talking about families at a time when there are 680,000 children living in families without a breadwinner. Hopefully, these are circumstances that will change before too long and that additional pressure will be removed from them.

It is inevitable that the stress of these facts will be very significant indeed. Some families may even be drawn together by the circumstances, but far more may well find that it is the thing that causes the fracture to come in the end and that the family will not survive, with the inevitable consequences, both for the children of the marriage and for the parties themselves whose hopes have been dashed. The one thing that the Committee had in mind throughout this inquiry was that the institution of marriage is something that is very important in our society. Honourable senators may think that is not apparent from the report because it dealt with the consequences of breakdown of marriage. But I believe that throughout the inquiry the institution of marriage was foremost in our minds as we dealt with the issues before the Committee.

We gave great consideration to the things which perhaps make it easier in the end to keep a marriage together: learning to understand each other; teaching life skills at an early age. I think we would be particularly conscious of those young people who have grown up in a situation where a functioning marriage has not existed. They will inevitably find it more difficult to enter a marriage and make it work because they have not had the example of a good, functioning family. It is particularly important that, somewhere in society, we enable people to learn the skills that are necessary to keep personal relationships in a wholesome way.

We need to concentrate more on prevention of breakdown of relationships, even though we recognise that, when a relationship has broken down, it is important to have in place mechanisms to enable people to restructure their lives as quickly as possible with as little bitterness as possible. It is inevitable that when a marriage breaks down there is great hurt—always for at least one party but, in my experience, frequently for both parties. That hurt does not go away easily or quickly. Those are the issues that brought this inquiry about. This must be a day of particular satisfaction for Senator Brownhill who worked so hard for so long to have this inquiry set up.

All of us, as senators—and, I suspect, members of the other place—have had representations over the years from constituents who have been hurt by their experience as a consequence of the breakdown of their marriage. They come to us and seek assistance. I think every senator and member would know of the issues that came before the Committee. We considered 1,031 submissions, 89 of which were confidential. Many of them were in the form of letters, and were no less valid submissions for being so. In many cases, the hand-written letters were far more impressive because carried within them were the real feelings of the person who wanted to be heard. In many of the submissions that is what people were seeking; they wanted to be heard. They felt that they had not been heard previously.

We are dealing with an Act of Parliament which affects more people in our country than any Act other than the income tax Act, so its significance is great. Approximately one in three marriages is ending in divorce. The solutions to dealing with those problems need to be looked at. The Act that we were reviewing came into existence in 1975. Although under the previous Act there was a ground for divorce which enabled people to dissolve their marriage without establishing fault after living apart for five years, with the new Act fault was eliminated from the legislation—but not from the minds of men and women who had embarked upon marriage in the first place. Although we can legislate to say that fault is no longer relevant, it is not as simple as that when we come to dealing with the people who are concerned with it. As a consequence, some of the other issues—such as custody, property, access and payment of maintenance—have become more significant than they were under the old Act when the grounds for divorce were frequently the centrepiece. That is what we are still dealing with 17 years after the event.

Some people have suggested that we should return to the old Act. I do not think that would really change or improve anything. We have to deal with the consequence of the breakdown of marriage. In doing so, we have to recognise that solutions are not easily found. We were given evidence that about 95 per cent of marriages which break down are settled between the parties, and the very best settlement is the one that the parties reach themselves. About 5 per cent go to litigation—a quite small percentage one might say, but significant nonetheless. We have to be careful that, in dealing with those who are unhappy with the consequence of all this, we do not set up arrangements which make life more difficult for the 95 per cent who in fact work out the solutions for themselves.

However, we appreciate that, amongst the 95 per cent, there are some who reach settlement but who are not happy with the consequences of it. It gets back to dealing with the hurt that comes from the breakdown of the marriage and enabling there to be sufficient counselling for people to be able to work it through and get on with their lives. That is the crucial thing. What really are the priorities of what we are talking about? I think that we are talking about the children of the marriage, first and foremost. I am not forgetting the adults, but I think it is the children who are least able to deal with the situation. I always feel a tinge of sadness when I hear a parent say, `The kids are fine. They understand. They know. They are all right'. I wonder whether in fact that is the reality or whether it just appears that way, because the impact on children is enormous.

We discussed this from a number of points of view. We spoke about the adequacy of counselling—not just for the future of the children but right from the beginning. If only we could get people to recognise the symptoms of trouble in the marriage early enough to obtain marriage counselling, from the Family Court, a marriage counselling service—anywhere. They would recognise the symptoms early if it were a tooth. Why not when it comes to the most precious relationship? We need education—and we referred to this—to encourage people to accept the necessity of obtaining advice, help and assistance at an early stage.

It is my view that there is no-one on earth to whom one should be more polite and more considerate than one's spouse—the most precious person in one's relationships. But somehow we tend to forget this from time to time. Counselling is necessary from an early stage, and also when it is recognised that the marriage has failed, in order to try to get rid of the bitterness, to try to get the parties to understand what has occurred—why one party has left or why it has happened as it has. It is absolutely vital to do as much as possible to avoid a defended divorce.

I am reminded of the woman who came from Albury to give evidence. She told us the story of the breakdown of her marriage, including the court proceedings and everything that went on. I said to her at one stage, `Would it not be the fact that you were married to somebody who wanted his day in court, no matter what?'. Some people are confronted with that situation: the other party will pursue the matter, is not amenable to counselling, is not amenable to mediation; the matter must go to court because that is the only way it can finally be resolved.

We talked about the need for people to be able to have separate interviews at counselling—especially where domestic violence has been involved—and the special sensitivity that is required in that situation. We talked about the need for an interpreter service so that one can be quite sure that those whose English is not up to it are able to get advice and assistance in a way that is meaningful to them.

We went to a mediation centre and looked very closely at mediation. It has been introduced; I believe that it is working well. I believe that it has a great deal to offer—not for everybody, but if it helps some it is an achievement. We suggest that in this particular skill there should be a diploma set up in each State so that people can study and become expert in this area. At the present time I do not believe that there are sufficient people skilled in mediation for it to become as widespread in the community as we would want it to be. Some people will not go to mediation; some people will go but will not participate. We know that, but we do believe that it is highly probable, especially where we have two people who deep down want the matter resolved, that they will be able to talk through their problems and come to a solution with mediation. But it gets back to counselling, mediation, marriage guidance and being prepared to deal with the problems in one's relationship in a meaningful way.

Access to children, of course, became one of the big and central issues. I particularly recall the grandparents that we saw. I hope that we can find solutions that will enable grandparents to be accepted as having a really meaningful role to play in the lives of their grandchildren. We heard some stories which were really quite pathetic and ought not to occur. But it is something that flows from the consequence of people being so deeply hurt that they want to get back at somebody in some way. They might not really mean it, but that is what they want to achieve at that time. As a consequence, I think the hurt to the grandchildren is great.

Senator McKiernan referred to the separate representation of children, especially when there has been abuse. It is not my view that all children should be represented in divorce proceedings. I think it is wrong to conclude that the parents do not have the best interests of their children at heart. Of course there is a case for separate representation, but we should not intrude that first; we should let the parents work out a solution. Frequently, there can be significant problems between the parents as adults, but in many cases they are able to come to reasonable decisions as far as their children are concerned.

We heard, frequently, about the costs of divorce—and I do not really need to go into that here. I think everybody would be aware of the fact that it is a pretty costly procedure to get involved in. Some cannot afford to get involved in it. There is legal aid available but on a fairly limited basis. I do not know that granting more legal aid is the answer to the problem, but we did make some comments about the influence that aid might have—the influence that flows from one person having assets as a result of which one might be totally bankrupted in the end by proceedings being drawn out and going on for a very long time.

We looked at some of the procedures of the Court and came to the view that simplification is required and is necessary. I believe that the Court is aware of that as well. It is in the process, together with solicitors involved in the area, of working towards simplifying procedures. The Court, we believe, should have regard to the impact of costs on proceedings. It should be sensitive to the costs which flow from regulations and procedures that are put in place. So when we are planning on a new procedure, we should think first, `What will the impact of this be on the cost of a divorce?'. It should not be looked at just solely from the perspective of convenience or the administration of the Court; it should also be looked at from the point of view of the litigants and what effect it will have on them.

Of course, we heard a great deal about domestic violence—far too much. Domestic violence is not new. It has been around for a very long time. Many honourable senators will remember the ground of `cruelty' that existed under the Act which this Act replaced. Nothing much has changed in that area, but I hope that we are more aware of it now as a community and regard it as totally unacceptable.

There definitely was a feeling conveyed to us that judges do not really understand domestic violence. I am not able to say whether that is a fair conclusion or not. I can only say to you, Mr Deputy President, that witnesses conveyed to us on occasions that they felt that judges did not understand domestic violence. It is an area where counsellors and judges need to be sensitive to what is happening in the community. I have used the word `sensitive' a number of times as I have spoken this afternoon because I believe that that is perhaps one of the words that is relevant to this whole area of human beings—being sensitive to each other.

But what came out of the submissions and the many letters that I referred to, handwritten letters, was the enormous sense of frustration that people suffered as a consequence of their encounter with the Family Law Act—the system, the Court, the judge, the counsellor, the lawyer, somebody. We were not a court of appeal and in no case did we ever set ourselves up to be one. We took all of these submissions as they came to us on the basis that we accept that `You have had an unhappy experience; we want to try to find, as a consequence, the solutions to those problems'. Of course, from time to time there are faults with all of those things: the system, the Court, the judge, the counsellor, the lawyer—we recognise that.

Many conflicting messages came through from all of this: the woman who feels aggrieved because she has been abandoned with the children and is not being paid maintenance, not getting a fair settlement and not being able to get on with her life; the man who feels he has done nothing wrong but has lost everything—his house and his children—and is paying maintenance. It is not simple to bring all these things together and find one solution. The situation is one where that is just not possible.

But we have to try to work through this situation and see that overall the Family Law Act is doing what people expect of it—it is enabling them to get before the Court, if that has to happen; enabling them to see counsellors when that is necessary; enabling them to get appointments without having to wait too long; and enabling them to get appointments with a counsellor without having to travel too far.

The area of access, though, is where many of the frustrations come after the marriage has been dissolved. There needs to be some fairness in relation to the costs of access where parents are living away from each other. There was talk about where children should be handed over if one of the spouses rightly fears violence. We rejected the idea of children being handed over at police stations, unless very special arrangements have been made. I think I would personally totally reject handing children over at a police station.

We looked at the situation which develops quite frequently of allegations of repetitive court actions or repetitive counselling appointments made in relation to access over little things; and of people who make appointments and do not keep them or people who are advised of appointments and do not keep them. There are so many ways of aggravating the other person. We have to deal with that of course, but what really needs to be dealt with is the underlying problem that makes a person want to continue to hurt the other party. We heard about false accusations in relation to a man having access to his children. I would deal with that most severely if it were ever found to be true. But, then again, sometimes it happens, so we cannot ignore the consequences of that either. We have recommended that the Attorney-General ask the Family Law Council to inquire into the incidence of allegations of false accusations and make a report on it.

We have asked that the police have more access to the information about court orders so that enforcement can be more meaningful if a domestic violence order is breached. At the present time, we all know stories and have all had constituents come to us complaining about not being able effectively to enforce an order. We have dealt specifically with the ways in which we think that that should be dealt with in the future.

The Committee discussed the question of the terminology used in relation to custody of children—custody, guardianship, joint parenting, and all of these things. My personal view is that we perhaps should abandon the use of the word `custody'. We should make custody the fact of parenting: once a child is born, those two parents are the custodial parents of it, and that that cannot be changed.

The reason why I think that should be explored is that the word `custody' has some meaning within it—that is, being in custody at a police station and so on. It has within it a meaning that implies ownership and control in a way that I do not think is really meant in this Act. We have not recommended any changes at this stage, but I think we should look at it with a view to making orders for the future arrangements for children more understandable and meaningful to the two parties involved. This will cover where the children will live and what involvement is meant by guardianship. People had so many different views of what they thought the orders meant. There is confusion in the minds of many people about that.

We have dealt with property and recommended more precisely defining the matters to be considered. We rejected any suggestion of a set formula. It was put to us that there should be a formula that is followed which makes property precise. I reject that as a proposition, because in the end that would cause more inequities and problems than the ones we are trying to solve. I understand why it seems a simple solution, but I reject it. However, we have suggested that more things should be taken into account when determining property so that there is less uncertainty than there seems to be at present.

We suggest that financial agreements between parties should be both recognised and enforceable, and we particularly deal with the special case of farming properties. Superannuation is a matter of great importance in this community and we recommend that the court have power to divide superannuation and that it be regarded as property. We recommend that the court have power, under an amendment to the Act, to direct the trustees as to what should happen. It is my view that every woman should have a superannuation scheme whether she is in employment or not. When superannuation is to be divided, it may not be fair or reasonable to set off superannuation that is due in 20-odd years against the house now. Perhaps that super should be divided between the two of them and put into a scheme for each which will mature and into which someone will continue to pay. We have dealt with that and made recommendations.

It was the Child Support Agency which raised its head constantly throughout our inquiry and in the submissions. I have spoken in this place frequently about the Child Support Agency. There are problems with the formula and with the way it is administered. That has been set out by the Ombudsman recently and I shall not go through those details now. But it is vital that the Child Support Act be reviewed.

We are creating a situation where men are abandoning their employment to avoid being absolutely bankrupted by the application of the Act. There are women who are having great difficulty surviving because their money is not being paid to them promptly, and they then suffer the consequence of the former husband giving up his employment altogether.

There are examples of men being absolutely unable to get on with their lives and re-establish a household because of what they have to pay under this formula. Sometimes a woman is in employment and perhaps living with a person who is earning a good income. All honourable senators present know the stories I am talking about because they have heard them in their electorate offices. We were not looking into the Child Support Agency, but we have commented on it in chapter 16; one could not complete this report without doing so. I hope our remarks will be read and taken into account.

We were asked to comment on whether the rules governing publication should be changed. At present any proceedings can be published and reported upon without identifying the parties. If the media is serious about educating and informing by the reporting of proceedings, they can do so now. The only reason why names need to be added is if the media want to sensationalise the issue. I totally reject the need for the names to be a reason for reporting Family Court proceedings. There are cases when a judge may order the names to be announced when they involve snatched children and things of that nature. That of course happens, but otherwise I see no reason to change it. We suggest and recommend that the Act be renumbered. It is very complex to use as it is, and I hope that will be done very soon indeed.

We recognise that many of the recommendations are quite costly. We suggested—and in fact this is now under way—that there be a review of the funding. Is the Family Court funded adequately to carry out the functions which this Parliament has said it must carry out? If we have passed legislation which says the court should do this, that or something else, we should ask whether we are funding it adequately. It is not just a luxury. On the other hand, it is very expensive and, in the end, perhaps we are asking taxpayers, who are busy making their marriages work, to dig deeper and deeper to fund the court. It is not easy.

We felt that we could not conclude this report without a review of the costs of the court and how it is spending the $110m that it is already getting. Is this sum adequate, and are there ways of making changes which will enable it to function easier and with less cost to taxpayers? Would it be cheaper in a sense to have more money spent on it so that it can be more effective than it is at present?

In nearly half an hour that is a very brief resume of this report and the inquiry which we have undertaken. I have not touched on a number of matters which I would like to have dealt with this afternoon. I hope people will read the report and that the Government will look at it very closely indeed.

It is a report which we have all agreed upon and that is of some significance. One might say that it is always tempting to put in a minority report and get the additional publicity that flows from that process. But all members of the Committee were very aware indeed of how important our inquiry is to so many people in this community. Some may not feel happy with what we have concluded, but I hope they will see a number of things in it that are worthwhile. We certainly have not adopted every proposition that was put to us, but we looked very closely at them.

Finally, but by no means least, I am grateful for the opportunity of working with Robina Mills, David Wallace, Fiona Taylor and Lesley Cowan who worked with the Committee during the last part of it. Early on we worked with a number of people, and I am thinking particularly of Jon Stanhope, who left to be Deputy Administrator on Norfolk Island. All those people were dedicated to the task, but in particular the four people I have mentioned have been invaluable. I have enjoyed working with them and have benefited greatly from the opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of pride that I am able to speak on the tabling of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act. It is the report of an inquiry which I was told repeatedly could not and should not be done and would not be possible. I thank those who supported my quest for an inquiry, encouraged me along the way and urged me to continue to battle for them and on their behalf.

PARA.TAB: However, to the extent that this inquiry was viewed by some with unrealistic optimism, we have not solved the dilemma facing 40,000 Australian families every year or answered the question, `Why do marriages fail?', and we have not provided a formula to prevent couples from seeking a divorce. The biblical intonation `What God has joined, let no man rend asunder' is no more or less achievable today than it ever was.

We have to recognise that the increase in the divorce rate is as much a reflection of people's changing attitudes and expectations of what is possible in life and the ability to work hard at a marriage as anything inherently wrong in the system or society. If we start from that basis, then objective examination of the Family Law Act is possible, as it was in the case of this Committee.

In speaking to the report, it is impossible to deal in any depth with all 16 chapters, so I will contain my remarks to those areas which prompted me to seek the inquiry in the first instance. Accordingly, my concerns will largely centre on chapters 5, 6, 7 and 11. My initial concern was with the apparent inequity and inconsistency in matters of custody, access, maintenance and property settlement. I believe those aspects of the Act have been all well examined in this report and the recommendations outlined will make a meaningful contribution to the family law debate in this country.

The question of child support and the Child Support Agency was not a term of reference for this inquiry, although I wanted it included. To most people grappling with divorce, it is all part of the one problem. However, in the strictest legislative terms, child support does not come under the auspices of the Family Law Act. Therefore, we refrained from making any recommendations on this issue. Senator McKiernan has already outlined how frequently this vexed question was raised. I urge the Government to seriously examine its operation.

Senator McKiernan has also covered the important role that counselling services play. I support the recommendations of strengthening that service. However, I am of the view that, unless separating couples are convinced of the benefits of counselling, the influence counselling has on future relationships between the divorced parents is limited. For that reason, I believe it is important that more appropriate guidelines be put in place so that the judges and solicitors have firmer guidelines to determine the merit of the opposing arguments, irrespective of the quality or quantity of counselling available. It is imperative that consistent guidelines be laid down for assessing custody and access arrangements and determining an equitable split of marital property.

In so far as the report talks about custody, many submissions suggested that the Family Court was not the appropriate place to determine custody problems. I would disagree with that assertion, but accept that decisions about custody need to be made by those in full possession of all relevant issues. There are too many submissions to quote in any detail, but it appeared to me that too often custody orders were made without the judge satisfying himself fully of all the facts that needed to be taken into consideration. We heard too many stories of unsuitable parents being granted custody to suggest that it is an aberration. A more informed judge could avoid many of these inappropriate decisions.

Similarly, too many divorcing parents have no real understanding of their rights and obligations. A submission quoted in the report is typical of those we received. The second paragraph on page 99 states:

SPEECH.PARA: My ex wife has sole custody of our children because I was not advised by my solicitor what the difference was regarding sole and joint custody [guardianship]. The solicitors fixed this up amongst themselves. I feel now that my rights as a parent have been stripped from me . . .

The recommendations we make on these will help reduce that lack of informed judgment. Access, or lack of it, is probably the single most contentious aspect of divorce. It is the subject of most of the submissions the Committee received and certainly it forms the overwhelming bulk of family law related letters my office receives. The law sets out quite clearly that access should be available to the non-custodial parent and, in theory, no-one would dispute that. In practice, it is not always that easy, as the Committee learnt. What happens if one parent moves thousands of kilometres from the other? What happens if access is only offered at a time when the non-custodial parent cannot have the child? What assurances can be provided that the child will be safe? How does one handle the resentment and jealousy that might arise between the two parents?

PARA.TAB: It is all very well to say that people must be objective and adult, but when it comes to wanting the best for your child it seems that rationality is often lacking. The court has battled with the problem for years with mixed success. The notion of joint custody is fine, provided both parents are sufficiently objective to allow it to work. Not everyone can be or wants to be objective and cooperative for a whole variety of reasons. The Committee recognised the difficulties that joint custody brought with it and, indeed, the Family Court itself advised us of research that suggests that joint custody should be provided only in cases where both parents were capable of assuming parental responsibilities, where there was a demonstrated willingness to cooperate, where it was geographically possible, and where there was an absence of parental conflict. It acknowledged that joint custody did not work when parents could not cooperate or communicate with each other or where they were actively litigating for sole custody of their children.

The report has also taken on board the practicalities of access. It recognises that there is often a cost involved in getting a child from one parent to the other. As the law presently stands, it is assumed, but not specified, that the non-custodial parent pays for the access visit, and if he or she cannot then either a mutual agreement is worked out or the child misses out. I think the most appropriate recommendation is recommendation 43 which directs the Family Court to give recognition to fairness and the capacity of the custodial parent to share the costs and the travelling time involved in the exercise of access and, where appropriate, make each parent contribute to the costs. The cost of access is often a prohibiter and has been used by both custodial and non-custodial parent alike as a barrier to access. If the court can provide some direction on this, it will remove some of the acrimony in some access disputes.

A recurring objection was that of the continual obstruction of the custodial parent in denying access and the inability of the court to bring the defaulting party to order. Again, the report suggests that the Family Law Council extend its present inquiry to examine the extent to which the access orders are breached, what and how penalties are presently imposed, and how effective they are in correcting the problem. Many submissions talked of continually denied access despite court orders. Providing specific access arrangements add to the frustration in making the custodial parent cooperate.

While penalties are written into the Act, it seemed to the Committee that they were rarely applied. We are suggesting that the Chief Justice of the Family Court instruct his judges to apply them. I hold the view that if there is a possibility that the penalties will be applied many defaulting parents would become more cooperative. Most of the time, access is denied because of sheer spite and resentment. I think that the fact the Act has operated since 1975 is evidence that the counselling and advising about right and proper behaviour has not been sufficient incentive in some cases for parents to adhere to the spirit of the law and it is past time to start applying the penalty clauses a little more rigidly. I think, if that were tried, we well may find less violence will result. Often, the tragic cases we hear about are a result of frustration and resentment over denial of access to children. The law is only as strong as its application and there is evidence that it could be more uniformly applied.

Another pivotal aspect of the divorce process is how best to split the assets of marriage. No matter how fair one might like to be, the fact remains that one $500,000 house is obviously more luxurious than a $250,000 one. The reality of divorce is for many a reduction in living standards. That cannot be avoided. Equity is more difficult to achieve. To what extent should the custodial parent receive more than the non-custodial parent? Much resentment surrounds this issue.

Property involves not just that accumulated during the marriage but that accumulated by both parties prior to the marriage. While under the Australian marriage law each spouse retains what property they might have owned prior to their marriage, in practice that does not always follow. The courts have a capacity under section 79 of the Act to alter the property interests of the parties to a marriage. To what extent property ought to be divided is no simple formula. What is meant by equality or sharing? Who determines it and how is it determined? Section 79 of the present Act sets out a number of issues that need to be taken into consideration, but their interpretation has been the cause of considerable litigation.

In all this comes the vexed questions of maintenance, child support, the financial capacity of both parties and the contributions of both parties. Many submissions related to difficulties arising between working and non-working parties. Because the Act does not clearly direct what weight a judge ought to place on each of these various considerations, there have been varying interpretations and determinations made over the years with discrepancies becoming more evident and some people believing they have not received a fair go from the court. This seems particularly the case with custodial versus non-custodial parents and evidence has shown some discrimination against the non-custodial party.

Additionally, because this has been a grey area, too many times it seems that the cost of litigation to determine a fairer property settlement has resulted in more money being given to the solicitors than the value of the property in dispute. That can happen if one party vexatiously decides to keep taking the other party to court. The Committee acknowledges that section 75 and section 79 of the Act do not give sufficient direction to judges. It has suggested that the Act be amended to instruct judges to combine relevant matters when determining property settlements.

There is an argument to suggest that the fifty-fifty marriage asset split is today more equitable in that the custodial parents receive considerable financial support through child support arrangements. This is a view strongly put by the Lone Fathers Association. The National Women's Consultative Council also asked for less discretionary powers and supported the notion of equal shares. The Family Court was at pains to point out that 95 per cent of all property arrangements are settled outside the court and that litigation affects only 5 per cent of cases. However, one cannot assume that the 95 per cent of cases settled outside are always either amicable or fair.

Our recommendations take those views on board. We support equality of sharing as the starting point in the allocation of property and that, where they exist, pre-nuptial or subsequent financial agreements should be the starting point but that the courts should have the discretionary powers to vary from the principle of equal sharing based on the length of marriage, future needs, financial impact and other similar considerations.

From my perspective, rural property was the pivotal point of this whole review in terms of how the Family Court regards the treatment of family farms in determining property settlements. Numerous cases brought to my attention involve farms being sold up and non-custodial male farmers losing not only their home but also their source of income to accommodate the requirement that a property split be done between the two parties. I have never subscribed to the view that a divorce ought to result in someone losing his or her home, job and livelihood. In my view, any law that supports that notion is clearly wrong.

I am in disagreement with the Family Court judges who, in the past, have seen nothing wrong with destroying a family farming operation. Their judgments have been counter to the notion of equity and law. Neither do I accept, as was suggested to the Committee, that the court attempts as far as it can to alleviate the sorts of problems associated with farms and businesses. I have too many examples highlighting this problem contained in letters in my office. Indeed, one such case started my relentless campaign to have this inquiry started.
Far too many totally unfair and inappropriate judgments affecting family farms need to be addressed. A submission in the report reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I have recently been involved in a divorce and property settlement, which I believe I was unfairly and unjustly treated, I was ordered to pay in excess of $600,000.00. This amount was arrived at by way of percentage of property value. Property which had been gifted to me by my father only three years prior to separation.

I am pleased that the Committee came to a similar view and recognised that family farms need to be considered differently in determining property settlements in marriage breakdown. I am delighted that we have done so and I trust that the legislation is soon amended.

PARA.TAB: We recommend that the Act be amended to distinguish farming properties from other matrimonial property so that the court takes into consideration such matters as how the farming property was brought into the marriage and the necessity to retain the property as an income producing unit. Frankly, if this Committee achieved nothing other than these changes, I would be satisfied that it had not been entirely without purpose.

The resolution of property disputes has frequently been linked with maintenance. As I have already said, the operation of the Child Support Agency was outside our terms of reference. However, that did not prevent many submissions being received that dealt with this vexed issue. Indeed, 198 submissions detailed complaints about the level of child support payable, and more than 70 complaints were directly aimed at the Child Support Agency. Complaints have continued to pour in both to the Committee and to the offices of myself and others.

Given that maintenance and child support are inextricably linked, the Committee could not ignore them. Generally, the complaints centred on the formula base, the inability of many non-custodial parents to start a second family because of the financial obligations placed on them by the CSA to their first family and the overwhelming amount of resentment that the whole process generated. In some cases, it has forced people to abandon employment to avoid their financial commitments. It has restricted increased access to avoid breaching the formula for shared custody and it has resulted in less access because the non-custodial parent cannot afford it.

Additionally, there has been no provision for custodial parents contributing below an income of nearly $30,000. We were told that some non-custodial parents are taking a lesser property settlement, usually outside the court process, to avoid expensive legal fees and on the assumption that their financial obligations would be reduced. That frequently was not the case, and the Child Support Agency made no recognition of the property settlement arrangements.

On that point, I expressed concern at evidence the Committee took last week from a representative of the Child Support Agency. In response to my questioning on what consideration the Child Support Agency gives to the changed circumstances of custodial parents, the gentleman concerned responded:

SPEECH.PARA: That is entirely irrelevant. It has nothing to do with the maintenance of the children of the previous relationship.
That attitude concerns me and clearly fuels resentment to an already very emotional issue.

PARA.TAB: I wish to raise two other issues only briefly, although that in no way implies their lack of importance. The first is the very disturbing issue of costs. This issue is dealt with at length in chapter 14 of the report. Increasing costs are affecting the ability of people to obtain justice through the Family Court system. Surely that is contrary to the spirit and intent of the Act. We have suggested a number of issues relevant to this subject. Too often it was suggested that the only winners in divorce were the solicitors.

Figures of $400,000 or $250,000 were given in various witnesses' evidence, and these were not large property settlements of millionaires. Those costs will never be recouped. In those cases, there seemed obvious grounds for the litigants to complain. Perhaps in other cases it was simply a matter of a client refusing to accept the advice offered and wanting to continue the litigation. The incidents reported to the Committee suggest that the legal profession needs to take a long, hard look at its charging procedures for family law. There is a great deal of room for improvement.

The other issue that I wish to raise briefly—again, it is one that Senator McKiernan has already mentioned—is our recommendation that the powers of the Commonwealth Ombudsman be extended to examine decisions of the Family Court which, until now, have been outside his jurisdiction, notwithstanding the fact that many people have taken that course of appeal. The Committee is of the view that it is an important countercheck on the Family Court and, as such, ought to be available to those who do not believe they have been fairly treated. Additionally, the Family Court could do well to examine its complaints handling mechanisms and see whether these might not be improved.

I draw my comments to a close, although there are so many other aspects that I want to comment on. I thank the Committee Chairman for his cooperation and the manner in which he treated this entire reference. That we have achieved consensus on so many issues is of great personal satisfaction. I also wish to be associated with the Chairman's remark as to the heavy burdens placed on the Committee secretariat, which has not had an easy job processing so many submissions and dealing with so many people, who understandably hold very strong and emotional views on this topic.

My electorate staff have been similarly very heavily involved in this issue now for several years. My personal thanks go to my electorate secretary, Mrs Toni Rogers, for the work that she has done for me and for the many other members and senators' officers in handling family law queries.

As I said at the beginning, no amount of legislation or review will ever remove entirely the bitterness, acrimony and sadness surrounding marriage break-up. This report hopefully takes the process of divorce a little closer to one of equity. As legislators, that is all that we can hope to achieve. I said when I moved for the establishment of this inquiry that we were setting out on a daunting task but that the rewards would be many. I believe that if this report is taken by the judiciary and all the people who have any association with family law, it will have achieved in no small measure a great deal to help people in those sad and emotional times.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity to add some comments to those already made on the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act. Unfortunately, I was not able to hear all the remarks of Senator Reid and Senator Brownhill. I did hear most of what Senator McKiernan said. I am fairly sure that I could concur with most of their comments. In particular, I would like to thank my colleagues on this Committee. Sometimes there is a clear division of opinion on committees but things worked out agreeably. Sometimes things become fairly divisive but in this Committee there was a unanimity of purpose and a remarkable ability for all members of the Committee to produce this almost unanimous report, with two very small dissents.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to thank the very hard-working staff. I am sure the Senate has already been told that we received over 1,000 submissions. The work required to sift through the opening round of letters and submissions to this inquiry was a massive task. It did not lessen as the inquiry proceeded because the interest in the Family Law Act and this inquiry persists. The Committee was tagged by many of those people in the community who had a lively interest in the deliberations of the Committee.

There are just a few points that I would like to highlight in my comments. The people who contacted me before this inquiry started, and certainly the people who led me at one stage to try to seek a reference to the counselling service of the Family Court through the Standing Committee on Community Affairs—more particularly women—were concerned about the consequences of the Family Court on marriage breakdown associated with domestic violence. Most people would know of some of the tragedies that have occurred within the Family Court where men and women—husband and wife—were required to attend together and have not in the past had adequate protection, even within the precincts of the court. On a few occasions very serious harm has been done to some women attending the court and on a few occasions I think there has been actual death. Those things no longer pertain and the Family Court has realised the importance of providing adequate security to those people attending the court. The counselling service should recognise that sometimes it is inappropriate for couples to attend together, particularly where the question of domestic violence is concerned.

We have heard Senator Tate in this place on a number of occasions point to the importance of the court protection orders actually being effected as well as being effective. As in the responsibility for who does what within the court precincts, there has been a period when the protection of citizens under the Family Court protection orders has fallen between Commonwealth and State jurisdictions. It has taken quite some time for those matters to be sorted out so that women who are victims of domestic violence and involved in Family Court proceedings can now expect a better understanding by the court of their needs for protection, both during the counselling and court procedures and subsequently.

No matter how well we might recommend changes under the counselling procedures in the Family Court here, it is also true that women continue to be harassed by unhappy spouses. I certainly put on record in this place and can say it again that there are still women who are murdered in this country as a result of domestic violence. Nearly 50 per cent of the murders in this country each year are domestic violence related. It is a matter of the greatest gravity that the Family Court, in looking at the very unhappy breakdown of some marriages, take account of those facts.

One of the other points I want to make—I have raised it in this place on a few occasions previously—relates to the importance of Family Court judges being up-to-date with community standards and having a recognition and understanding of what is the state of play in the real world. Sometimes it has been clear that some of the comments of Family Court judges would have us believe that they are not up-to-date with community standards.

In this report we recommend that it is important for the Family Court to have a more systematic and intensive program of judicial education in relevant non-legal matters, particularly in factors such as domestic violence and child abuse, which can influence the welfare of the child. I would also hope that that could be read without necessarily requiring the welfare of the child to be of prior consideration.

In matters such as domestic violence, the welfare of a woman is equally deserving of the court's consideration. In making this recommendation we appreciate that sometimes Family Court judges are not completely up to date with what are community standards. It is not acceptable for women in our society to be victims of domestic violence. It is not acceptable for women from one State to another to be harassed or hounded across our nation. This is what happens to many women. It is very unacceptable that women who have left a violent marriage to try to make a new start and provide adequate care and support for their children should find themselves harassed and hounded across the nation.

The recent proposals for portability of protection orders go a long way towards the courts, governments and parliaments recognising that it is not okay for women to be victims of violence and to be harassed across the country. At the same time it is also quite clear that we cannot guarantee protection to women who have come out of a domestically violent marriage. We cannot give a guarantee after a divorce or after a woman's leaving a violent marriage. We need to address ways in which portable protection orders can be provided to the necessary police forces or magistrates courts in the places to which a woman might move. We need to ensure that protection in fact exists rather than being set out on a piece of paper.

Under the recent agreements between Attorneys-General it is proposed that the issuing of a protection order will allow police immediately to seize all guns belonging to the person against whom the protection order is issued. These steps are a beginning to protect women who are the victims of domestic violence. Certainly, the changes reflect the very considerable move in this Parliament, in government and in society to recognise that domestic violence does exist and to determine exactly what constitutes such violence. I am very pleased that we have addressed that in this report on the Family Law Act.

We have addressed all the bits and pieces of the consequences of the administration of the Family Law Act. In particular, we have pointed to the importance of counselling being provided early. It should be provided in a way that takes account of the particular circumstances of any family—that is, if there is a domestic violence situation, couples are not required to attend counselling at the same time; or, if joint counselling is agreed to, adequate protection must be guaranteed to the woman.

In the report we also talk about the importance of mediation as an alternative dispute resolution mechanism. Mediation may not be the preferred or appropriate way to deal with a situation involving domestic violence. Mediation often works best if both parties to the marriage breakdown can attend. That, of course, may not be possible if the spouse who is a victim of violence cannot be guaranteed protection.

Recognising the time constraints, I will not trawl over many of the things that I would like to say about this very comprehensive report which will be an excellent addition to the Family Law Act and its implementation. In particular, the chapters on the role and effectiveness of counselling, mediation and marriage guidance deserve very serious deliberation and consideration.

I think every member of the Committee recognised the importance of marriage guidance. The report proposes that even school-age children, and in particular secondary school children, be given access to early education on communications and relationship skills. If this is done, it is hoped that in the longer term there will be less marriage breakdown due to the failure to address the resolution of difficulties. The breakdown of some marriages is evidence that lots of people in our society lack these basic communication skills.

The other area that deserves consideration is the enforcement of Family Court orders. I have talked about protection orders.
