Until recently, and possibly even still, in some jurisdictions protection orders are not satisfactorily or adequately enforced. As well as that, much evidence was given to the Committee about the failure to enforce access orders. There is a concern that the penalties and sanctions under the Family Law Act are not being used to require the implementation of court orders.

We even talk about consideration of the reverse onus of proof against a person who fails to meet an access order. Orders are made to require a person to provide access. It is therefore argued in this report that it is up to the person who fails to satisfy that order to justify or come up with a reasonable excuse why that person was unable or unwilling to fulfil it.

A number of chapters in the report deal with matters concerning property. I simply draw attention to the fact that we did look very extensively at property issues. I have to say that it is now something like a mere 100 years since women won the right under English law to have some claim on their own children. Up until the 1880s women in Britain had no claim of access to their children. As with all property in a marriage, children belonged to the man. Over this century we have seen a breaking down of those laws and a recognition of the rights of women to have access to their children, to parental responsibilities and to property. This report highlights that, by and large, a property settlement following the breakdown of a marriage would start off with a fifty-fifty split. That is an extraordinary move—even when compared with what happened 25 years ago.

We had a huge number of submissions and complaints relating to the child support scheme. This area was not part of our terms of reference. But we could not properly ignore the number of submissions. So we wrote a chapter on the problems relating to the child support scheme. This may be something that the Government will want to take up; it may be something that will lead to a further examination. This is a very constructive, thoughtful and comprehensive report. I am very happy to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act which was tabled this afternoon by Senator McKiernan, the Chairman of the Committee. The Committee had its beginnings in a motion moved some time ago by Senator Brownhill in response to many representations that he had received from constituents asking for just such an inquiry.

PARA.TAB: I must admit that at first I thought this was likely to be a waste of time. It is a matter of public record that the family law area has been surveyed, investigated, researched and reported on many times. As a result, there have been countless reports and perhaps not as much action as one would wish.

I thought that it might have been quicker if I approached the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) and submitted a range of reforms that the Australian Democrats thought should be implemented as a matter of urgency. When it became obvious after three months that the Attorney-General was unable to proceed with most of those requests for reforms, the Democrats decided that we would support Senator Brownhill's motion for a select committee, and the Committee started work.

The inquiry turned out to be a substantial undertaking indeed. It received more than 1000 submissions. Public hearings were held in all States, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. Some 120 recommendations are the outcome of this report. Many of them are not directed to the dissolution of marriage but to the maintenance of marriage, to attempts to achieve reconciliation and to offer as much support as possible to people going through this most traumatic human experience.

The Committee worked well under the sensitive yet goal-directed chairmanship of Senator McKiernan, with quite superb and expert support from the secretariat and, in particular, its Secretary, Robina Mills, the legal adviser, David Wallace, the senior research officer, Fiona Taylor, and the very able administrator, Lesley Cowan.

My satisfaction with the results of the report is somewhat tempered by the realisation that the law is necessarily a very blunt and, in the end, inadequate instrument to assist people in this most traumatic area of human experience. Another aspect that I found rather unsatisfactory during the process of this inquiry was that many of the 1,000-plus witnesses recounted personal problems, personal anguish and personal trauma and asked the Committee to assist them.

It was not easy to withstand those requests. Very obviously, it was not our task, it was not within the ambit of our activity, and we had neither the resources nor the avenues open to us to assist with individual difficulties. Nonetheless, I think all members of the Committee would have experienced considerable anguish—`anguish' is not too strong a word—when we faced these personal experiences. I think that to a large extent it informed our determination to do the best we could in this difficult area.

That aside, the results of the Committee were a lot better than I expected could be achieved. I agree with the Committee's report and recommendations. They are a very significant step forward in the continuing effort to improve the provisions and the implementation of the Family Law Act. Nevertheless, a number of matters require stronger action. I will refer to the three points which formed the subject of my dissent a little later tonight.

One of the largest areas in which I believe positive progress was made is in the assessment of the Family Court counselling service and the recommendations arising from that. There was very clear agreement that increased resources were necessary to meet the demand in this area. In particular, Committee members felt that it was necessary to reduce waiting times, to make sure that after hours services were available, that visiting services to outlying areas could be provided and that additional resources could be provided to cope with the additional caseload due to references from States regarding ex-nuptial children and other areas of counselling, such as grief counselling, post decision and post settlement counselling, which the Committee thought were essential.

In addition, the Committee recommended that filing and sub-registries be established in a number of regional centres other than those currently in existence. This includes a new registry for Geelong. The Committee also felt that continued and ongoing training was necessary for councillors, particularly—and previous speakers have mentioned this—in the areas of domestic violence and child sexual abuse. The Committee found differing levels of understanding and expertise in the various courts around the country. I was also pleased to see that the Committee considered that an interpreter service for the Family Court was essential and must be provided free of charge. For people who are in a strange country, with a language they do not speak, to have to go through this emotional experience without being able to communicate in their own tongue would be an additional burden.

I turn to some other matters related to the Family Court counselling service. I note with satisfaction that the Committee recommends the promotion of complementary community based counselling services and mediation services coupled with a determined push to increase community education in the community and in schools.

Probably the most difficult area is custody and access. There was some suggestion at the beginning of the inquiry that we could achieve a cultural change in the attitudes prevalent in this area if we turned away from the term `custody', which somehow conjures up an image of imprisonment and control, and perhaps went to more neutral terms—something like `joint parenting', or `parenting plans'. In the end, after receiving considerable evidence on this question, the Committee decided that this was not a good way to go at this time, that we were dealing not so much with terminology but with substance, and that we needed to ensure that as far as possible this area was administered in any improved manner.

The Committee also addressed itself to the question of separate representation of children and noted that this is provided in the Act. Under section 65, the Family Court is given power to order separate representation `in any proceedings under the Family Law Act in which the welfare of a child is relevant'. The discretionary nature of this provision and the absence of easy access to legal advice for children do not satisfy either the general principle that all human beings are autonomous individuals regardless of age or the provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, to which Australia is a signatory.

The effective operation of section 65 is limited in two ways. Firstly, the court exercises its discretion to appoint a separate legal representative somewhat infrequently, and by definition only when it has become obvious that the welfare of the child could be affected unless this step was taken. Secondly, the number of cases actually coming before the court is small compared with the total number of marriage dissolutions involving children. More than half—55.6 per cent—of all divorces granted in 1990 involved children. However, approximately 95 per cent of all divorces do not reach the stage of proceedings before the Family Court. Hence, in most divorces, decisions affecting children are made by agreement between the separating parties in circumstances which do not enable the court to use its discretion under section 65.

Even if such an agreement were to be registered with the Family Court, the court is not obliged to examine the terms of the agreement. Only 380 such agreements were registered in 1990. The court cannot assess the effect on the former partners or on their children of the agreements and their contents. The opportunity for emotional blackmail to achieve, for example, a favourable property settlement, trading off access or custody provisions, is obvious. Indeed, the Committee has been provided with some anecdotal evidence to that effect.

The underlying assumption in such cases is clear: the children are chattels and may be treated as such. Separate representation for all children involved in family law proceedings has been recently introduced in New Zealand. The operation of the scheme is awaiting analysis, although the Committee was offered informal and anecdotal evidence that the cost to the legal system was substantial. The cost factor will indeed require careful consideration, but where the welfare of children is at issue it should not be a bar to the implementation of an appropriate scheme.

In practical terms, and to a large extent in legal terms, children are under the control of adults in a family or household which is intact. This is often used to rebut arguments in favour of separate legal representation for children. However, the need to protect the welfare of children, even in so-called normal settings, is on the public record, not least in the growing acknowledgment of domestic violence in families across all socioeconomic strata. The loss of security and the emotional upheaval of a marriage dissolution lends particular urgency to the need for separate legal representation. However, the principle of greater personal autonomy, enunciated in the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of the Child, has general application.

To meet these requirements, I added the following recommendations to the report: firstly, in all cases involving access, custody or property disputes, where the contestants have care and control of children, a separate legal representative for the children be provided by the court; secondly, that ready access to legal advice be made available through community legal centres or other agencies funded by the Commonwealth Government for children who are in the care and control of persons undertaking marriage dissolution proceedings; and, thirdly, that the Registrar of the Family Court be given the responsibility to ensure that all children involved in a marriage dissolution be informed that such a service is available.

In the area of custody, the Committee recommended that custodial parents share the costs of travel—often long distances—for non-custodial parents as a result of changes in the domestic arrangements of their former partner. That was one of the areas on which the Committee received considerable representations.

The other area that provided a lot of heartache was the difficulty that some non-custodial parents experienced when seeking to visit their children under the access arrangements and found, either intentionally or by accident, that this had become impossible. Attention is drawn in the report to the summary enforcement option available in such cases. The report also notes that early intervention counselling should be instituted on a much broader scale where such access problems are expected to ensure that some early action is taken.

Division of property has notoriously been an area of difficulty in marriage dissolution. The Committee has recommended that an equal sharing of property be the starting point where an agreement is not in existence and that where an agreement exists that agreement should be the starting point. However, considerable discretion has been left with the court. In exceptional circumstances, the court may pay attention to the length of the marriage, the care and control of children, obligations that one of the former partners has under the child support legislation, the future needs of each former spouse, the financial impact on each former spouse, the property brought into the marriage, the home-making and child rearing contribution made during the marriage and the financial contribution made during the marriage.

The other notoriously difficult area that the Committee addressed was the area of superannuation. The Committee recommended that superannuation be considered a property asset and be taken into account on the basis of the notional realisable value at the time of the hearing and that this asset be shared between the former partners at the discretion of the court in proportion to the length of marriage or co-habitation by reference to the total period of contribution to the superannuation fund. Whether a trustee can be directed to divide the asset in this way remains to be decided and presents some legal difficulties.

In the area of property disputes de facto couples have so far been disadvantaged. The Family Court has jurisdiction over de facto couples when they separate if children are present. However, where there are no children, the Family Court has no jurisdiction over property disputes. The inadequacy of State law in this area is notorious, and the Committee recommended that separate legislation be passed—separate from the Family Law Act, that is—to give the court jurisdiction over property disputes of separating de facto couples.

In this area, the definition for a de facto couple refers to a partnership between a man and a woman. I have added the recommendation that this should be extended to de facto gay couples since I am of the view that there is no reason why these couples should not be helped in a similar way. It has been acknowledged in the report that the Family Court's addressing this particular matter would in no way detract from the basic premise, which is enunciated in the Family Law Act, that marriage, as a social institution, must be supported and protected. However, it is quite clear that we must take account of social realities: that the number of de facto unions in our society is increasing and that these people, as well as legally married couples in the traditional sense, should have access to the legal system.

An area that has been difficult in the past, and continues to be problematical, is the area of farming properties. Very clearly, a farming property usually represents the major asset in a marriage and there is the desire—in fact, the need—to retain the farm as an intact and viable income producing unit. At the same time, the Act requires that the assets be divided. The court has addressed this matter by raising a number of exceptions to that rule and offering a number of avenues in which this could be addressed.

I found it a matter of regret that, due to the absence before the Committee of specific evidence, the Committee could not address the matter of the small business—that is, a non-farming business; say, the corner grocer store—which in many cases may well be the only asset of the couple. But I trust that in time this matter will be addressed in a similar way to the consideration given to farming properties.

The Committee has recommended that financial agreements made between prospective partners or agreements made during the currency of a marriage be given higher status. In particular, it has been recommended that such agreements should contain a list of assets that each of the partners brings to the marriage and that they should make provision for variation. The Committee also recommends that the court retain a residual discretion to deal with changing circumstances. That is a very worthwhile move since it could well be said that an agreement made in the first flush of a new marriage may not receive the same hard-headed consideration that the making of a commercial contract might receive and that partners, unwittingly or willingly, might disadvantage themselves.

The Committee also recommends that mediation be given a much greater role in the area of counselling, arbitration and settling of marriage disputes. But it would be true to say that the Committee, at this stage, has not seen fit to push this to the stage where mediation is offered as a direct alternative to the court process.

I was pleased to see that self representation and the facilities to be offered for people seeking to represent themselves form part of the report, and that an officer of the court is to be appointed in each court to make relevant advice available.

In conclusion, I wish to advert briefly to the fact that the Committee has sought and received agreement to extend the inquiry to deal with the administration and funding of the Family Court. Under the terms of reference that the Committee had it was not possible to address this in any depth. Very clearly, the recommendations made by the Committee would not have a lot of substance unless one addressed the perennial questions: where is the money coming from, and how much is required? I am very glad that this step was taken, and look forward to the continuing work of the Committee on this question and its report that will be brought down in February.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters I present the interim report of the Committee entitled Counting the vote on election night, together with the transcript of evidence. I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have my tabling speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: COUNTING THE VOTE ON ELECTION NIGHT
INTERIM REPORT ON THE INQUIRY INTO THE CONDUCT OF THE 1990 ELECTION, PART II AND PREPARATIONS FOR THE NEXT FEDERAL ELECTION
Mr President,

The report I have just tabled addresses part of the Committee's current inquiry into the conduct of the 1990 Election Part II, and preparations for the next federal election. The issues covered in the interim report are expected to come before the Senate this week. Accordingly the Committee decided to provide the Parliament with its views before proposed changes become part of the Act.

In reporting on the conduct of the 1990 federal election the Committee was critical of the time taken to finalise the House of Representatives result—which was not known until four days after the election. The Committee made several recommendations aimed at speeding the House of Representatives result, including better access for scrutineers to monitor the preferences.

In responding to this recommendation the Australian Electoral Commission has proposed a provisional two-candidate preferred distribution to be conducted by polling officials in each polling place on election night.

Senators will recall that a Bill for an Act to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 was introduced in the Senate on 15 October 1992. Clause 22 of the Bill deals with the scrutiny of votes in House of Representatives elections. An addition to section 274 of the Principal Act is proposed to provide for "a scrutiny of such preferences (other than first preferences), on such of the ballot-papers, as are required by the direction; . . . " This allows for the provisional two candidate preferred distribution, if so directed by the Australian electoral officer for the State or Territory. No details are provided in the Bill regarding how this is to be done.

Details on the new election night procedure were provided in three submissions from the Australian Electoral Commission. Certain aspects of the procedures caused some concern, including proposals for transmitting the result, the process of identifying the candidates to receive provisional preferences and access for scrutineers.

In relation to transmitting the House of Representatives results, the AEC's preferred position was to hold the results of the primary count until the two-candidate preferred result was available. The two results were to be transmitted at the same time to the national tally room, thereby providing an earlier and more accurate result than could be achieved using previous procedures.

While welcoming the promise of a more accurate result on polling night, the Committee could see no reason for creating a "nexus" between the primary vote result and the two-candidate preferred result. This topic was explored at length in two public hearings during which the Committee took evidence from AEC officials regarding the arguments for creating the "nexus". The Committee was not convinced that there was any good reason for holding back the results of the primary count—in fact there is an expectation from the public and candidates that results will be broadcast as soon as possible.

The Committee has made six recommendations in this interim report, covering procedures for identifying the two candidates for the provisional distribution, counting and transmitting the vote, access for scrutineers and liaison with the media.

The Committee wishes to thank the Australian Electoral Commission officers for their advice on the technicalities of the election night system and for their willingness to consider the Committee's concerns in relation to the planned procedures. The Committee believes that the recommendations in this interim report will provide a more accurate result than in previous years, and will satisfy the needs of the public and candidates in the most timely and efficient way.
Mr President, I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (QUALIFICATIONS AND DISQUALIFICATION OF MEMBERS OF THE PARLIAMENT) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Kernot) agreed to:

That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution with respect to the qualifications for membership of the Parliament and the disqualifications of members of the Parliament.
Motion (by Senator Kernot) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: One of the mysteries of Australia's constitutional history is the number of anomalies gathered along the way. There are provisions in the constitution which are widely agreed to be expired, or even silly, and about which nothing substantive has been done.
Paragraph (iv) of section 44 is a case in point.

Section 44 as a whole deals with "disqualification". That is, it prescribes that certain persons, or classes of persons, "shall be incapable of being chosen or of sitting" as a member of this place or the other place.

Among the curious grab-bag of circumstances listed in section 44 is paragraph (iv). In effect, this paragraph disqualifies people from being a candidate for election if they hold an "office of profit under the Crown.

While the provision operates to prevent a person holding two jobs at one time, with the public purse paying for both, it also operates to remove a fundamental right—the right to be a candidate—from an enormous number of Australians.

Time and time again Parliamentary committees and constitutional commissions have reported that this provision should have been changed, and have even prepared draft legislation for this purpose. Yet nothing has been done.
Why?
The answer probably is that to this point there hasn't really seemed all that much of a pressing need.
Sure, the provision is wrong in principle.

Sure, it inconveniences a fair number of school teachers or police officers or clerks or public sector engineers who want to stand for election—but until recently ways have been found for ameliorating the worst effects, and in any case the "victims" hadn't complained too loudly.

Now we have the Cleary case to focus our attention on this matter. More significantly, in terms of practical politics, if the High Court confirms Mr Cleary's ineligibility we will also have had the Cleary case to focus the community's attention on this very silly provision of the constitution. And we ourselves will then look silly if we are seen to continue to fiddle.
This, clearly, is a time for us to act together. It seems from report after report that we are all of the same view on this matter.
The Bill I am presenting is substantially based on that recommended by the Constitutional Commission in Appendix K of its Final Report in 1988.
None of us can claim to have uniquely identified either the problem or the sensible solution set out in the Bill.

We can, all of us, join in saying that the doubt and uncertainty—not to mention the potential disruption, cost and inconvenience—of the Cleary case has got us to agree on one thing at least. This is that the piece of silliness acknowledged by common consent to be enshrined in paragraph 44(iv) of the Constitution will now by this Bill be put behind us.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Jones) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Coulter)—as amended by leave—agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to submit to a referendum a question in relation to a goods and services tax.
Motion (by Senator Coulter) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Referendum (Goods and Services Tax) Bill 1992 provides for a referendum to be held at the time of the next Federal election. Voters would be asked a simple question: do you agree to the introduction in Australia of a goods and services tax?

PARA.TAB: On 6 November the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, told the House of Representatives that if the coalition wins the election Labor would pass legislation imposing a GST. On 9 November Mr Keating said that Labor wants the coming Federal election to be `a referendum on the GST'. Well, Mr Keating, here it is: a Bill to hold a referendum on the GST.

This Bill aims to make it as hard as possible for the Prime Minister to manipulate voters into casting their election ballot on one issue. It also makes it as hard as possible for a harsh and punitive goods and services tax to be imposed on the Australian people. A GST referendum would allow the election to be decided on the big issues: the state of the economy, society, unemployment and the environment. With a million Australians unemployed, a huge and growing foreign debt and an industrial base that is small and ecologically unsustainable, it is a perversion of democracy to focus on a solitary tax measure, large and unfair though it is. Mr Keating knows full well that if the coalition wins the election, it will do so in spite of the GST. This week's Newspoll showed that only 28 per cent of Australians support a GST—some mandate!

The fact is that whichever party wins government, it will do so with well under 50 per cent of the popular vote in the House of Representatives and less than 40 per cent in the Senate. That party will have a mandate to run government. It can expect to have its Supply and Appropriation Bills passed, but every other piece of legislation will have to run the gauntlet of parliamentary scrutiny. This includes tax Bills which, contrary to popular belief, are not Supply Bills.

Recent history is littered with examples of Labor and coalition oppositions voting against tax Bills announced as Budget measures. In 1981, Mr Keating joined his colleagues in the Opposition and voted against sales tax legislation to force the Fraser Government to exempt necessities of life. After the 1985 Budget, the coalition voted against the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and the ending of tax deductions on entertainment expenses. There is no parliamentary convention or constitutional restriction which requires Parliament to pass tax Bills.

The only honourable pretext on which Mr Keating could vote for a GST in opposition would be if this referendum were passed by a majority of Australians. Otherwise his pledge to pass a GST will be seen for what it is—a sell-out of Labor voters and a cynical attempt to win government by coercion. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of remarks to make in respect of what Senator Coulter has just said. In my view, the question that he suggests be put by way of referendum to the Australian people—that is, `Do you want a GST implemented in Australia?'—indicates what some less kind people than I might refer to as the stupidity of the Democrats. Why do we not put the simple question: `Do you want more of the same?' It is just about as telling to the Australian people as the simple question, `Do you want a GST?'.

PARA.TAB: The question `Do you want more of the same?' connotes all the things that I would want to indicate to the Australian people that this Labor Government has brought about: one million people unemployed and a recession we did not have to have which, all of a sudden, became the recession we had to have. All those sorts of things are conveyed in the emotive question `Do you want more of the same?' Similarly, the question `Do you want a GST?' conveys the message `Do you want another tax?'.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you and I know—and it is probably in the forefront of your mind, if not the deepest depths of your heart—that that is not the question that is being put to the Australian people at the next election. It is not simply a question of whether they want a GST. It is a question of whether they want a GST if they also get personal income tax cuts, a disposal of the petrol excise, a disposal of the training guarantee levy, a disposal of customs duty, a disposal of lump sum tax on superannuation, and so on.

The question that should be put to the Australian people is not, `Do you want a GST?' but, `Do you want a GST if, in exchange for it, you can get some things and get rid of some other things?'. In other words, it is an overly simplistic question which would mislead the Australian public. That is not the mandate that my Party is seeking or is going to seek from the Australian people at the next election.

We will not be saying to the Australian public, `Do you want a GST at all costs?'—come what may, willy-nilly. We have put before the Australian public a plan which we have chosen to call Fightback—fight back against the decay, the million unemployed people, the hopeless situation presented by this Government. It is true that Fightback includes a GST, but it also includes a number of other very positive things. It is a plus and minus sort of package where members of the Australian public will choose, on balance, which they would prefer—more of the same or a package such as the one that we propose.

I do not wish to take much time because I know there is pressure on the Senate at the moment. The question proposed by the Democrats does not in fact portray the whole question that will be put to the Australian people by virtue of going to the polls at the next election. The second point I make—and it just happens to be Senator Coulter to whom these remarks need to be made—is that Senator Coulter has tonight committed a sin, or what I would regard as a sin, that the Democrats frequently commit. Senator Coulter has said, `Do not think for one minute that if the coalition is elected at the next election it will have a mandate to implement the policies it wants'.

This is a somewhat breathtaking remark from the Democrats. He says, `Do not think that because someone has put a broad plan before the Australian people they are entitled to seek the implementation of that plan—not at all'. Senator Coulter has made a mathematical calculation which indicates—and, incidentally, it is quite right—that a party can get a majority of the seats without having a majority of the votes. He basically says that, therefore, the system stinks and we should not rely on the system of gaining seats in the lower House. The system that allows a party to get a majority of the seats in the lower House does not require it to have a majority of votes. He says that, therefore, we should not accept that as being a mandate.

However, one can question the role of the Democrats in this chamber; one can say to them, `For every seat you have, you have to get only 14-odd per cent of the vote'. Why should we, the major parties, which gain a much bigger proportion of the vote, allow them—how ever many of them are left at the death knell of their Party, or that which calls itself a party—to hold the balance of power over what will or will not happen in this country? The Democrats then say, `Do not be silly. That is the way we vote. That is the way one gets elected to the Senate. That is how the system works. Therefore, we are entitled to expect to exercise that power'.

The point I am trying to make is that the Democrats cannot criticise the system by saying, `I know you meant to get a majority of seats but because you do not need a majority of votes to get a majority of seats, we do not approve' and then, in the next breath, without even turning face, say that in this place, which is an integral part of the system—it works together; it is not a case of the House of Representatives down there and the Senate up here and never the two shall meet; we are all part of one system—with the limited proportion of votes that they get they should be able to decide what will happen with the whole nation. They do have to try to resolve that matter for themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to resolve it.

—They think it is quite amusing. Senator Coulter says we have to resolve it. I suppose we have to put up with it until they do resolve it. If the Democrats want to have any integrity in what they say, they have to resolve this matter. They simply cannot say that the system in one House does not justify those with the majority having a say and then, in the next breath, say that those with a minority are entitled to decide how the country should be run. The Democrats have to sort that out. They cannot have their cake and eat it too.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, the question being proposed by the Democrats is ludicrously simple—probably indicative of their own minds and capacity. Secondly, the proposition they put forward as to why this is necessary is totally unacceptable. Thirdly, the proposition they put forward as to why they ought to have the say and discount in some way the say given to a party which earns the majority of seats in the lower House—albeit that it may be without a majority of the population, as the Labor Party now governs—is a ludicrous proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
