SPEECH.PARA: IMMIGRATION (EDUCATION) CHARGE BILL 1992

Mr President, this Bill is to impose a charge on those adults who apply for certain visas and entry permits and who will need instruction in the English language. The Bill also provides scope for charging people who are already resident in Australia and who enrol in courses arranged under the Commonwealth-funded Adult Migrant English program.
The charges are in two forms:
Up to a maximum of $4080 for applicants from 1 January 1993 who are issued visas or entry permits after 1 March 1993.
Up to $250 a year for current residents enrolling or re-enrolling in Adult Migrant English Courses.
In return the Commonwealth undertakes to fund up to 510 hours of tuition.

The charges are part of the broader reform strategy spelt out in a statement made jointly with my colleague, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. In brief, the statement details plans for removing the backlog of need for English as a Second Language (ESL) among long-term residents who are registered jobseekers.
The Department, through the A.M.E.P., will prevent the backlog from growing:
by honouring commitments to currently enrolled clients;
and by delivering ESL for incoming migrants more effectively than in the past.

The Government will also provide for other groups, particularly women, who may fall outside those broad priorities. $500,000 is earmarked for them. Our strategies will bring significant benefits to Australian society. Commonwealth funding of the A.M.E.P. has increased substantially in recent years, exceeding $100 million in 1991-92.

This year total Commonwealth resources for adult ESL will exceed $142 million, of which $42.2 million will be targeted at jobseekers through labour market training programs. As these commitments demonstrate, the Government recognises that proficiency in English is an essential part of Australian life.

Learning English benefits Australian society by facilitating communication—and hence equality of opportunity—among Australians. At the same time proficiency in English benefits individuals. It is reasonable therefore that individuals who benefit from the Adult Migrant English Program should contribute to its cost.

There are exceptions—among them refugees, preferential family members and those who are wholly dependant on social security payments. Hence revenue projections are modest: $3.65 Million in 1992/93 and $9.7 Million in 1993/94. The scheme will allow increased resources for the program with no increase in Commonwealth appropriations.

But the benefits of charging go beyond any contribution to revenue. Client contribution to cost will encourage greater motivation from students. More importantly, charging places a greater obligation on service providers to meet the expectations of clients. The charges, together with the other reforms I have touched upon, will result in a better managed, client responsive program.
I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
MIGRATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

Mr President, this Bill amends the Immigration (Education) Act 1971 and the Migration Act 1958. The amendments will permit regulations to be made which provide for the charging and recovery of fees for English language tuition. These are historic developments when considered in tandem with the Immigration (Education) Charge Bill 1992 introduced with this Bill.

Further amendments enable the Commonwealth to carry out its intention of providing 510 hours of English language tuition in an approved English 'course to each eligible adult migrant within a specified time. Future regulations will specify who is to be charged how much.

For the first time, clients of the program will know clearly what service they can expect. That is a significant improvement on previous arrangements when clients had no guarantees of access to the Adult Migrant English Program.

The Bill contains other amendments to the Migration Act. These amendments will allow domestic passengers who are on domestic sectors of international flights with passengers who have cleared immigration to be processed by immigration upon arrival at their destination. The Bill also contains several minor amendments of a technical nature. Those amendments are explained in the explanatory memorandum.
I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
SEX DISCRIMINATION AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992
I am pleased to be able to move the introduction of a piece of legislation which will significantly improve and extend the operation of the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 (`the SDA').
These amendments restate and re-emphasise the Government's commitment to constant vigilance when it comes to improving the status of Australian women.

The amendments I introduce today are part of the Government's response to a number of the recommendations made by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, chaired by Mr Michael Lavarch MP, (`the Lavarch Committee') in its Report of its Inquiry into Equal Opportunity and Equal Status for Women in Australia.
The Committee's Report entitled Half Way to Equal was released on 30 April 1992.
The Lavarch Committee engaged in one of the most wide-ranging and comprehensive inquiries ever conducted into the status of women in Australia.

During the course of its Inquiry the Lavarch Committee received over 600 submissions, held 19 days of public hearings in which it heard testimony from 181 witnesses, held four two-day public seminars and released four discussion papers.

Consequently, the Committee's Report presents one of the most detailed pictures of the position of Australian women ever to be made available. It also represents the first comprehensive evaluation of the operation and effectiveness of the SDA since it commenced in 1984.
The Committee has done a fine job and is to be congratulated.

The Committee made a substantial number of recommendations, including many worthwhile and practical suggestions for amending the SDA and improving the functioning of the Sex Discrimination Commissioner and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (`HREOC').
This Bill contains a number of amendments to the SDA which implement those recommendations.

The Bill will also amend the Industrial Relations Act 1988 (`the IR Act') as part of a new mechanism to allow review of awards and certified agreements which are discriminatory on the basis of sex, marital status or pregnancy.

The Bill also contains, where appropriate, amendments to the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 (`the RDA'), the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 (`the HREOC Act') and the recently passed Disability Discrimination legislation to bring these acts into line with the amendments to the SDA.
Details of the amendments contained in the Bill are set out in the Explanatory Memorandum, which I present to the House.

Let me briefly summarise their provisions while at the same time informing the Senate of the reasons for the Government's speedy response to the Lavarch recommendations and the other initiatives contained in the legislation.
We as a Government recognise the important contribution to the Australian economy made by Australian women, and we do all that we can to encourage their greater participation.
Women have in fact taken up the majority of new jobs created since Labor came to office almost a decade ago.
We also recognise that there are still barriers to women's full and equal participation and our sex discrimination and affirmative action laws were designed to help remedy this.
Women by and large still earn less than men, despite legislated provisions for equal pay, because women and men tend not to be in the same jobs.
Women encounter barriers to promotion—the so-called `glass ceiling'. Sexual harassment remains an unwelcome feature in many women's working lives.
Where such barriers can be addressed by legislation, we will continue our proud pioneering record.
Today represents such an occasion.
There is no doubt that the Sex Discrimination Act has helped change attitudes towards discrimination and has made us understand how widespread—and unacceptable—sexual harassment is.
But like most laws, these need to be scrutinised from time to time to ensure that they are in tune with current realities.

The Lavarch Report provides us with the opportunity to revisit this legislation and the amendments I introduce today represent the Government's response to the Report's recommendations concerning anti-discrimination legislation.
Mr President.
The Lavarch Report also contained a great many other recommendations which did not involve anti-discrimination legislation.
These recommendations are at present being studied by the Government and we hope to be in a position to provide a further response by the end of November.
Today, let me outline our response to the legislative recommendations.
Industrial Awards
We have decided to extend the Sex Discrimination Act to industrial awards.

Concern has been expressed by women's organisations that the advent of enterprise bargaining and the new certified agreement provisions contained in the Industrial Relations Act may have an adverse impact on women.

While the "no disadvantage" test contained in the certified agreement provisions is intended to protect well-established standards such as maternity leave and parental leave, the Government accepts that it will not necessarily operate against provisions which discriminate against women.
The proposed changes will underline the social justice safeguards in the Government's industrial relations framework.
They will signal to all workers, especially women, that the shift to a more decentralised system is a part of a managed and responsible process.
Discriminatory acts done in direct compliance with an award are currently exempted from the operation of the SDA.
The Lavarch Committee received a number of submissions which were critical of this exemption.

In response, we have developed a mechanism so that complaints concerning a discriminatory award will be able to be made to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission under proposed section 50A of the SDA alleging that a person has been discriminated against under an award.

If it appears to the Sex Discrimination Commissioner that the award is discriminatory, the Commissioner must refer the award to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission—unless the Commissioner is of the opinion that the complaint is trivial, vexatious, misconceived or lacking in substance.
If a complaint is referred to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (`the AIRC') the AIRC will then convene a hearing to review the award.
The Sex Discrimination Commissioner will then have standing to appear before the AIRC.

If the AIRC is of the view that the award operates in a discriminatory way, then it will be required to take whatever action is necessary to remove the discrimination, unless it considers that a variation would not be in the public interest.

If the complaint concerns a certified agreement, the AIRC must give the parties to the agreement an opportunity to amend the agreement so as to remove the discrimination, before taking the necessary action to remove the discrimination.
Sexual Harassment
Division 3 of Part II of the SDA, the sexual harassment provisions, currently apply only to sexual harassment in employment and harassment of students by staff in educational institutions.

The current definitions of sexual harassment also require that the complainant suffer disadvantage, or that the complainant had reasonable grounds for believing that she or he would suffer detriment, if she or he objected to the harassment.

I believe that most members of the general community would now accept that a person can be subjected to sexual harassment even if she or he suffers no detriment or disadvantage in connection with her or his employment or education.
Accordingly, this Bill will amend the definition of sexual harassment to remove the requirement that the complainant demonstrate disadvantage.
Under the new definition, the test will be satisfied if the complainant felt offended, humiliated or intimidated by unwelcome conduct of a sexual nature from the respondent.

The test also has an objective element: that is, a reasonable person, having regard to all the circumstances, would have anticipated that the complainant would be offended, humiliated or intimidated by the conduct that is the subject of the complaint.

The Bill extends the ambit of the sexual harassment provisions to the provision of goods, services and facilities, the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs, and dealings in connection with land and the provision of accommodation.
Consequently, it will now, for example, be unlawful for a landlord to sexually harass a tenant.

The existing proscription of sexual harassment in education will also be extended to cover situations where a member of the staff of an educational institution is sexually harassed by an adult student, or where one adult student is sexually harassed by another adult student.
Victimisation
The Lavarch Committee expressed concern that the effectiveness of the SDA could be put at risk by a real fear of victimisation of complainants.
The SDA, the RDA and the HREOC Act will be amended to allow complaints of victimisation to be considered through a process of conciliation.
This is the model that has been used in the recently passed Disability Discrimination legislation and is also the model used in State and Territory anti-discrimination legislation.
Representative Complaints

The representative complaints provisions of the SDA, the RDA and the Disability Discrimination legislation will be replaced by new provisions adapted from the representative proceedings provisions of Part IVA of the Federal Court Amendment Act 1991 which came into force earlier this year.
These amendments will make it easier for a representative complaint to be made.
The procedure for dealing with such complaints will also be flexible enough to ensure that they are handled efficiently and that the procedure is not abused.
Determinations

The amendments contained in this Bill will put in place a new mechanism for enforcing determinations by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission under the SDA, the RDA and the Disability Discrimination legislation.
At present, a complainant who wishes to enforce a determination of the Commission must bring proceedings in the Federal Court.
In practice, this has meant that the Federal Court has had to hear the matter afresh.
This duplication obviously increases stress on the parties, as well as increasing the financial cost borne by the parties and the taxpayer.
Understandably, the existing enforcement mechanism has been subject to judicial criticism (for example, comments made by Wilcox J in Maynard v Neilson (1988) EOC 92-226).

Under the new mechanism, a determination will be registered in the Federal Court, and will have effect as if it were an order of the Court, unless the respondent to the determination applies to the Court, within 28 days, for a review of the determination.
In the absence of such an application, action can be taken through the usual processes of the Court to enforce the determination.
Mr President, I am confident that these amendments will strengthen and streamline our anti-discrimination laws.
They will ensure that women—and men—can get on with their lives, their working lives, their education, able to seek redress against discrimination and disadvantage should that be necessary.
This Government is committed to preserving women's ability to make choices about their lives.
Women value their new independence and ability to take part in all areas of society.
We will ensure that no obstacle or barrier stands in their way that we have the power to remedy.
We stand for the full equality of women and men.
This legislation goes a long way towards furthering that aim.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
HUMAN RIGHTS AND EQUAL OPPORTUNITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

This Bill contains amendments to the Commonwealth's human rights legislation to create the Office of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commissioner and to proscribe dismissal of a worker on the ground of his or her family responsibilities.
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner

This Bill provides another example of this Government's commitment to implementing its undertakings to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people arising from the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.

There were many aspects to the report of the Royal Commission. The fact that the Commission was required at all and the extent of the recommendations made, clearly indicate a need for there to be an ongoing overall report on the exercise of basic human rights by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The extent of the disadvantage suffered by indigenous Australians was graphically highlighted by the work of the Royal Commission.

The response of all Governments to the recommendations of the Royal Commission has been very positive. But there continues to exist a need for us as a nation to regularly focus on the extent to which Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are able to exercise the basic human rights that the rest of the nation take for granted.

The creation of this office and the production of a yearly report will provide this focus. I hope that all Governments will actively co-operate in the work of the Commissioner to allow for that office to be part of the ongoing push to improve the everyday lives of the first Australians.

The Commissioner will have an opportunity to continue the work already done by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in highlighting the plight of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people over the years.

One of the often least appreciated aspects of legislation is the potential of that legislation to educate public opinion and attitudes far in excess of those who may actually be directly affected by it. In the area of human rights generally this is particularly critical. The Government has a very proud record in relation to human rights reform commencing with the Racial Discrimination Act in 1975, the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986, the recently passed Disability Discrimination Act 1992 and now these reforms. This is not to mention our work on ratifying numerous international instruments during the term of the Hawke and Keating Governments.

The legislation creates a new part to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act to establish the office of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. The Commissioner's major function is to be the preparation of a yearly report on the enjoyment and exercise of human rights by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. That report is to be tabled in the Parliament and sent to all States and Territories. It will, therefore, be a public document available to all. One of the ongoing tasks that the Commissioner will undertake as part of the production of his or her report will be to review the overall implementation by all Governments of the recommendations of the Royal Commission.

The Commissioner is to be a full member of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and will have all the powers necessary to carry out his or her functions. In particular, the Commissioner will have the power to seek and obtain information and documents from government agencies. Commonwealth, State and Territory Government agencies will be subject to this power but a State or Territory Attorney-General will be able to provide a certificate that release of the information would not be in the public interest for a number of reasons set out in the Bill. These include that release would prejudice criminal investigations, that it would show the deliberation of Cabinet or Executive Council of a State or Territory etc. Similar power already exists in the Act for the Commonwealth Attorney-General. The Commissioner is also prevented from seeking details which would identify individuals unless they consent.
The Commissioner will also have functions relating to promoting and encouraging respect for the human rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

The Commissioner is to be appointed by the Governor General for a period of up to 7 years and is able to be reappointed. The legislation requires that a person appointed must have significant experience in community life of either Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.

The Commissioner will also be required to consult with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and may consult with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and organisations as appropriate.
Workers with Family Responsibilities
I am pleased to be able to move the introduction of legislation on a matter which so deeply affects the lives and opportunities of people with family responsibilities.

Life in Australia at work and in the family has undergone profound changes over the last three decades. The expectations of the social and economic roles of men and women are broadening. This attitudinal shift is supported by increases in the participation of women in the workforce and education; a growing recognition and understanding of the value of carers of families, people with disabilities, our sick and elderly; and the ageing of our population.

The Government has recognised that the interaction between work and family responsibilities has implications for the achievement of social justice for our citizens, as well as having a critical impact on the efficiency and productivity of our economy.

In March 1990, Australia ratified International Labour Organisation Convention 156, `A Convention Concerning Equal Opportunities and Equal Treatment for Men and Women Workers: Workers with Family Responsibilities', (`ILO 156') and it came into effect in March 1991. Prior to ratification, Australia already had a number of measures in place which comply with the principles underlying ILO 156. However, our ratification of ILO 156 relies on the flexibility provided by its staged implementation process, and the Government plans to undertake further action to supplement these measures in order to ensure full compliance over time.

In March 1991, an interdepartmental committee (`IDC') was established to co-ordinate the development of the strategy chaired by the Department of Industrial Relations. The overriding principle embodied in ILO 156 is that of equal opportunity for all in employment through, where possible, the removal of discrimination on the grounds of family responsibilities. To this end, the IDC endorsed the following legislative strategy, in two stages: one for immediate implementation and the second with a view to implementation within two years. The first legislative stage is to amend the Sex Discrimination Act 1984 (`SDA') to proscribe dismissal from employment on the ground of family responsibilities. The second stage is to enter into wide ranging consultations with a view, at this point, to a further amendment to the SDA to prohibit more generally, discrimination in employment on the ground of family responsibilities.

It is this first stage which is the subject of the Bill before Parliament. This amendment seeks to give effect to Article 8 of ILO 156 which provides that family responsibilities shall not, as such, constitute a valid reason for termination of employment.
I turn now to a more detailed description of the amendments.

This amendment is intended to be narrow in its scope in that it provides protection only against discrimination on the grounds of family responsibilities which takes the form of dismissal. Family responsibilities is defined by reference to the terms of ILO 156, which applies to workers with family responsibilities in relation to their dependent children as well as for the care and support of other members of the immediate family. This definition is not intended to be exhaustive. The provisions of this Act are intended to apply to a situation in which an employee has assumed the responsibility for, and therefore could be said to have a special relationship with, any other member of his or her family with regard to their care and support.

Discrimination is defined to include less favourable treatment, that is direct discrimination. This new provision will apply only to a dismissal on the ground of the existence of family responsibilities, or of a characteristic that appertains generally or is imputed generally to persons with family responsibilities. It is not intended to cover, for example, the dismissal of an employee because the employee is unwilling to change a shift, or has a period of unauthorised leave, even though both may be due to family responsibilities.

While some members of the community may be concerned that this amendment does not go far enough, I am confident that it points the way to a much broader direction being pursued by the Government, with the assistance and views of both employers and employees. We look forward to a time when workers with family responsibilities will be able to work without being subject to discrimination and as far as it is possible, without conflict between their employment and those family responsibilities.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

I am very pleased to move the introduction of these amendments to the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act 1986. The amendments before you today arise out of an extensive review of the Act which involved consultation with all parties affected by the legislation, including employers, unions, higher educational institutions and women's organisations.

None of the proposed changes alter in any fundamental way the original intention of the Act. Contrary to the fears and concerns expressed by some people some six years ago, the Act enjoys widespread support among employer organisations, unions and the wider community.

Many employers have indicated that the Affirmative Action Act has been very useful in focusing their attention on the needs of their women employees, and that there have been positive spin-offs in efficiency generated by implementing equal opportunity policies.

The importance of affirmative action programs was highlighted in the recent Lavarch Committee Report, Half Way to Equal. The Committee was categorical in its support for affirmative action programs which it stated are "integral to greater access to career opportunities for all women". This Government wholeheartedly endorses these views and, indeed, the Bill before you forms an important part of our response to the recommendations arising from the Lavarch Report.

The review of the Act and the findings of the Lavarch inquiry came to similar conclusions about the effectiveness of affirmative action programs. Over the last six years, the Act has played a pivotal role in winning support for the principle of equal opportunity. Independent research commissioned as part of the review found overwhelming endorsement for the equal participation of women in paid employment.

However, while there are a growing number of companies with exceptional affirmative action programs, many employers have yet to move beyond the rhetoric to institute comprehensive changes in their own management and work practices.
The need for ingoing reform is clear.

While women make up 42 per cent of the paid workforce, they are often disadvantaged at work. Despite the increasing participation rate, many women are confined to a narrow range of jobs, at the bottom end of the hierarchy with far less access to training, career paths and reasonable pay. Many women work part-time to balance the double load of domestic responsibilities and paid employment. These women are often excluded from the benefits accorded to full time work. The predominance of women in low paid part time work is a key explanation for continuing pay inequity.
Although it is important for Government to provide the framework for change through legislation, real structural and attitudinal change has to occur at the level of the workplace.

That is why the Government is absolutely committed to ensuring that, over the next few years, there will be a much greater emphasis on the quality of affirmative action programs. We will be working closely with employers, unions and other interested parties to help make equal opportunity in employment a reality for all women.

We will do this, not only because the Government has a fundamental commitment to ensuring that women get a fair deal at work, but also because this approach is vital to the health of the Australian economy. More and more businesses are recognising that international competitiveness and increased productivity are dependent on valuing and utilising the talents of the whole workforce.
Outmoded personnel policies and attitudes which hold women back are against the interests of any organisation which wants to do well in today's competitive environment.

Affirmative action provides the springboard for the kind of initiatives which need to occur so that women can contribute fully to their workplace—from employer supported childcare to career break schemes to more flexible, family friendly hours of work.
Let me take a moment to contrast this Government's approach with that of the Opposition.

The Opposition has said it will abolish the Affirmative Action Agency but still keep the legislation. How can the Opposition claim to be in favour of equal opportunity and simultaneously destroy the organisation which has been set up to advise, assist and monitor employer compliance with the Affirmative Action Act?
The Opposition's policy is totally out of touch with the community. Employers have indicated their support for the Agency and want it to provide them with more assistance and advice.

The Opposition's policy to abolish the Agency is only the tip of the iceberg. The Opposition's industrial relations policy will be particularly harmful to women because they are less likely to be members of unions and are often in low skilled jobs with little bargaining power.

The Coalition's policy would remove many women from their awards and then force them on to individual employment contracts where they could face big cuts in their pay and conditions. Women could be forced to work long hours in total conflict with their family responsibilities.

In complete contrast, the Government's approach to industrial relations and the amendments to the Affirmative Action Act, recognises the importance of protecting award wages and conditions and improving the position of women workers.
COVERAGE OF VOLUNTARY BODIES, UNIONS AND GROUP TRAINING SCHEMES
The amendments to this legislation are an important part of this approach and set a new direction for the Affirmative Action Agency.

The Government has decided to retain the current threshold of 100 employees for an employer to be covered by the Act. Reducing the threshold at this stage of the legislation's life would divert resources from improving the quality of affirmative action reports.
Instead, the Agency will provide greater assistance and advice to smaller employers not covered by the Act on how to implement affirmative action programs.
However, the Bill will remove some existing anomalies in coverage by extending the coverage of the legislation to voluntary bodies, union officials and group training schemes.

The extension of the Act to voluntary bodies, mainly large private schools and charities, will be particularly important as it means that an estimated 60,000 additional employees will benefit from the Act.
AFFIRMATIVE ACTION AGENCY AS A STATUTORY BODY

The Bill changes the status of the Agency to that of a statutory authority. This proposal will give the Agency greater protection against the Opposition's intention to abolish the Agency. It also gives legal weight to the current relationship of the Agency to Government.

The Agency is already located separately from the Department of Industrial Relations (DIR), and is directly accountable to the Minister. This has allowed the Agency to develop its own identity and high profile with its client groups.
By clarifying its legal status, the Government is cementing the independence and authority of the Agency, while still maintaining accountability to the Minister and this Parliament.
DISCRETION TO VARY REPORTING REQUIREMENTS

A discretion to vary reporting requirements will be introduced in the Bill. This amendment will assist in improving the quality of affirmative action programs. It provides the Director of the Agency with the discretion to alter reporting requirements, or waive them for exceptional performers.

Such an approach requires the development of performance standards and benchmarks which can then provide the criteria for identifying those employers which have achieved best practice and exceeded expectations.

Rather than impose these standards, a Tripartite Committee will be established to develop practical and reasonable standards which are adaptable to the diverse range of organisations covered by the Act. An immediate priority will be to focus on those steps in affirmative action programs which have had low levels of compliance, especially consultation with unions and employees.
The development of standards will improve the accountability of companies for their affirmative action programs.

It will also allow the Agency to use the experience and expertise of high achieving companies for the benefit of other organisations. This will be complemented by the establishment of a program allowing employers to apply for grants to assist in developing best practice affirmative action programs.

All of these amendments are part of this Government's wider program of positive reforms which recognise that women are a permanent and vital part of the Australian workforce and that they must be assured of a fair and satisfying working life.

The Government has a proud record of achievement in improving the position of women in the workforce. We have been responsible for providing women with legal redress under the Sex Discrimination Act and have ratified International Labour Organisation Convention 156 on Workers with Family Responsibilities, which makes it an aim of national policy to balance work and family life.

The Affirmative Action Act is an essential part of this strategy because it recognises that discrimination against women is not merely an individual matter which can be addressed on a case-by-case basis, but is part of our cultural, economic and industrial heritage.

The legislation is concerned with encouraging employers to remove the limitations imposed on women in a systematic and detailed way. This Bill will make the Act more effective and allow the agency to build on the achievements it has already made, particularly in the area of the quality of companies' affirmative action programs.
FINANCIAL IMPLICATIONS
The changes introduced in the Bill will have no significant impact on Government expenditure.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSMITTER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

The Radiocommunications (Transmitter Licence Tax) Act 1983 provides for the imposition of taxes in relation to transmitter licences granted under the Radiocommunications Act 1983. The Radiocommunications (Transmitter Licence Tax) Amendment Bill 1992 provides for amendments to that Act which are consequential upon the Radiocommunications Bill 1992.
Currently, there are approximately 90 different kinds of transmitter licences which can be granted and for which tax is payable.

The amendments will provide for the amount of the tax to be determined by the Spectrum Management Agency, being established by the Radiocommunications Bill 1992, and will make any such determination a disallowable instrument. This change is part of the new licensing system being established under that Bill.
The explanatory memorandum sets out the purposes of the provisions in more detail.
I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (RECEIVER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

The Radiocommunications (Receiver Licence Tax) Act 1983 provides for the imposition of taxes in relation to receiver licences granted under the Radiocommunications Act 1983. The Radiocommunications (Receiver Licence Tax) Amendment Bill 1992 provides for amendments to that Act which are consequential upon the Radiocommunications Bill 1992.
Currently, there are a number of different kinds of receiver licences for which tax is payable.

The amendments will provide for the amount of the tax to be determined by the Spectrum Management Agency being established under the new Radiocommunications Bill 1992, and will make any such determination a disallowable instrument. This change is part of the new licensing system being established by that Bill.
The explanatory memorandum sets out the purposes of the provisions in more detail.
I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TEST PERMIT TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

The Radiocommunications (Test Permit Tax) Act 1983 provides for imposition of taxes in relation to test permits granted under the Radiocommunications Act 1983. The Radiocommunications (Test Permit Tax) Amendment Bill 1992 provides for amendments to that Act which are consequential upon the enactment of the proposed Radiocommunications Bill 1992.

Currently, a test permit can be issued by the Minister administering the Radiocommunications Act 1983. Test permits are issued to persons wishing to operate substandard devices for purposes related to research, education or demonstration. The Bill also replaces "test permit" with "permit" to avoid any suggestion that the purpose of such permits is limited to the testing of radiocommunications equipment.

The amendments will provide for the amount of the tax to be determined by the Spectrum Management Agency being established under the new Radiocommunications Bill 1992, and will make any such determination a disallowable instrument. This change is part of the new licensing system being established under that Bill.
The explanatory memorandum sets out the purposes of the provisions in more detail.
I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS TAXES COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

The Radiocommunications Taxes Collection Act 1983 provides for collection of taxes in relation to various licences, permits and certificates granted under the Radiocommunications Act 1983. The Radiocommunications Taxes Collection Amendment Bill 1992 provides for amendments to that Act which are consequential upon the enactment of the proposed Radiocommunications Bill 1992.

The major substantive change in this Bill relates to the way taxes are paid. Currently, taxes are payable on the grant of licences and permits. Under the Radiocommunications Bill 1992, apparatus licences will be able to be granted for periods of up to 5 years. This could cause difficulties for users who would have to pay 5 years of fees in advance. The amendments to the Radiocommunications Taxes Collection Act 1983 will allow users to pay in annual instalments.
The Bill also provides that taxes may be recovered as debts due to the Commonwealth.
The explanatory memorandum sets out the purposes of the provisions in more detail.
I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 9 November, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992. The schedule to this omnibus Bill contains amendments to various Acts, including the Bankruptcy Act 1966, the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981, the Family Law Act 1975, the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976, the Freedom of Information Act 1982, the Judges (Long Service Leave Payments) Act 1979, the Judges' Pensions Act 1968 and substantial amendments to the credit reporting provisions of the Privacy Act 1988.

PARA.TAB: The amendments to the Bankruptcy Act arise from the early discharge system introduced in the Bankruptcy Amendment Act 1991. Under this system, as soon as a person has become a bankrupt, the trustee must send a notice to creditors stating the trustee's opinion as to whether the bankrupt is eligible for early discharge. Under the amendments in this Bill the trustee will also be required to notify the Official Receiver as to whether the bankrupt is eligible.

The Opposition was concerned that further amendments to 31(1), paragraphs (c) and (da) would have the effect that annulments of bankruptcy and annulments in relation to compositions of creditors would not need to be heard in open court. We proposed amendments in the other place to ensure that they would and the Government accepted these amendments.

It is a matter of concern to the coalition that in his second reading speech to this Bill the Minister refers to the requirement for consequential amendments arising from the Bankruptcy Act 1991 which were `inadvertently' not made by that Act. It is surely obvious that legislation is virtually certain to be flawed when the Government refuses to devote sufficient time to debate. In many cases Bills are dealt with under a guillotine in the other place and under pressure in this place, if not under a guillotine, owing to the enormous number of Bills we are expected to plough through in the last week of every session.

Of course, this takes place because of the fact that the bulk of the Bills introduced into this place by the Government are introduced at the end of a session and not at the beginning so that we would then be able to plan some orderly consideration of these Bills. It means that the Government proposes shoddy, badly drafted legislation which we simply do not have the time to review properly. After all, that is the prime function of this place. Thus, we end up passing Bills one year and correcting their flaws the next, and then correcting the flaws in the amending legislation the following year. It would all be unnecessary if the proper time were given to it in the first place.

The Bill also makes minor amendments to the Family Law Act to allow a judge to resign a commission and accept a new one without loss of continuity. This amendment is also as a consequence of last year's mistake in the change made in the Family Law Amendment Act (No. 2) 1991, which extended the maximum retiring age for judges from 65 to 70 years. The amendment contained in this Bill will make it clear that, when the Government offers new commissions to those judges whose current terms of office are stated to end at age 65, there will be no doubt as to their continuity of office.

The Bill also inserts a new subsection 37C which provides that a principal registrar, registrar or deputy registrar must take an oath or affirmation of office before the Chief Judge or a judge of the Family Court before commencing duty. The wording of this proposed oath is somewhat interesting. It requires the person to swear or affirm that they `will well and truly serve in the office of Registrar'.

By way of contrast, the oath taken by judges of Commonwealth courts is not just an oath of office; it is one of allegiance to Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia, and her heirs and successors according to law. An oath of allegiance is also required of members of the Industrial Relations Commission and the registrars of the IRC and ACT Supreme Court.

We already know that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) would like to do away with the oath of allegiance for new citizens of this nation. Now it seems that the Government is trying to sneak a step on the road to republicanism by making the officers of the Family Court swear simply an oath of office rather than the traditional oath of loyalty.

However, this cannot change the fact that Australia is a constitutional monarchy and any oath taken ought to be in the existing prescribed form. There is in any event—irrespective of your view or mine, Mr Acting Deputy President, as to whether we ought to be a republic or a constitutional monarchy—no reason why the oath taken by registrars of a court should be different from that taken by that court's judges. I foreshadow that on behalf of the Opposition I will be moving an amendment to change the oath of registrars to the traditional oath of loyalty.

The Bill also amends the Federal Court Act of Australia 1976 to provide for an oath of office for the registrar, district registrar, deputy registrar or deputy district registrar of that court. I will be moving a similar amendment in respect of the proposed oath of office for registrars of the Federal Court so that it will include an oath of loyalty.

There are further amendments to the Federal Court of Australia Act in relation to the amendments inserted last year to allow representative actions to be brought in the Federal Court. At the time the coalition was strongly opposed to the proposed structure of class actions whereby a person's consent is not required to become a party to the action. However, a person does have the choice of opting out of the proceedings by giving written notice to the court. We argued in favour of a system of opting in, whereby anyone wishing to be a part of representative proceedings would have to consent in writing before the commencement of the proceedings.

Section 43 of the Federal Court Act allows the court to award costs in proceedings. Proposed section 43(1A) in this Bill is designed to prevent the Federal Court awarding costs against a person represented in a representative proceeding which is brought under part IVA of the Act.

There are two exceptions where a court may order costs. The first is in paragraph (a), which provides for exceptions as authorised by section 33Q and 33R, where a group member is responsible for conducting a part of the proceedings. The second is in paragraph (b), which provides for exceptions when proceedings are commenced under another Act and a provision in that Act authorises an exception.

The coalition supports the general principle that a court should not be able to award costs against a person on whose behalf a proceeding has been commenced, especially since that person could have been joined in the action without their knowledge or consent. However, we believe there is scope for abuse. For example, relatively wealthy members of a class who are considering bringing an action could deliberately choose an impecunious representative party. Then, if the action is unsuccessful and it is only the representative party which or who can be liable for costs, the defendant will not be able to recover any costs. Therefore, we believe that the court should have a discretion in exceptional circumstances to award costs against persons on whose behalf a proceeding has been commenced. Obviously this would only apply when required in the interests of justice. I will be moving an amendment to the proposed section 43(1A) to provide that, in exceptional circumstances, a court may award costs against a person on whose behalf a representative proceeding has been commenced.

The Bill also makes amendments to the credit reporting provisions of the Privacy Act 1988. The passage of the Privacy Amendment Act 1990, which introduced the regulation of the credit reference industry, was without doubt one of the most tortuous processes ever suffered in this chamber. I think I can say as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs that it was even more so for that Committee. Indeed, had it not been for the then recently introduced procedures for the referral of Bills to committees, that is in this case the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, it is difficult to imagine how it would have been passed at all. As it was, the Government, the Opposition and the Democrats together moved about 100 amendments in the committee stage of the Bill. Then, after its eventual passage in December 1990, the Government was forced to further amend the Act and delay its implementation date, which was supposed to be September 1991.

At the time of the original debate in 1990, a question was raised by Corrs Australian Solicitors, now Corrs Chambers Westgarth, about the effects of the legislation on those involved in securitisation arrangements. It was obvious that further amendments would be required to provide adequately for these complex commercial schemes. A securitisation scheme involves a mortgage, ostensibly financed by a credit provider such as a building society, actually being financed by funds invested by investors in a trust. The trust is managed by a manager who deals with credit enhancers who have a role similar to mortgage insurers in that they take the financial risk by underwriting the securitisation scheme.

Corrs Australian Solicitors pointed out that it would be detrimental to the securitisation industry if those parties behind the original credit provider were prevented from having access to credit reports. Under the provisions in this Bill, organisations involved in a securitisation arrangement will be deemed to be credit providers while they are involved in those arrangements, thereby giving them access in their own right to credit reports from credit reference agencies. Unlike other credit providers under the legislation, they will be able to disclose credit information to other members of the securitisation scheme without seeking the consent of the borrower. This recognises the commercial reality of such arrangements which could not operate effectively if each transfer between the bodies involved needed the consent of the borrower.

Another amendment to the Privacy Act, proposed paragraph 18N(bg), provides that a credit provider may disclose to a guarantor credit information relating to a borrower. The right of a guarantor to have access to credit information was another question which was much discussed at the time of the debate on the original legislation. I understand that the amendments to the Privacy Act have the support of the Privacy Commissioner.

The coalition is supporting most of the provisions contained in this Bill. I will, however, be moving amendments to provide for an oath of loyalty, not merely an oath of office, for registrars of the Family and Federal courts to put them in line with the oaths taken by the judges of those courts and also an amendment to allow a Federal Court judge to award costs against a person who is party to representative proceedings in exceptional circumstances at the court's discretion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate tonight is discussing the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992. It is an omnibus Bill proposing amendments of a minor policy nature to a number of Acts falling within the Attorney-General's portfolio. The major amendments proposed in this Bill are, firstly, to require the official receiver in bankruptcy to be included as a recipient of a trustee's notice to creditors of the bankrupt under subsection 19 (1B) of the Bankruptcy Act 1966. Under subsection 19(1B), such a notice must state whether, in the trustee's opinion, the bankrupt is eligible to apply for early discharge from bankruptcy. The purpose of this proposed amendment is to correct an oversight in the 1991 amendment to the Bankruptcy Act of not including the official receiver as a recipient of a trustee's notice. As stated by Senator McMullan in the second reading speech, this amendment will facilitate the administration of the review processes in relation to early discharge.

PARA.TAB: The second amendment I would like to advert to is the one requiring registrars and deputy registrars of the Family and Federal courts to take an oath or affirmation of office before performing delegated judicial or quasi-judicial functions. It is interesting to note that these two proposed amendments do not require the registrars or deputy registrars to swear an oath of allegiance to the monarchy although the judges of those courts are obliged to do so. From listening to the previous speaker, it would appear that the Opposition thinks that this omission is yet another attack on the monarchy. I understand that the Opposition will be moving amendments which require the registrars and deputy registrars of the Federal and Family courts to swear an oath of allegiance to Her Majesty the Queen upon taking office.

The Australian Democrats see no reason for entering into a debate on the merits or otherwise of republicanism while debating this particular Bill that is before the Senate today. The simple answer lies in the fact that the vast majority of superior courts of record in Australia do not require their registrar or deputy registrar to swear an oath of allegiance to the monarchy when taking office. Among Australian supreme courts, the ACT Supreme Court is the only one to require its registrar to take an oath or affirmation swearing allegiance to Her Majesty the Queen. From this, it is overwhelmingly clear that other superior courts of record, apart from the Federal and Family courts, do not require their registrars or deputy registrars to swear an oath of allegiance to the monarchy when taking office. The Democrats can see no reason why one should depart from this practice and make that a requirement in this Bill of the registrars and deputy registrars of the Federal and Family courts. Accordingly, the Democrats will not be supporting the Opposition amendments on this issue.

The third amendment I wish to address is the one which makes clear under the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 that, except in two circumstances, a person represented in a representative proceeding under part IVA of that Act or in a proceeding of a representative character authorised by another Act, such as the Trade Practices Act 1974, cannot be ordered to pay costs. One exception is where an individual member appears in a representative proceeding for the purpose of determining an issue that relates to his or her claim alone. The other is where a proceeding of a representative character is commenced under another Act and that Act authorises the ordering of costs. The second reading speech states:

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment reaffirms a long line of judicial authority which was said to be wrong in a recent judgment of the Supreme Court of Victoria in respect of statutory provisions in that State dealing with the power of that court to award costs.

I understand that the Opposition is concerned about this amendment because it argues that, as proposed subsection 43(1A) stands, there is the possibility that those choosing to be represented in a class action may deliberately choose an impecunious representative so that they can effectively be shielded behind that impecunious person in relation to an award for costs. The Opposition argues:
In these circumstances, if evidence is forthcoming to the court, the court should have the power nonetheless to make an order for costs which has some chance of being fulfilled.

I understand that the Opposition will be moving an amendment to cover a situation such as the one I have just outlined. However, two points need to be made. The first is that the chances of such a situation arising are very remote. Commencing a class action is very expensive and it would be highly unlikely that the representative would embark on it without making an appropriate cost sharing arrangement or obtaining indemnities from the other parties.

PARA.TAB: The second point is that the proposed amendment by the Opposition would have the practical effect of discouraging people from taking class actions because of the possibility of costs being awarded against them. This possibility sits at odds with the basic premise that class actions should encourage people to gain access to the law. On that basis, the Democrats will oppose the proposed Opposition amendment.

The fourth amendment that I wish to address relates to a range of miscellaneous amendments to the Freedom of Information Act, including an amendment to continue after the abolition of the National Companies and Securities Commission an exemption from applications under the Act for documents of the Commission that were exempt prior to that abolition. The current exemption provision in section 47 refers to documents which relate solely to the functions of the NCSC. I understand that only a relatively small number of documents fall within the terms of section 47. On this basis, the Australian Democrats accept the proposed amendment.

The next set of provisions that I wish to address relates to the mortgage securitisation industry under the Privacy Act 1988 so as to include asset-backed securitisation. The amendments will also deal with a number of problems and anomalies in the credit reporting provisions of the Privacy Act that have been brought to the Government's attention by industry representatives and the Privacy Commissioner. These include allowing credit providers to disclose credit information regulated by the Privacy Act to guarantors or would-be guarantors where the borrower has consented to the disclosure; permitting credit providers who have mortgages over the same property to share credit information where the borrower is more than 60 days in default; and allowing basic transaction information to be disclosed to a person who is authorised to operate an account that is in another person's name. These proposed amendments have the support of the Privacy Commissioner and have been prepared after consultations with interested parties. On that basis, the Australian Democrats will support them.

I also note that the Government has stated that the proposed amendments will not have any significant financial impact. As the consumer credit industry is already operating under the Privacy Act and because this Bill does not significantly require the industry to change its practices, the Government argues that there will be minimum direct cost impact on consumer credit reporting agencies and credit providers. The Democrats welcome the amendments contained in the Bill and regard the Bill as a constructive attempt to improve various pieces of legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to the second reading debate on the Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1992. The various matters which are dealt with in the Bill—there are quite a number of different areas: the Bankruptcy Act, the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act, the Family Law Act, the Federal Court of Australia Act, the Freedom of Information Act and the Judges' Pensions Act and so on—have been canvassed by myself earlier and by Senator Vanstone and Senator Spindler this evening.

PARA.TAB: The Senate has been presented with a number of matters which, in the main, are of a technical nature. There is one matter only that I want to mention more elaborately in the course of my response. It involves a most important provision that deals with the very difficult situation faced by guarantors or would-be guarantors in finding out about the credit position of those who are seeking to borrow money from some financial institution or by a person being approached to act as a guarantor and the guarantor, because of various blood ties or ties of an emotional character, not feeling able to press the point as to the very real risk or vulnerability to which he or she might be exposed. It has been put from time to time that credit providers themselves are unsure about how much information they can give to the guarantor in that situation.

I am sure that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, along with Senator Vanstone, Senator Spindler and others, have had some heartbreaking cases in your electorate offices where those who have acted as guarantors have found that, quite literally, they have been conned and put under tremendous emotional pressure. I am not simply referring to what is called in the feminist jargon `STD'—sexually transmitted debt—situations but to other situations where long term friendships have been abused, even amongst business colleagues, for the purpose of extracting a guarantor and where the guarantor or would-be guarantor, in the initial contact with the bank, has not been properly informed as to the real financial situation of the borrower and, therefore, the guarantor might have been exposed to risk and vulnerability.

The leading case that has been remarked on in many debates in this place is that of Sabby and Lyn Conn, an elderly immigrant couple who provided several guarantees and a mortgage to secure a number of business and personal loans for their son. Mr Conn was poorly educated and had little grasp of business matters and Mrs Conn had a long history of mental instability. Both were pensioners who clearly depended upon their bank manager for financial advice and guidance.

The new business was unsuccessful from the start. Despite being authorised by the son to disclose details of his accounts to his parents, the bank neglected to inform Mr and Mrs Conn of their son's poor financial state. Of course, the bank moved in and engaged in what was undoubtedly agreed at settlement to be unconscionable conduct in breach of section 52A of the Trade Practices Act. The Trade Practices Commission, on behalf of the Conns, issued legal proceedings against the bank to try to remedy this situation where these parents, in devotion to their son, had been led into a position where the bank could have disclosed the true circumstances but failed to do so.

There are several cases such as that. I believe that the Privacy Act, which is extremely well intentioned, was passed by this Parliament in order to ensure that those who provide information to credit providers do not have that information made available to a wide range of persons. You will recall, Mr Deputy President, that during the debate on that Bill concern was expressed that, when we live in a credit ridden society, as we do, where everyone is dependent on access to credit and the ability to borrow funds, all borrowers—which means all of us—are in a very vulnerable position and that when we give information to a bank or a financial institution in order for it to assess whether we should be loaned certain money or monies we can, unless protected by law, be virtually compelled to allow the financial institution to make whatever use it wishes of the credit information that we may have to give to it. That may include passing on information to insurance agents or real estate agents and so on. So the Parliament did act, but I do not believe that it ever intended to act in a way which would prevent guarantors from being made aware of the borrower's financial status.

The Bill before the Senate tonight attempts to deal with that situation by providing in very broad terms that, where a situation such as this is impending, the guarantor, with the consent of the borrower, is entitled to have the consumer credit worthiness of the borrower exposed by the financial institution to the guarantor or would-be guarantor. This follows a recommendation of the Martin committee report. The Bill takes into legislative form that recommendation. I hope that assists.

There were some matters raised by honourable senators more or less by way of foreshadowing amendments to be moved by the Opposition principally in relation to this particular Bill. I will leave my remarks until the committee stage to respond to those foreshadowed amendments. I commend the second reading to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

`I, , do solemnly and sincerely promise and declare that' (as above, omitting the words `So help me God').".

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Schedule, page 5, amendments of the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976, proposed section 18Y, omit the form of oath or affirmation of office, substitute:

PARA.TAB: "`I, , do swear that I will bear true allegiance to Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth the Second, Her Heirs and Successors according to law, that I will well and truly serve Her in the office of (Registrar, District Registrar, Deputy Registrar or Deputy District Registrar, as the case may be) of the Federal Court of Australia and that I will do right to all manner of people according to law without fear or favour, affection or ill-will, So help me God!'

SPEECH.PARA: or

PARA.TAB: `I, , do solemnly and sincerely promise and declare that' (as above, omitting the words `So help me God').".
