SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take the third amendment first, which relates to the fact that in representative proceedings, known colloquially as class actions, under the Federal Court of Australia Act the Opposition intends to create a situation where the judge may exercise a discretion, in what the Opposition terms `exceptional circumstances', to allow costs to be awarded against those who are represented before the court, not just the representative party. This was considered during the drafting of the original Bill now containing those provisions in the Federal Court of Australia Act establishing this representative proceeding. It has to be understood that the normal cost rules apply—that is, the unsuccessful party would normally be ordered to pay the party-party costs of the successful party.

PARA.TAB: Senator Vanstone raises the very good point about the problem of the impecunious representative party perhaps being deliberately selected so that if the representative action is lost the defendant does not have anybody of substance against whom to claim the costs. This was dealt with by seeing the whole context of the Federal Court of Australia Act, into which our representative action was placed. It was expressly provided in the Bill—in 33ZJC(5)—that nothing in that representative proceeding affects the operation of any law relating to security for costs. The court may make an order for security for costs on the same basis as in any other proceeding. When we look at section 56 of the Federal Court of Australia Act we find the main power to order security for costs. I will read it because that may satisfy Senator Vanstone as to why we are not accepting the proposed amendment. Section 56 provides:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)The Court or a Judge may order an applicant in a proceeding in the Court or an appellant in an appeal to the Court to give security for the payment of costs that may be awarded against him.
(2)The security shall be of such amount, and given at such time and in such manner and form, as the Court or Judge directs.
(3)The Court or a Judge may reduce or increase the amount of security ordered to be given and may vary the time at which, or manner or form in which, the security is to be given.
(4)If security, or further security, is not given in accordance with an order under this section, the Court or a Judge may order that the proceeding or appeal be dismissed.
(5)This section does not affect the operation of any provision made by or under any other Act or by the Rules of Court for or in relation to the furnishing of security.

Basically, there is adequate provision within the Act as it stands to allow for the court to satisfy itself that a defendant will be in a position to be able to recover costs if the plaintiff's case is lost. I believe that the court, by exercising that power, would be able to ensure that no defendant is left in the situation which Senator Vanstone feared.

PARA.TAB: It is also the case that the court has a power to order security for costs. The court's powers in relation to a proceeding in which no reasonable cause of action is disclosed, or that is oppressive, vexatious, frivolous or an abuse of the process of the court, are specifically preserved in the Act too. Quite simply, I believe that there is sufficient power in the Federal Court to ensure that there is no abuse of process and that the defendant in the situation envisaged by Senator Vanstone is able to recover costs.

The other amendments moved by the Opposition relate to what is proposed by way of a formal statement—to put it in neutral terminology for the moment—by registrars who have the power to exercise delegated judicial functions. What is intended by the Bill is that some indication of independence from the Executive is to be assumed by the fact that such a giving of an oath will be required. The oath that is proposed is in the form of an oath to the court. It is not an oath of allegiance such as judges take before commencing duty. A judge swears an oath to the court as well as an oath to be faithful and bear true allegiance to the Queen. The registrar will swear to well and truly serve in the office of registrar of the court and to do right by all manner of people according to law without fear of favour, affection or ill-will. It is believed that that is a sufficient and adequate formal statement of the role which ought to be recognised of registrars as they exercise their delegated judicial or quasi-judicial functions.

I believe that what is required is that registrars act fairly when performing those delegated judicial functions. The terminology which is provided for in this Bill gives a sufficient and adequate foundation to the sort of undertaking which ought to be given and which is required by the community for those exercising such powers. It is not thought that the oath of allegiance in the form suggested by the Opposition is necessary for those exercising these sorts of powers.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING SERVICES (SUBSCRIPTION TELEVISION BROADCASTING) AMENDMENT BILL 1992RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1992RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (NO.3) 1992RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSMITTER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (RECEIVER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TEST PERMIT TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS TAXES COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 12 November on motion by Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Tate)—by leave—agreed to:

That the Broadcasting Services (Subscription Television Broadcasting) Amendment Bill 1992, the Radiocommunications Bill 1992 and two related Bills and the Radiocommunications (Transmitter Licence Tax) Amendment Bill 1992 and three related Bills be taken together for their remaining stages.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of Bills that we are dealing with tonight covers a range of topics. I think it is fair to say that the Bill dealing with part 7 of the Broadcasting Services Act—that is, relating to subscription television services—is certainly the most important of those.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I would like very quickly to run through the coalition's position in relation to each of the pieces of legislation. The Radiocommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992 repeals frequency reservation certificates and temporary permits, which will no longer be required under the new radio communications licensing scheme.

The radiocommunications tax amendment Bills contain a package of amendments dealing with taxation matters. These amendments are consequential upon the Radiocommunications Bill 1992, which establishes a spectrum management agency to determine all such taxes. The determinations are disallowable instruments. We support each of those Bills. We do not regard them as contentious but as simply necessary parts of the rationalisation of spectrum management and the manner in which the issue of entitlements of access to networks should be made available.

The concept behind the Radiocommunications Act 1983 is one that has been in place for a number of years. The 1992 Bill reforms the management of the radio frequency spectrum as originally outlined in that 1983 legislation. A public inquiry was undertaken by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. As a result of the report of the Committee, the Bill aims to establish a more efficient allocation and use of the spectrum in a rapidly changing communications environment.

I think we are all aware of the rapid convergence of technology in this area and the great difficulty that regulators can have in seeking to impose boundaries which in many respects can become artificial very quickly. The challenge in many respects has been for the law to keep up with practice. Therefore, in seeking progressively to introduce a market system of spectrum management in defined spectrum bands alongside the existing administrative system, we are hopefully on the way to a more rational use of resources and a more flexible method of determining access to the spectrum.

The establishment of a spectrum management agency, as proposed in the Bill, is also a very necessary development. The radio frequency spectrum is under the control of two primary agencies. The ABA, under the Broadcasting Services Act, will continue to plan the broadcasting services bands located in parts of the AM, FM, VHF and UHF frequencies. The rest of the spectrum will come under the aegis of the Radiocommunications Act and, specifically, the spectrum management agency.

The proposal for a market-based allocation of spectrum is a step in the right direction. Reform is limited in speed and scope, both by the physical characteristics of various parts of the spectrum and the time and resources required for negotiating conversion with incumbents and planning and packaging the unencumbered spectrum to suit the market. Its introduction will occur selectively and progressively under the control of the Minister who will designate those parts of the spectrum suitable for marketplace services.

We therefore support the Bill but express some reservations as to whether the structures will provide for emerging technologies and services in the most desirable and effective manner. At this stage of the process we take the view that it certainly is a step in the right direction.

The Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992 allows for the ABC to carry corporate sponsorship and promotional material on its new international satellite services to South East Asia. We support that amendment to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act. The legislation also makes it a reasonable excuse for a journalist at an ABA hearing to refuse to answer a question or produce a document if, to do so, would disclose a confidential source of material used in a broadcasting program. We do have concerns in this area.

Certainly, it has been the practice of the common law for very many years that journalists should not be immune from disclosing the sources of their information. Indeed, it is a very necessary part of keeping the system open and honest that people are required to disclose their sources. To the extent that this makes an exception in relation to the ABA hearings, we will certainly be following it closely to ensure that there are no suggestions of abuse of process.

We concede that there may be circumstances in which it is a reasonable excuse to refuse to answer a question. But we are very concerned that, taken at its fullest, it may provide opportunities for people to avoid disclosing sources in situations where it may well be desirable in the public interest that people are held directly accountable.

The amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1991 allow agreements between carriers about interconnection to more than two carriers. They extend the protection of communications to suppliers and former suppliers, establish a telecommunications industry ombudsman and ensure that carriers retain the reserve right to install or maintain line links between distinct places. Each of those amendments is a step forward. We think these are a set of encouraging developments in terms of ensuring that we keep up to date with technological progress.

I would like to turn briefly to the Bill which effectively reintroduces pay television—the Broadcasting Services (Subscription Television Broadcasting) Amendment Bill 1992. The Bill does contain a number of key changes from the original proposed part 7. It does follow on from the report of the Senate select committee to the extent that it specifies a role for the Australian Broadcasting Commission. It adopts the recommendation of the Committee. To the extent that it mandates compressed digital technology, it does not. It also requires that 10 national channels be made available but no more until 1 July 1997.

We express our concerns about the extent to which there may be significant limitations upon competition as a result of that decision to limit pay television effectively to three licence holders for the next five years. Despite the fact that we are commencing with digital technology, it has been the view of Optus, which made an amended submission to the select committee, that one would be looking at anything from the availability of 24 to 48 channels as a result of the introduction of digital technology. In those circumstances it is an artificial limitation to provide that only 10 should be available in the short term.

We therefore regard the model as significantly flawed in limiting the choice of technology by confining licensees to carriage by Optus, making artificial distinctions between broadcast and narrowcast, concentrating on supply in the number of channels rather than on demand, and being uncompetitive by imposing severe ownership restrictions on the A licence, which is confined to new entrants, but few on the B licence for existing free to air operators, and by enabling vertical integration and risking the emergence of only one operator.

There are still some very substantial question marks over the whole concept of pay television. We are loath to hold up the process any longer, given that we have now been dithering in this area for something like 12 years. We are not in any way impressed by the suggestions made from time to time by the Minister that thousands of new jobs are just around the corner as a result of the introduction of pay television. It is more important to get it right.

But to the extent that this Bill does propose a model which may well be viable, at least in the short term, and which does not deprive us of the opportunity to make any significant amendments in due course after the next election to open up the system to much greater competitive pressures, then we take the view that it ought to proceed at this stage. We regard it as very important that we have managed to achieve a role for the ABC in the satellite delivery of pay television. We are also encouraged that the Trade Practices Commission is embedded in the Act. We would like to see that go further so that the TPC at all stages has a vital role to play not only in ensuring that there is competition between licensees but even to the extent of ensuring that there are no collusive practices between those who might jointly bid for a licence.

The use of common customer reception equipment for satellite pay television is certainly important, as are codes of practice relating to the billing, fault repair, privacy and credit management for satellite pay television. A contents standard amendment relating to R rated material on satellite pay television is also important. We will take that a step further in relation to free to air during the committee stage. So, although the current model is a fairly second best outcome, we take the view that it is better than no model at all and that it therefore ought to be allowed to proceed at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not believe this is a second best model. At this stage we believe it is about a fifth or sixth best model. We are still very unhappy with it. This has been discussed many times before in this chamber and nothing very much has changed since the last time we discussed it. The difference with this model is that the ABC has been given two channels, if it wants them, rather than the one that it had last time. All our previous objections remain. Cross-media involvement has not improved in this model. We still have the second licence holder able to come from the current free to air or any other media owners in Australia. We still do not believe that the ABC is able viably to participate in this model. Although Australian program content is set at 10 per cent, we think it is too low. We would like to see it start at 20 per cent. We still believe that exclusivity periods are necessary if we are to have a viable model in the first place.

PARA.TAB: This legislation proposes a two-licence model with the ABC tacked on. Each of the main licences has four channels and the ABC has two. The ABC is supposed to do a deal with one of the major licence holders to be carried as part of a package deal on subscription if it can. I doubt very much whether it can. Then it has to compete as a third offering to consumers. The likely make-up of the licences would be a movie channel, a sports channel, a news channel and one light entertainment channel in a four-channel package. It is expected to cost about $40 a month to subscribe, based on overseas experience.

The ABC is expected to offer a news channel and one other, probably a light entertainment channel, music channel, children's channel or a combination of all three. Most consumers are unlikely to be interested in paying extra money to replicate parts of the four-channel package that they already have, even if it would give them much better news and current affairs, which it would. Unless the ABC signs a deal with a major licence holder it will most probably be cut out of the market or be forced to underprice itself considerably. If I were the ABC, I would not even bother with this one.

The holder of licence B would be allowed to have a consortium, including current free to air broadcasters. This is one of our major problems with this Bill. The Bill provides protection for current free to air services via bans on the carriage of advertising until 1997, plus participation in the second and subsequent licences. The Bill explicitly relies on section 50 of the Trade Practices Act to control market dominance. But we note that section 50 of the Trade Practices Act did not stop newspaper or television aggregation, did not stop bank mergers, and did not stop the two major airlines squeezing out Compass.

The Democrats believe that the current media players should not be allowed to participate in pay television at least for the first couple of years and that cross-media ownership rules should apply equally to both licences A and B. After 1997 there is to be a free for all for single channel licences, as many as Optus wishes to make available, and no restrictions placed on licence holders. Current licence holders A and B, as they will be after this Bill comes into effect, can buy up what they like. There are no provisions for consumer protection during or after the ensuing bidding war or if one prices the rest out of the market.

Australian consumers and potential industry participants are entitled to express outrage about their part in this Bill. It completely ignores the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services and to a large extent disregards the findings of expensive fact finding missions undertaken by the Department and previous Ministers.

The current proposal does not ensure an adequate start-up period to allow Australian manufacturing to begin production of hardware in time to profitably meet demand. In order to meet the licensing provisions, both licence holders would be forced to begin broadcasting before there were enough Australian made dishes and decoders available. Australian manufacturers would not merely be forced to compete with foreign imports from the start; they would be disadvantaged in the marketplace because ready-made imports would already be here before they were up and running.

We also believe that the Government has failed in its attempts to set up an accessible if not a level playing field. Provisions which allow the first two licence holders to decree the technology standard to be used should oblige them to consult with Optus or Austel and be mindful of any international standard. Other transponder capacity will almost certainly be used for other communications purposes, including data transference systems, which require the use of a monitor such as a TV set or a computer screen. There is no reason why the same decoder hardware could not be used for TV and other purposes as well. An arbitrary decision by two self-interested players who are being given the opportunity to limit their future competitors will create add-on expenses for consumers in the future and will severely curtail the potential for telecommunications expansion in the next decade.

It is difficult to decide which is the most glaring area of belligerent policy making here—the lack of adequate enhancement for Australian industry participation or the level of Australian program content to be required for predominantly drama channels. The Bill imposes a 10 per cent Australian program content level despite all of the Committee witnesses, including potential bidders, saying that they thought 15 per cent or more was appropriate.

The Minister states in his speech that setting the level higher than 10 per cent would be an unnecessary financial burden. We do not believe that. One of the amendments that I will be moving in the committee stage puts it up to 20 per cent. I hope we get support from both sides, or at least one side, for that. Another of the amendments, which I have more hope for, would allow the ABA after five years to look at whether the local program content should be increased by 5 per cent or more. I think that one might have a bit of support somewhere. I hope so.

All witnesses before the Senate inquiry suggested higher levels of independent Australian production were not only attainable but also highly desirable. Not one of the potential bidders expressed the view that higher levels would amount to an unnecessary financial impost. The Democrats have moved several amendments. We hope they will redress some of the major problem that we see in this Bill.

I am very disappointed that after so long, and after so much assistance from many experts in the community as well as from the Opposition and the Democrats, the Government has offered Australian consumers and business only the personal prejudices of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this second reading debate on the general communications Bills, I want to confine my remarks to those aspects of the Broadcasting Services (Subscription Television Broadcasting) Amendment Bill 1992 which relate to the introduction of pay television in this country. Perhaps for the last time—at least the last time this year—I place on record my view that the model which has finally been arrived at by the Government, largely through imposition by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), for pay television in this country is a model in which I have little confidence. I believe it will not serve well either the Australian consumers or any section of Australian industry with an interest in the area of subscription television.

PARA.TAB: What we see in the legislation before us today is a subscription television system which is as close as one could have expected the Government to have come to Opposition policy. It is a process of open slather by which the licences to be allocated will be allocated in a market which is uncertain and into which the present media players will be able to move at the same time as a new licensee is being encouraged to come in.

Senator Bourne has referred to the great body of information and expertise that has been brought to bear on this policy area over many years. Overseas experience has shown that this is a very difficult area in which there have been commercial disasters. Those commercial disasters have impacted on household consumers.

It is fair to say that people are not marching in the streets for pay television in this country, even though pay television has been a matter of debate for inordinate hours in this chamber during the course of this year. The people out there are not overly concerned about this question. If they are, they are nonplussed about the costs involved—assuming that they can afford them—about the insecurities, and the fact that they will probably be getting more of the same. I think it is almost inevitable that once this model is put in place there will be repercussions in the market and that Australian consumers will be the losers along the way.

It is interesting that the Labor Party had a policy of not introducing pay television to this country. That policy was changed not because of marketplace demand, but because this Government needed a carrot to dangle before the nose of the potential purchasers of the millstone around the Government's neck represented by the Aussat satellite. In introducing competition to Telecom, Aussat was sold to Optus Communications. Subscription television by a satellite monopoly was the carrot: hence this legislation.

In persuading the Labor Party Caucus to lift the moratorium on pay television, several promises were made. The first was that pay television would provide an opportunity for more diverse ownership of media in this country. This is an interesting promise from a government under whose care the monopolisation of media ownership in this country has reached stunning heights. So I suppose it might have been attractive to believe that new players, or even one new player, might come into the media scene via pay television. The model we have before us today, which allows present media players in at the same time as this potential new operator, means that the odds are that, presently, the operators will be the ones who will win out in the marketplace in which this new industry will be operating.

A second carrot for the Caucus was that the introduction of pay television would give a boost to both the production industry and the manufacturing industry in this country; that this country could get into a whole new area; that we could become exporters of relevant manufactured products, particularly into the Asian region; and that there would be more product needed and therefore more Australian production. Senator Bourne has referred to the fact that this legislation allows a disappointing 10 per cent of Australian content provisions on drama channels only. That is not adequate and will certainly not provide the impetus for increased Australian production. The recommendation of the Select Committee on Subscription Television Broadcasting Services should have been followed at least in that respect.

In terms of the manufacturing industry, the Committee heard, as the public has heard often enough, from manufacturers in this country saying that, unless a viable system was put forward, they would not, and could not, be interested in tooling up for a whole new industry that they could not be certain would survive. So there is an enormous question mark over that.

The third promise was that Australian consumers would benefit—that there would be increased diversity of programming; greater access to material that the public currently does not have; and that it would enhance the culture, entertainment and general viewing of Australian consumers. The problem there is that first there are no guarantees of this—there never are; and, secondly, if we leave aside the esoteric argument about the fact that we all pay for advertising and therefore free-to-air is not really free, consumers of free-to-air television compared with subscription television consumers stand to lose quite considerably by this package.

As we can anticipate, the commercial pressures are very strong and there are risks that pay TV simply will not pay the providers. Obviously there will be pressure on this Government, the next government and succeeding governments to eat away at some of the safeguards that are in the legislation, and they are few enough, against the siphoning off of major events, major programming, to the subscription area so that free-to-air viewers—those who cannot afford $40, $50 or $60, or however many dollars a week they may have to pay to get all these programs through subscription television—will be deprived. Those who do pay will be deprived if it is not a commercially viable system.

Therefore, on all counts I think that the Caucus of the Labor Party in government has been sold a pup on this one, to say the least. It has been a surprise, and a disappointment, to me that the previously strong Caucus committee on transport and communications has not stood firmer on this throughout the whole process.

The Opposition has always wanted a system which would be open—in other words, the more the merrier, and letting the market determine what happens. As I have suggested in my remarks so far, the inevitable consequence of that—and we should have learnt the lesson from the UK, which is a much bigger market—is that in that sort of market even two players could not survive. There is also the experience in New Zealand and elsewhere around the world. So I cannot understand how we can expect to survive in this small, and at this moment quite depressed, market.

I think it is an unsatisfactory package in almost every way and I believe that it is a package that should be rejected. I guess it will go through the Parliament, however, with the support of the Opposition because, once again, as I say, we are seeing the Labor Party in government do the work of the conservative coalition parties in yet another policy area.

I just want to make a few remarks about one issue that has been raised recently in the debate surrounding broadcasting policy in this country. It will be the subject, I am sure, of more debate in the chamber this evening as amendments which are being foreshadowed around the chamber are debated. The issue concerns the classifications of material viewed on television and on pay television as well. Amendments will be moved during the committee stage and I would like to say a few words now and, hopefully, not contribute to what may be an extended committee debate, if my judgment is anything to go by.

I think we all agree with statements that have been recently made by the Prime Minister with regard to the level of violence on television and the need for the classification systems to be changed, to be unified across the various forms of video film and television material and to take more account of the depiction of violence. The various classifications need to be uniform and agreed and children, in particular, should be protected from inappropriate viewing. The Prime Minister has made these points and he has been supported in making those points by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson).

I think it is obvious, and one would agree, that they reflect the views that are widespread in the community. Senator Lees has made those remarks too in a recent debate on behalf of the Democrats, and others in this chamber have also done so. Of course, the levels of violence in viewing are unacceptable in many cases. I am sure we all want to work towards alleviating that situation. The issue of violence in the context of the family was further raised by the Prime Minister in a speech at a conference on family issues here in this building just over a week ago.

I just want to make one point tonight—that this is not something that has newly been raised. I have in the chamber with me tonight the report of the National Committee on Violence that came down in 1990 which made certain observations about violence within the family. I will read one of them now. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Victims of violence most commonly tend to fall into two broad categories: men who become engaged in altercations with other men; and women and children who suffer at the hands of men with whom they have been living.

That Committee went on to recommend a whole series of very strict regulations in the area of gun control. More recently, the National Committee on Violence Against Women in October this year released its report entitled The national strategy on violence against women. In that report, the availability of guns in the home having been identified as clearly a significant factor in violence against women, the following recommendation is made:

Continue working towards stricter, uniform firearms legislation, establishing a national register of gun owners, and banning military style, semi-automatic weapons; as well as promoting the knowledge that guns kill people rather than protect people.
Legislate against guns being allowed in domestic households.

The point I want to make is that it is good to hear political leaders expressing their concern about violence—about depiction of violence, about the effects of violence and depictions of violence on our young people—and, further, to hear them express their concerns about family life and the safety of, particularly, children in the family context.

PARA.TAB: I would be more impressed if I could see more evidence of the implementation of, certainly, the 1990 Committee report. I am conscious that the Federal Government is reliant in this area very much on cooperation at State level. I will look forward to speedy action on the recommendations that are contained in the recent report of the National Committee on Violence Against Women.

While there may be time and energy, and even emotion, expended in the debate as it goes on tonight about depictions of violence in the electronic media, it is also important to tackle in a very practical way some of the very well and quite long-identified issues which can make a marked difference to the real experience of violence, particularly in families in households in our country.

I am conscious of the presence in Australia at this time of the leader of the US gun lobby. I simply make the point in this debate that there are other practical things that we can do to reduce the incidence of violence in our community. I think the Broadcasting Services (Subscription Television Broadcasting) Amendment Bill puts forward an inadequate package and I believe this legislation should be opposed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having discussed this with the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), I seek leave to move an amendment to the second reading which was not available at the time I was speaking a short while ago.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after "That", substitute:
", but the Senate:

(1)records the fatally flawed nature of the bill and notes that, in Government, the Liberal and National Parties will move so as to ensure that a much more competitive model is established in accordance with the principles and concerns set out below;
(2)condemns the Government for:

PARA.TAB: (a)what has been a chaotic policy process in relation to this bill; and
(b)its regulatory policy for pay TV services which:
(i)contradicts the stated aim of the principal Act to readily accommodate technological change,
(ii)treats the delivery of pay TV by satellite as a special case,
(iii)creates barriers to entry by placing severe restrictions on licence A and few on licence B and by prescriptively limiting foreign investment, and
(iv)prescribes advertising on the satellite pay TV services;

SPEECH.PARA: (3)notes that the bill:

PARA.TAB: (a)does not provide an `open architecture technology';
(b)provides for the use of only 10 satellite channels until 1997, with limits on the A and B licensees to 4 channels each and on the C licensee to 2 channels;
(c)excludes the operation of the Trade Practices Act from the allocation of satellite channels prior to 1 July 1997;
(d)makes artificial distinctions between broadcast and narrowcast services;

SPEECH.PARA: (4)expresses its:

PARA.TAB: (a)concern about the possible vertical integration of satellite pay TV licences and possible monopoly control of the subscriber management system;

(b)concern about the process of setting transmission system standards specific only to satellite pay TV which may result in standards different from all future television services and standards dissimilar to the rest of the world;

(c)concern that the common reception equipment is specified only for satellite digital pay TV services when this same equipment may be capable of providing access to all future digital television services; and
(d)concern that the resulting standards may result in a high cost to the consumer.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not go through it all. I trust it has been circulated. It simply records what we regard as the flawed nature of the Bill, emphasises that we will pursue a much more competitive model in government, spells out the shortcomings of the current system and expresses concerns about a number of matters which I dealt with during the course of my contribution to the second reading debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be moving an amendment during the committee stage of the Broadcasting Services (Subscription Television Broadcasting) Amendment Bill 1992 which will restrict the broadcasting of AO programs to 9.30 p.m. and afterwards. It will make sure that the AO programs presently viewed by up to 35 per cent of children between the hours of 8.30 p.m. and 9.30 p.m. will not be available for their viewing.

PARA.TAB: In speaking to the amendment, I will give a brief history of the Opposition's policy on this matter. In 1988 I introduced a private member's Bill into this Senate. One of the clauses in that Bill sought to downgrade violence in videos and films. That Bill was defeated by the Government and the Democrats at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take a few minutes to respond to remarks made by the Queensland Treasurer, Mr De Lacy, in the Queensland Parliament last week. The Queensland Treasurer has given a detailed and lengthy speech in reply to my earlier speech on the adjournment regarding public sector superannuation in that State. I wish to place on record the appreciation for the complimentary remarks that Mr De Lacy made about the work of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. In fact, Mr De Lacy said:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know what more can be done to assure any critic that full actuarial funding of the Government's schemes is being maintained.

Perhaps Mr De Lacy could publish the 1985 actuarial report, the recent actuarial report on the police fund as well as any other independent audit report. Then he would be in a position to truly convince the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation that his Queensland superannuation schemes are fully funded.

PARA.TAB: Mr De Lacy's letter to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, following its third report, admits that fully funded superannuation does not occur and that Queensland is no different from the Commonwealth and other States that admit a superannuation liability. I seek leave of the Senate to table the letter to the Senate Select Committee from the Treasurer of Queensland.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr De Lacy's letter to the Chairman of the Committee reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In this regard, the Queensland Government's superannuation schemes are operated in the same way as the schemes operated by the Commonwealth and the other States. The component of emerging benefits which is funded by the Crown, as employer, is paid to the Superannuation Fund at the time payment is made from the Fund to the beneficiary.

In other words, there is an emerging debt, not a separate fund to cover all liabilities. Mr De Lacy should now have his Treasury officials calculate the emerging benefits that will need to be paid over the next 20 to 30 years to each of his employees and past employees who are already in receipt of retirement benefits, just as the other governments around Australia have done.

PARA.TAB: When this has occurred, and it has the stamp of an actuary and the seal of an auditor, we will have a figure of unfunded liabilities for public sector superannuation in Queensland. Mr De Lacy has also remarked that, unlike private sector employees, his State receives no taxation relief for providing superannuation schemes. That is an extraordinary statement. However, he admits that the States do not pay taxation on earnings made from investments or consolidated revenue funds, nor do they have to fully fund their defined benefits schemes.

Mr De Lacy has the temerity to question private sector superannuation schemes in his less than generous comments in the Queensland Parliament and in his letter to the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation when he says, in identical words:

SPEECH.PARA: Nor do the States, unlike the Commonwealth, have the opportunity to reduce the cost of their superannuation through social security or income tax clawbacks.

I remind Mr De Lacy that the private sector would indeed be happy to change positions. By virtue of being paid into the consolidated revenue fund, his so-called arrangements escape both the employers contribution tax and the earnings tax of other superannuation funds because the income in his case is derived from an exempt source, which is the consolidated revenue fund.

PARA.TAB: Mr De Lacy's letter is not only contradictory, but also his assertions lead thinking Australians to question his claims and, unfortunately, the professional training of his advisers that he sends on Government errands to public Federal parliamentary inquiries to convey false impressions such that his superannuation funds are fully funded schemes. I would welcome Mr De Lacy's response to each of the points that I have submitted and sustained this evening. I thank the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the comments made by my colleague Senator Watson in relation to the superannuation funds that are held by the State Government in Queensland. The cause of my concern is very simple and is as follows. When the senior officers of the Queensland Government, senior representatives of the superannuation funds and of the Queensland Investment Corporation appeared before the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, they stated categorically that the superannuation funds in Queensland, in respect of both employee and employer contributions, were fully funded.

PARA.TAB: A couple of weeks after that date, however, the Queensland Treasurer admitted in Parliament that at least the defined benefits fund available for the police force was not funded at all. Clearly we have a case of senior public servants, wittingly or unwillingly, misleading a Senate inquiry. I know that Mr De Lacy has attempted to excuse these rather frightening errors, but his explanation creates more holes than it plugs. It is, as Senator Watson says, quite contradictory. But clearly, on the basis of what Mr De Lacy told the State Parliament in Queensland, the evidence that was provided by the senior departmental officers and senior officers of the government superannuation funds in the Queensland Investment Corporation was incorrect. In other words, the Senate inquiry was, wittingly or otherwise, misled.

We now find Mr De Lacy, in his letter to the Chairman of the Committee, yet again attempting to obfuscate the problems that exist. Senator Watson has correctly pointed out that, whilst Mr De Lacy begs poor about not getting a tax benefit for contributing to the fund, the State Government in Queensland is not being obliged to pay tax on its earnings, nor on the contributions. As Senator Watson quite correctly says, many Queensland or Australian companies would gladly swap places with the Queensland Government.

My concern is, of course, that the number of public servants in Queensland is increasing at a dramatic rate. If it continues at this rate, even if the State Government funds are fully funded, there will come a time—

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you have a funding of funds?

—It is very difficult, Senator Watson; one really has to have a mind as twisted as Mr De Lacy's. If the number of public servants continues to increase at the current rate, even if the funds are fully funded at the moment—or rather that the obligations are fully funded because there is no fund—then there will come a time when the obligations are not fully funded. I believe that point in time could be very, very close if it has not already reached us. Therefore, I believe that it is absolutely important that Mr De Lacy does as Senator Watson has suggested; that is, have a full actuarial report on the State Government's obligations and whether in fact they can be met out of the consolidated fund, as Mr De Lacy has suggested.

That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the adjournment debate, I was giving the history of the reason for my amendment to the Broadcasting Services (Subscription Television Broadcasting) Amendment Bill. As I said, in 1988 I presented to the Senate a private member's Bill, one of the purposes of which was to downgrade the violence in videos and films. At that stage it became coalition policy that violence should be downgraded for the viewing public. That Bill was defeated by the Government and by the Democrats at that time.

PARA.TAB: Just a couple of months ago, in September of this year, I reintroduced a similar Bill, but that Bill was to lie on the table for public discussion. Public discussion did take place, even though it was only from September until early November, and 22,000 signatures were presented to the Parliament. I think Mr Keating then looked at the number of people who were so concerned about the amount of violence that we see, both on television and on films and videos, and he thought it would be a good idea to join the bandwagon. So Mr Keating is a Johnny-come-lately to the concern shown by the community on the amount of violence it is seeing.
A short while ago the Prime Minister made a speech to the Family Summit here in Canberra in which he made his view very clear. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are not trying to restrict what adults can watch.

He made it very clear that his view was that only children should not be watching the violence. He made his views well known because he said he went home and had to turn off the television because his young children were watching a violent AO film.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister then came up with a wonderful suggestion. I am quite sure that the media all thought that this was something new. He suggested that the category M be divided. In his speech to the Family Summit he said that M was a very broad category and it should be divided into M-plus and M-minus so that the less violent or sexually explicit sections of the M classification are divided from the more minor classifications of that grading. What he did not say was that he was picking up a recommendation made by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

We must be reminded that the M category is presently not allowed on television. Only AO is allowed on television and it is a lesser category than M. I will read the recommendation made by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal which states:

SPEECH.PARA: We propose that, for the purposes of television broadcasts of M classified material under self-regulation, broadcasters adopt a system which splits the M classification into two categories, with the milder material in the lower M range being equated to the current AO classification and thus able to be shown from 8.30, and that material in the M classification which includes stronger depictions of sex, violence or coarse language be restricted to broadcasting in an unmodified form only after 10.30.

That is exactly what the Prime Minister has suggested and he made it sound like it was something new coming from him. It did not ever come from him. It was a recommendation from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. He has literally pinched this suggestion and made it as if it came from him.

PARA.TAB: It must be clearly understood that M-rated material is not permitted on television, but the ABT is recommending that only the lower categories of the M classification should be shown on television at 8.30 and the stronger depictions should be shown only at 10.30.

There was a violent reaction from commercial television stations to the Prime Minister's suggestion that AO material be moved to 9.30 and not shown before that time. They frankly told him to go jump in the lake. They thumbed their noses at him and said they would not abide by it. We all know that self-regulation is part of the Australian decision. It was a bipartisan agreement at that stage that they should be able to self-regulate, and they have abused that self-regulation.

I believe that commercial television stations owe a responsibility to the community. It is extremely clear from the latest inquiry by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal that people have told it time and time again—and in large numbers—that they do not want as much violence on television. They have put to the ABT many times that the time slot should be pushed back further. The television stations have not accepted that. I believe their responsibility to the community is to accept it.

We know from the various surveys which have been undertaken that 35 per cent of children are still viewing at 8.30 and, if the commercial television stations believe, as they say they do, that parents should be the sole people in charge of children's viewing, then the commercial television stations are not abiding by what actually occurs in the community at the moment. As I said, up to 35 per cent of children are still viewing television at 8.30 at night. It is for these reasons that I will be moving my amendment later in the committee stage of this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The eight Bills we are debating this evening relating to broadcasting services, radiocommunications and transport and communications issues generally have some positive aspects to them. However, there are also several unsatisfactory aspects as far as the Opposition is concerned, particularly with regard to the Broadcasting Services (Subscription Television Broadcasting) Amendment Bill 1992, which is the subject of the second reading amendment moved by my colleague Senator Alston a few moments ago.

PARA.TAB: This Bill reintroduces part 7 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 which relates to pay television. As senators would be aware, at the request of the Opposition, part 7 was referred to a Senate Select Committee in late June for a detailed inquiry. During that inquiry the Committee unsuccessfully attempted to seek resolution on two key issues: firstly, the when and how of pay TV service licences being issued and, secondly, how the Australian Broadcasting Corporation would be best placed to operate within that industry.

Unanimity was achieved only in respect of the role of the ABC in subscription television and there was little agreement on anything else before that Committee. In fact, the Committee reported on the basis that analog technology, which required a restriction to only six channels, would be used for pay television in Australia. We now know that that technology has been surpassed by the digital compression technology. That is in part reflected in the Bill before us today which reflects several major changes to the original legislation.

Firstly, as I said, it mandates compressed digital technology with a standard to be agreed by licensees A and B and set by the Minister in consultation with Optus Communications. Secondly, it provides that there be 10 national channels until 1 July, after which time single channel licences may be issued, subject to the Trade Practices Act. Within that licensees A and B will provide up to four channels each and licence C is to be issued free to the ABC and SBS, individually, as part of a consortium or in strategic alliances with licensee A or licensee B to provide up to two fully commercial services.

Non-satellite licences will have no cross-media limits and will be subject to the Trade Practices Act and licensees will be free to operate their own subscriber management system, but will be required to provide fair access for other satellite licensees.

The Opposition believes that this Bill as presented this evening is fundamentally flawed. The main reason for that flaw is that it limits the options of technology by confining licensees to carriage by Optus. Further, it makes artificial distinctions between broadcast and narrowcast. The essence of the shortcomings of this legislation is that it concentrates on supply, that is, the number of channels, rather than market demand, that is, the size of the market.

Therefore, the Bill artificially limits the availability to 10 channels when, with the technology that is now to be applied, 24 channels would be quite feasible. The legislation is short on providing competition in two key areas. Firstly, it imposes strict ownership restrictions on licence A, but few on licence B. Secondly, it enables vertical consolidation and risks the emergence of one operator. Further, it restricts the diversity of programming in its interconnector arrangements by not providing for multiple program providers.

It is true that under this legislation the industry could reasonably expect significant shifts in employment, stimulating manufacturing and program production growth as well as realising some export potential. Because of those positive aspects to the legislation, we will not oppose it. However, we will, as Senator Alston has already indicated, be moving a second reading amendment and will also be moving specific amendments in the committee stage to seek a more balanced presentation of the pay television scenario, particularly with regard to advertising on pay television, the involvement of the Trade Practices Commission in the allocation of the A and B licences and the institution of modifications to the standard setting procedure.

The Liberal and National parties' preferred model for the introduction of pay television seeks to promote and support the concept, but in a much more competitive environment and with a much more competitive spirit than is offered by this legislation. The area we believe is the major shortcoming for this particular Bill is that it does not provide adequate competition with regard to pay television.

With regard to the other particular Bill to which I wish to refer this evening, the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill, there are two areas which concern the Opposition. This Bill primarily deals with the technical aspects of transport and communications and seeks to clarify diverse provisions of various Acts administered under this portfolio. We have particular concern about the provision whereby journalists will enjoy special privileges when appearing before the Australian Broadcasting Authority. It is the view of the Liberal and National parties that journalists should be treated in exactly the same manner as other individuals who may appear before any authority hearing. Therefore, we have severe reservations about that aspect of this Bill.

The other concern we have is with regard to category four of the amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1991: the rules relating to the general carriers reserved rights. The purpose of this is to ensure that carriers retain the reserve right to install or maintain line links between distinct places and to ensure that the accepted line links allowed under the Act revert to their original purpose if title passes to another person. This category four amendment is specifically detrimental to the Liberal Government of New South Wales, which has recently established its own telecommunications system for government communications.

That initiative, in its limited form which is allowed by the legislation, alone will save the New South Wales taxpayer $28m per annum over the next 10 years. Such initiatives have no right to be thwarted by this Government. In fact, the legislation as presented to this chamber seeks to prevent the New South Wales Government from further extending this worthwhile initiative which it has taken and merely seeks to reserve the right to existing carriers to keep extra revenue.

The coalition is strongly opposed to this maintenance of a duopoly until 1997 when the New South Wales Government will attain separate carrier status at any rate. We believe that there ought to be strong and open competition in telecommunications now and that this should not be delayed until 1997. The country should be working towards developing the optimum telecommunications network for its needs as we approach the twenty-first century.

The final issue I wish to raise in this debate this evening is the incorporation into this legislation of an amendment which, in the light of the High Court's decision with regard to the legislation banning TV advertising for election purposes, reinstitutes the three-day media ban for advertising prior to elections. As we know, the Government's attempts to prevent free speech in election campaigns through the legislation which it passed through this Parliament with the support of the Democrats some time ago were overturned by the High Court, quite thankfully, and so the legislation was declared null and void. Now, through the back door, late in the debate on this legislation, the Government seeks to restrict in part our capacity to free speech and to advertise effectively in election campaigns by reinstituting the old three-day blackout period, which was part of this election broadcasting and advertising legislation some time ago but had been removed from that legislation and had not applied for quite some time. We are opposed to that backdoor method of seeking to restrict the capacity for free speech and I would urge the Senate in particular to reject that part of the legislation.

Overall, we support the general passage of these Bills, subject to the reservations I have mentioned, subject to the amendment which has been moved to the second reading and subject to further amendments that the Opposition will move in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise not to speak on the technical aspects of this package of broadcasting Bills although there are some aspects which I would like to have dealt with at some length because there are some factors which I believe ought to be considered and I am not sure they have been considered fully. The time is late and I will restrict my remarks to the matters dealt with by Senator Walters. I will be supporting the amendment Senator Walters has foreshadowed. She has advanced good reasons for support of that amendment.

PARA.TAB: I am also proposing an amendment and that amendment in fact is to allow this Parliament in the end to consider the questions of program standards. That is something that this Parliament has been denied by the Broadcasting Services Act. At this time, when there is widespread public concern over TV programs which for free to air television screen unacceptable themes and depictions of violence and sexploit material, I believe my amendment is quite appropriate and timely.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), as has been indicated by Senator Walters, in his address to the Family Summit and since has expressed views that AO programs should not start until after 9.30 p.m. and that the M category should be split with only the milder versions being able to be shown on television. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has also expressed concern, as have the Australian Democrats, whose spokesperson recently pointed to the inadequacies of the legislation.

In the end, all this is whistling in the dark because, under the new Broadcasting Services Act, the Parliament has no say over codes of practice, the development of which are entrusted by the legislation to the commercial television networks. These networks have in effect thumbed their noses at the Prime Minister, declaring that they do not intend to extend the family viewing time—if that is what one can call the period up to 8.30. There are also moves, as a result of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's final recommendations, to screen after 10.30 p.m. material which, under current programming standards, cannot be screened at all. That matter has been referred to by Senator Walters.

I now return to the Prime Minister's statement. I differ slightly with one aspect of what Senator Walters has said in respect of what I understand to be the Prime Minister's view on the matter as outlined to the summit. I think it is probably more correct to say that the Prime Minister was concerned not only about dividing M into MV, that is M violence, and a lower category, but also, as he indicated in the summit:

SPEECH.PARA: In the past there have been suggestions that a special category be created just for films which depict violence.
I interpolate here that it was the recommendation of the ABT that there be an MV category. The Prime Minister has said:

While this would help to identify violent films, it would ignore the concerns of many parents in the community about coarse language, or depictions of sex or drug-use which also feature prominently in the "M" category.
I believe that there should be two levels in the present "M" category.
The first would cover the lower end of the category, would include all films and videos which contained "milder material" and would—like the present "M" category—be advisory only.

The second, which might be called MA, would be restricted rather than advisory (meaning there would be penalties for allowing children under 15 access to these films unless accompanied by an adult) and would apply to the other, more raunchy and more violent end of the spectrum.
For completeness, I will continue:

At the same time as we were making more sense of these classifications, we might want to take a look at the recommendation of the former Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for a single classification system for television and for films and videos.
The present dual system is confusing to all concerned.
He then goes on to deal with the point that was mentioned by Senator Walters, saying:
We are not trying to restrict what adults can watch.
But I do think I speak for many parents when I say we need more reliable means of knowing the contents of films and videos so we can make informed choices about what our children are subjected to.

He then goes on to say that he proposes to ask his colleagues the State premiers and the Chief Ministers to agree to list film and video classification as an agenda item at the meeting to be held in Perth on 7 December.

PARA.TAB: I can see that there are internal contradictions in some of those statements. One can give the Prime Minister the benefit of the doubt when he says that only material that is contained in the milder version of M should be screened over television. He said that the MA category, which includes the violent and `sexploit' material, should be:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . . restricted rather than advisory (meaning there would be penalties for allowing children under 15 access to these films unless accompanied by an adult).

I presume he means that that material is not suitable for television. Time will tell whether that is what is being said. We should be very careful about anything the Deputy Chairman of the Film Censorship Board, Mr David Haines, might have to say on this matter, because of the views he holds.

PARA.TAB: The amendment I will be moving will ensure that the Parliament is able to act in the interests of the public and the electors. I will be indicating to the Committee at that stage that the amendment is couched in careful terms so as to essentially preserve the requirements for the development of codes of practice by the industry and for the development of certain standards by the ABA.

I believe that my amendment will not really interfere with the general thrust of the legislation. Indeed, the codes of practice will not automatically be considered by the Parliament. For any of those codes of practice to be overturned would require each House of the Parliament to arrive at a common decision, which clearly would not occur unless the matters were of grave public concern.

I believe that what I am foreshadowing would also give to the Prime Minister an effective fall-back position if the television networks continue in word and in practice to ignore views expressed by him and other senior members of the Parliament about this issue. That is what has happened. Since the Prime Minister's address to the family summit, there has been no abatement at all in the showing of violent and `sexploit' material at 8.30 p.m.

Indeed, on Sunday last week, Death Wish started at 8.30 p.m. I have a letter from a retired, very senior broadcaster indicating that that film was violent, with at least a dozen gun and knife killings and full effects of gore and splashing blood. On Monday last week at 8.30 p.m., Hot Spot was shown on Channel 9. As this broadcaster describes it, apart from the usual gun violence and no-holds-barred bedroom sex, there was explicit cunnilingus and fellatio.

On Friday last week at 8.30 p.m., In Bed With Madonna was screened. This was described by the film reviewer of the guide in the Sydney Morning Herald, Doug Anderson, as a cavalcade of masturbation. Bachelor Party was screened at 8.30 p.m. on Saturday last. All these films have been screened since the Prime Minister made this declaration. The same reviewer in the Sydney Morning Herald described Bachelor Party as a farce of exceptional crudity and destructive stupidity which teeters on the brink of pornography.

Clearly, the television channels are thumbing their noses at the Prime Minister. They could not care less about what he says. They are trying to patch him up. They are trying to say, `Yes, we will show all the details of what is contained in this material so that parents can make a judgment', ignoring the fact that there are many single parent families and that the pressures of household and work for many mothers and fathers are such in this day and age that it is virtually impossible to control at all times what children see on television. The daddy of them all was when FACTS said that the problem with having AO films commence at 9.30 p.m. is that the adults will have to go to bed at 11 o'clock or 11.30 p.m. Would you believe it!

I have not seen in the objectives of the Broadcasting Services Act a requirement that priority be given by broadcasters in their programming to the time when adults go to bed. But I do see in the broadcasting services legislation an amendment which was carried by this Parliament requiring that the television stations must give a high priority to the protection of children from material that is likely to harm them. That is what I see there. What some television stations are doing now is quite contrary to that provision.

I applaud what the Prime Minister has done; I applaud his statements and his concern. But I believe that we need to have something behind our back—some weapon—to use if some television stations continue to determine their programming standards in accordance with their view of how to make a fast buck.

I will not proceed to make a further explanation of the amendment because I think I might be out of order. I shall leave that and hopefully will not need to canvass it in great detail in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. We have a number of serious concerns about technical deficiencies in Senator Walters's amendment. The amendment does not apply to ABC/SBS programming. It does not address the situation in Queensland during daylight saving where programs shown in New South Wales or Victoria at 9.30 p.m. will appear at 8.30 p.m. in Queensland or involve broadcasters in substantial—and I mean substantial—expense in purchasing time-shifting equipment at the cost of millions of dollars.

PARA.TAB: The AO definition relies on value judgments by broadcasters, especially with reference to paragraph (d) of Senator Walters's amendment. Only a classification scheme will offer broadcasters certainty for otherwise unclassified material. The amendment does not restrict M or R material being transmitted before 9.30 p.m., which leaves the peculiar situation of those more restricted categories being governed by standards which may be replaced by codes of practice, while the less pernicious AO is legislated for. I understand that the Democrats have their own concerns about the technical deficiencies in this amendment which they will canvass themselves.

However, I am in the fortunate position of advising the Senate that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has succeeded in his negotiations with the television industry in producing a proposal which I hope every senator would support. It is certainly the most sensible proposition in terms of classification that I have seen for some time, and the Prime Minister is to be congratulated on getting this agreement, perhaps reluctantly. Perhaps it is too strong to say that it is an agreement, but it will bring the Government to a position where we will take the appropriate action to produce this result.

I foreshadow a motion that I will be moving at the end of the second reading debate so that I can formally incorporate in Hansard the commitments the Government will be making to establish the bona fides that we want to provide in this debate. It is a proposal which I think is years overdue. It provides something which I know the censor has wanted to do for years. I go back to my time on the classifications committee in terms of the concerns that everyone has expressed about the totally unsatisfactory broadness of the M classification.

Senator Walters referred earlier to the television channels thumbing their noses at the Prime Minister. I thank Senator Harradine for his positive comments about the Prime Minister's role because I think it has produced a commendable result. If they have thumbed their noses, it does not seem to have done them any good.
I will read into Hansard the terms of the motion which I will formally move at the end of this debate. The motion has been circulated in the following terms:
At the end of the motion, add: "and that the Senate note that:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.The Government will establish a common film classification system to operate across the mediums of film, video, and television;
2.The classifications will be set by the Office of Film and Literature Classification and product will bear its classification across all mediums;
3.The classifications will be G, PG, M, MA and R;
4.Product will be modified for television where necessary and will be broadcast as G, PG, M, MA, but not R;
5.The M and MA categories will replace the wide and indiscriminate AO currently used for television;
6.The time-slots for telecast of film on free-to-air television will be 8.30pm for M category product and 9.00pm for MA category;

7.The Australian Broadcasting Authority will be the relevant authority for monitoring the utilisation of the new classification system and ensuring that television stations suitably modify material for broadcast within the appropriate codes under the self-regulatory framework;
8.Product labelling and publicising of classifications will be implemented by television stations;

9.The new system will mean for the first time AO type film will be more appropriately classified and that the 8.30pm time-slot will see softer material telecast than that presently undertaken within the current classification system; and
10.The Government will legislate for the above arrangements as appropriate.

I indicate to the Senate that this proposal was only just thrashed out by the Prime Minister this evening. It would be inappropriate to try to draft the legislation, if legislation is necessary, in that time, and I do not think any senator would want us to do it. I will certainly give the Senate a commitment that whatever action the Government needs to take in relation to this proposal will be taken before the end of this parliamentary year.

PARA.TAB: I just indicate why I believe this proposal that has been thrashed out by the Prime Minister is not only welcome but also very rational and reasonable. The M classification has for years been a source of irritation to many people and is often commented on. There is no need for me to go to great length tonight as to why it is unsatisfactory, but I will give an indication of how unsatisfactory this broad classification is. Films that are currently rated as M include Batman; Crocodile Dundee; Steel Magnolias—a wonderful movie; Rain Man; Don's Party; and Chevy Chase's Funny Farm. But the M classification also contains movies such as Kick Boxer, a very violent movie; Full Metal Jacket, also a very violent movie; and Silence of the Lambs, an extremely violent movie, but in my view a superb movie which I am certainly glad I watched and would be happy to watch again, being an Anthony Hopkins fan.

Honourable senators will understand from that short list that I have read out that review of that M classification is long overdue. I think it would receive general support across the industry and in the community if the classification were to be split into far more appropriate classifications and provide a reasonable opportunity for those movies to be viewed.

The industry has also indicated that it intends to publish far more detailed information about what is going to air than it currently does. There is no question at all, and I think most people would agree, that the crude classification of AO is far too crude and broad, and encompasses far too wide a range of material. Simply being shifted a full hour from 8.30 to 9.30 cannot be done without severe financial implications for the networks. I do not want what I say to be misunderstood. I am not suggesting that the networks need to be pandered to. Clearly this proposal does not do that, but it has to be laid on the table that a full hour shift in the current AO classification, which is as broad as I have just indicated, cannot be done without severe financial repercussions on the networks, which are not in a very robust financial situation currently. They cannot move their feature movie back a full hour without making virtually redundant some other programs, from which they get advertising revenue, because most people generally leave television—even the late nighters—at about 11.30 p.m. and go to bed to get ready for the next day—

TALK.START.PARA: —A sensible thing for us to do.

—Indeed. That is why I am saying that this is not only a rational but a sensible proposal, years overdue, in my view, and provides a number of much needed reforms in a common classification system across all media; that is, video, cinema and television, and a complete reorganisation of the M category. I simply conclude by saying that the Government will be, for reasons which I do not want to go into, opposing the second reading amendment that Senator Alston has moved. We do not support open slather on advertising for pay television. We do not support propositions such as an open slather on the number of channels that can be available, and so on. For all of those reasons, and to save the Senate's time, I simply indicate that the Government will be opposing Senator Alston's second reading amendment, but will be formally moving the amendment as circulated and outlined by me during the second reading. I will not speak to that amendment a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to say a couple of things about this amendment. It really does not give us much to go on. PARA.TAB: This is what I said before in commending the Prime Minister. I think that there are smarties around the place who have got into this and who are dollying this up behind the scenes. SPEECH.PARA: We propose that, for the purposes of television broadcasts of M classified material under self-regulation, broadcasters adopt a system which splits the M classification into two categories, with milder material in the lower M range being equated to the current AO classification and thus able to be shown from 8.30 p.m., and material in the M classification, which includes stronger depictions of sex, violence or coarse language, being restricted to broadcasting in an unmodified form only after 10.30 p.m. This arrangement would be an interim one until such time as changes were made to the OFLC standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—I will come to that.
—I can give you that assurance, but I can't speak again.

—I am happy to give the Minister leave because I would love to be assured of that; I would be very grateful to be assured of that. TALK.START.PARA: —I say by way of response that obviously we have had only a very short time to absorb the amendment. PARA.TAB: Until we know precisely what will be constituted by M and MA, we cannot gauge the effectiveness of this new approach. TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats think that the Government's amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time is an excellent move. We look forward to seeing the details, when the Minister brings them in, within the next couple of sitting days. It is about time there was a common film classification system for film, video and television. We look forward to this amendment coming in under the transport and communications legislation in the next couple of days.

—I have no problems at all with there being a general classification for films, television and videos. But there are so many questions to be asked. Is the classification of G to be altered? —Yes it is; Batman and Crocodile Dundee.

—I do not expect the Minister to understand the matter to the absolute detail that a committee that I and other senators have been sitting on for a couple of years understood it.
