As I said earlier, television stations have required, in their recommendation to the ABT, that for the purpose of television broadcasts of M classified material—M classified material is not permitted on television—M now be permitted on television for the first time. They recommend that broadcasters adopt a system under self-regulation which splits M classified material.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has picked up their recommendation for a system which splits the M classification into two categories, with the milder material in the lower M range being equated to the current AO classification, in order to allow M on television for the first time—not the Batman film that Senator Collins is referring to, but the uncut versions that are now not classified as AO.

The lower range of the M classification is now allowed in AO. This results in AO becoming more violent. It also results in AO being shown at 8.30 p.m. The proposition is that the more violent material be shown at 8.30 p.m. The material in the M classification, which includes stronger depictions of sex, violence or coarse language, will be restricted to broadcast in an unmodified form only after 10.30p.m.

The commercial stations must be laughing their heads off. They have done this deal with the Prime Minister because he did not understand the detail of the proposal. I am not being critical of the Prime Minister not understanding the detail; he cannot be expected to understand the detail. The television stations must be laughing their heads off. If the Minister's amendment is agreed to they will be able to show the M classification on television.

I am sure the Democrats do not want that to occur. That is exactly what would occur if MA was allowed to be shown on television. The Prime Minister has done a deal that allows MA to be shown at 9 o'clock. The recommendation of the Broadcasting Tribunal was that the stronger side of M should not be allowed on television at 9 o'clock but instead at 10.30 p.m. The television stations are laughing their heads off because the Government has been taken for a ride. The Prime Minister cannot possibly be expected to understand all the details of the classifications because he has not got the time to do that sort of work; he has, therefore, been taken for a ride.

The television stations have not been dragged into this agreement screaming. They are delighted and tickled pink that they have done a deal with the Prime Minister far better than they wanted. Their recommendation was that the stronger side of M be on at 10.30 p.m. The Prime Minister has given way to a 9 o'clock viewing of stronger MA; that is absolutely unbelievable.

Is M going to be altered altogether, or is it going to be divided up? That is the basic question concerning the Minister's recommendation. Is G going to be the same? Is PG going to be the same? Is M going to be the same, but divided up into the stronger and less strong? Is R going to be the same? If the Government is going to reclassify all programs, then that is going to take a long time. If the Government is not going to classify all programs, then just dividing M into the two different categories allows the commercial stations to get the violent pictures that they are presently not allowed to show on television, but which is their desire to show.

If the Prime Minister has fallen for that, then no wonder the television stations have agreed with his proposal. All they have done is go to him. I do not expect his advisers to understand the classification because it is very detailed. They have been laughing all the way because he has agreed to something which is completely opposed to what he first initiated. He said AO, the most violent material that can be shown on television today, should be put back to 9.30 p.m. If we agree to what the Minister is suggesting we will allow more violent material to be shown at 9 o'clock, not at 9.30 p.m. as the Prime Minister said for AO.

I will be most interested to hear what the Minister has to say in that regard. I do not think the Prime Minister really wanted to be diddled by the commercial television stations. If his advisers have not warned him that that is exactly what has happened then their skins will be up for grabs.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —From what I have just heard, it is the intention of the Senate—and I am not entirely unhappy about this—to adjourn after the second reading is completed. I seek leave of the Senate to make a short statement addressing the concerns that have been raised by Senator Walters and Senator Harradine.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, the one thing I do know, having spent some time on a classification committee with Senator Walters—and that committee was an experience which I still rate as being the worst parliamentary experience I have ever had in 15 years in this business—
—I have been insulted by experts and you're no expert!
—Why does Senator Walters not let me finish?
—You're no expert.

—Why does Senator Walters not let me finish? It is an experience which I do not attribute to Senator Walters but I attribute it to the nature of the committee, which is what I was about to say before Senator Walters jumped in. Might I just elaborate slightly by saying that it did not assist my enjoyment of that committee to trek all the way down to Canberra from Darwin especially for committee meetings and have the Chairman storm out of the room in a tantrum, then have the committee meetings adjourned for want of a quorum and a chairman, then have to get back on the plane, having taken three days to complete the exercise, and go back to Darwin without ever having had a meeting.The reason I say that is that the passions are aroused by this debate. The debate and the negotiation on this matter has moved on since the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) spoke at the forum to which Senator Harradine has referred.

PARA.TAB: I point out that the motion only calls on the Senate to note this proposal for the reason that we do need to provide the precision that is being sought. We will have to consult with the classification authorities who, frankly, I think are more appropriate for setting these matters than we are by doing it off the top of our heads. But I assure Senator Walters, from personal experience, that the networks are not happy about this proposal at all; they are, in fact, extremely unhappy about this proposal because—and I can state this as a matter of Government policy—the Government will not allow, under any classification, no matter how this is divided up, any material to be broadcast—
Senator Walters interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Will Senator Walters let me finish? It will not allow any material to be broadcast on free to air television which is currently not broadcast on free to air. Senator Harradine has sought that assurance from me, and I give it to him.

PARA.TAB: I want to restate—and I make no bones about restating it—that it is very easy for us to sit in here totally remote and cut off from the commercial world of running a service which most Australians do want to continue. Most Australians like having three commercial television channels and do not want to see any of them collapse because the channels cannot afford to run themselves. They are in a delicate state of health at the moment—and that is not exactly a State secret. Senator Alston talked about the impact that the Opposition amendment had on the debate and why the debate carried on tonight, or why the negotiations with the Prime Minister carried on. The Opposition's amendment had nothing whatever to do with that process. The dynamic of that process was finding—and I am pleased to say a number of senators who have criticised this see these as positive elements—a rational system of classification but at the same time preserving the commercial base of the operations. We do not want to see any of those TV services collapse because, frankly, I do not think the majority of Australians, as concerned as we all are about the question of violence and classifications, want any lesser choice in our television viewing than we have at the moment.

It is very easy for senators to sit in here and pass laws that have profound commercial implications for the broadcasters. Fortunately, the Prime Minister is a little more responsible than that and wants to see a change in the regime. He wants a clearer classification system and some modification consistent with the evidence that is available in terms of what is put to air, but at the same time he does not want to cause television networks to go broke.

The only person who has raised that question during this debate in here has been me. It is very easy for senators to come in here and say, `Let's put all AO on at 10.30 at night'. I point out that we cannot make those kinds of radical shifts in programming on television networks without profound negative commercial implications for the networks concerned. The end result of that will be less choice for Australians in what they view because the networks will not be able to sustain all of the commercial operations. Tonight Live with Steve Vizard is a classic example of late night viewing. It will be an unsaleable program because programs like that will have to be put to air so late that the viewing audience will be so small that one will not be able to sell the level of advertising for those programs that one can now. The majority of the audience will be in bed if the main feature movie cannot start until 10.30 at night.

These are matters for negotiation and reasonable outcomes. With respect, I think that is what we have here. But the detail does have to be provided. I thank honourable senators for the support that they have given for this proposal. Having spent six hours with Senator Walters in Estimates committees debating why the ABC broadcast the Riddle of the Dead Sea Scrolls on Palm Sunday, we are not likely to produce a result on this matter that will satisfy Senator Walters, but it may satisfy the more reasonable people in this chamber.

I say to Senator Harradine again, because it is an important point and I give the assurance for a second time, that these classifications are an arrangement that will provide a staggered time for viewing. But it will not be the intention of the Government to allow any material that is currently not permitted to be broadcast on television to be broadcast.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister respond to my question? He responded to most of it, but he did not respond to my question.
—We will have the committee stage tomorrow.
—Yes, I understand that, but could the Minister respond to the question that I particularly raised regarding whether the classifications are staying as they are at present with M just being divided?

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the hopeful consequences of the end of the Cold War and the winding back of the vertical proliferation of the nuclear arms race was the possibility that at last there would be an end to nuclear testing, and the nuclear weapons states would sign a comprehensive test ban treaty. The world was encouraged by a French nuclear test ban moratorium in the Pacific this year, as well as a Russian moratorium, but until recently, the United States, the United Kingdom and China would not follow this initiative.

PARA.TAB: Now it appears that the US Congress has at last forced the hand of the outgoing United States President, George Bush, and from last month the United States began a nine-month moratorium on testing. This is good news. This moratorium will be followed by limited safety testing for three years and a total ban is to be imposed in 1996. With the arrival of a new President in the White House, it is possible that this timetable may be speeded up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I suggest that the senator might like to incorporate her speech in Hansard so that everyone can get home a little earlier.
—I am sure the honourable senator cannot do that because she cannot be reading her speech; it must just be notes.

—I am afraid that my notes would not be decipherable in the form of a speech that could be incorporated. The Russian President, Boris Yeltsin, has been under pressure from his military to resume nuclear testing, especially when it seemed that President Bush would veto any resolution from Congress to call a halt to nuclear testing. However, Congress has managed to get around the President's threatened veto and so Mr Yeltsin also has been able to resist his military pressure and extend the Russian moratorium. Now we await news from London and Beijing to see whether they too will join the moratorium and commit themselves to a total nuclear test ban treaty.

PARA.TAB: We are, therefore, nearing a very significant and vital point in the history of nuclear disarmament. It is worth recalling the long haul of the peace movement to achieve a comprehensive nuclear test ban. Initially, in 1963, the peace movement had a failure in the sense that a partial test ban treaty was signed after the military managed to block a comprehensive ban on nuclear weapons testing. Although France and China ignored the partial test ban treaty and continued atmospheric testings after 1963, there were some successful results with the other three nuclear weapons states switching to underground testing. An unfortunate consequence was that the demand for nuclear disarmament eased somewhat as the dangers of radioactive fallout receded from the public mind.

Following worldwide protests in the early 1970s, spearheaded by peace organisations such as Greenpeace and Campaign Atom in the South Pacific, as well as the support of the Labor governments here in Australia and New Zealand, the French moved their tests underground after 1974 and China opted to go underground as well. As the second wave of the peace movement got under way after December 1979, the demand for a comprehensive test ban treaty came back onto the international agenda. It was the Labor Government that was elected here in 1983 that made it a major plank of its foreign policy, and the six-nation initiative gave further momentum to this demand.

Unfortunately, this demand encountered a hostile and intransigent administration in Washington, first under Ronald Reagan and then under his successor, George Bush. When it became almost counterproductive to raise the issue with the Reagan Administration, the Australian Government switched its energy to a chemical weapons ban, although it continued to lobby for a comprehensive test ban treaty.

I ask: why was there such opposition to a comprehensive test ban treaty, and why has the world had to wait for 30 years for one to come? Initially, the push for nuclear testing arose from a desire to test, develop and refine new weapons after the first test in New Mexico in July 1945. Each nuclear weapons state built up highly specialised teams to design new generations of nuclear weapons, and we are now up to the fourth generation. There are a number of books in the Parliamentary Library documenting these developments and covering all five of the nuclear weapons states. That number becomes six if we include India, which tested one nuclear weapon in 1974.

Much of the opposition to this comprehensive test ban came from the United States, where the role of the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory in California has been decisive in persuading each successive administration in Washington to oppose the idea. There have been a number of articles on how this was achieved, not least those published in the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientist.

Not surprisingly, one of the key figures in this total opposition is the man who provided the model for Dr Strangelove, Dr Edward Teller, also known as the father of the hydrogen bomb and the man who sold Star Wars to Ronald Reagan. This intransigence, pushed along by the military and the weapons makers themselves, has been caused by what Sir Solly Zuckerman referred to as the technological imperative. Incidentally, Sir Solly Zuckerman was the British Government's chief scientific adviser for 25 years.

The technological imperative fuels the arms race, he argued, because it has to go on justifying its own existence. Teams research and design new weapons, and then have to invent new and better ones in order to keep ahead of the enemy, who is also being pushed along by the same forces in the military-industrial-scientific vicious circle. That is why we are now up to the fourth generation of nuclear weapons being designed for the weapons of star wars, the strategic defence initiative, now known as `brilliant pebbles' or by its latest acronym, G-PALS.

If a weapons team is dissolved it could take up to 20 years to build up again, so it has to be kept busy doing something. Sir Solly Zuckerman, later Lord Zuckerman, argued it was this momentum, the technological imperative, which was the main driving force behind the nuclear arms race. This is precisely why it is so important at this point in history to have a comprehensive nuclear test ban. We may have lost enemies, but we have not lost this drive to keep up the arms race based on the technological imperative.

With regard to the survival of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, it is very important that we continue pressure for its renewal in 1995. The original agreement was based on the commitment of the nuclear weapons states to achieve a comprehensive test ban and to move towards disarmament. The end is in sight.

Earlier this year things looked rather gloomy. The French had drilled another hole at Mururoa to start testing again in May 1993. In May this year the Chinese tested one of their largest nuclear weapons—one well over the threshold agreed on by the United Nations and the Soviet Union in 1974—at Lop Nor. President Yeltsin was under pressure from his generals to start testing, although a people's movement had finally put an end to tests at the Semipalatinsk site, leaving only the site off the north coast of Siberia on Navaya Zemalya.

The British Government's position was that it tested only once a year anyway and that it intended to continue in order to maintain `the effectiveness and safety of our deterrent', although there was no suggestion of who it was trying to deter in these days. Finally, I feel I must put on record the continued and courageous opposition of the Western Shoshone nation in Nevada, which has been active over many years in trying to put a stop to nuclear testing on its ancestral lands in the south-west of the United States.

These activists must be congratulated for the moratorium that has been achieved. Many other activists have supported them in their struggle, including a number from Australia, amongst whom was my predecessor, Senator Vallentine. Greenpeace, Campaign Atom, PND and people's movements and governments throughout have all contributed.

Now, hopefully, the end is in sight, although we must continue to try to stop any further tests by any nation until a comprehensive test ban is signed. Disarmament is a step by step process, but if we can put a stop to that technological imperative at this level now, it will rank as a major achievement in the movement towards nuclear disarmament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 10 August l992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the current procedure adopted by the department in relation to the return to their homeland of Indonesian fishermen caught illegally fishing in Australian waters.
(2) What were the total costs involved in these forced repatriation for the years: (a) l989-90; (b) l990-91; and (c) l991-92.
(3) What was the total number of Indonesian fishermen so repatriated for the years: (a) l989-90; (b) l990-91; and (c) l991-92.
(4) Do departmental staff accompany Indonesian fishermen being returned to their homeland; if so, what is the standard of ratio of staff to fishermen.
(5) Is it true that ten Government officials recently accompanied 17 Indonesian fishermen being returned to Indonesia; if so, what was the total cost of this exercise.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Procedures for repatriating illegal Indonesian fishermen vary slightly between States as a result of differences in the numbers apprehended, and different State and Territory prosecution policies. In general, such fishermen are repatriated to the nearest port in Indonesia as soon as possible after fisheries authorities have completed their investigation of contraventions of fisheries legislation, and any sentences that may have been imposed following conviction.

In Western Australia, both masters and crew are normally prosecuted and if convicted, serve custodial sentences at Broome. When available to travel, fishermen are transferred by scheduled bus to Port Hedland and placed aboard a commercial flight to Denpasar. Both bus and aircraft may be chartered if the numbers are sufficient to make this more economical.

In Queensland, generally only the masters of vessels (and not crew members) are prosecuted for contraventions of fisheries legislation, and may serve custodial sentences. On release from gaol in the Cairns/Townsville region, the masters are placed on commercial flights to Kupang or Denpasar.

Crew members are transferred by ferry and bus from Thursday Island to the nearest airport at Horn Island, and are then repatriated by charter flights to Merauke in Irian Jaya. These repatriations are usually accompanied by an officer of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (DILGEA), and one Queensland Police officer per aircraft. Spare seats are sometimes offered to other government organisations based on Thursday Island that have a role in dealing with illegal fishing issues.

In the Northern Territory, masters of vessels only are prosecuted, and are generally fined and not imprisoned. The master and crew remain in Darwin until legal proceedings have been finalised. The fishermen are then placed on a commercial flight, usually to Kupang.
In all States/Territories, where the court orders vessels to be confiscated, fisheries authorities arrange for the vessels to be destroyed.
(2) & (3) The tables below indicate, for the past three financial years, the number and cost to DILGEA of repatriations of illegal Indonesian fishermen.

(4) There is no standard procedure or ratio for DILGEA staff accompanying fishermen being repatriated. As indicated in response to question 1, repatriations in Western Australia and the Northern Territory are not accompanied by DILGEA staff. In Queensland, an escort of one Police officer per aircraft, and one DILGEA officer accompany each trip. With commercial flights, and the larger charter aircraft as used in Western Australia, the carrier determines whether or not security arrangements are necessary. In view of the light aircraft used in the Torres Strait, which carry no cabin crew, DILGEA considers it necessary to provide escorts for repatriations.
(5) A group of 18 illegal Indonesian fishermen was repatriated to Merauke, Indonesia, on 19 July l992, accompanied by seven officials and three private pilots. The officials were:

ANSWER.PARA: one Queensland Boating and Fisheries Patrol official

PARA.TAB: Two aircraft were used for the repatriation. The largest aircraft available for charter at the time had 19 seats. As it was considered unacceptable to have only one police escort for 18 people, a second 9-seater aircraft was chartered.

The cost of chartering the aircraft for the round trip was approximately $3000 for the 19-seater and $1500 for the 9-seater. As these costs remained the same regardless of the number of people travelling, the Customs, Quarantine and Queensland Fisheries officials were invited, in the interest of fostering a closer relationship between various enforcement agencies working together in the Torres Strait, and to acquaint them with Indonesian officials and their procedures. Three seats remained vacant.

It is understood that the Customs and Quarantine officers were not to be paid salary or overtime. It is not known whether the Queensland Fisheries officer was to be paid. While the Department has not yet finalised payments for this exercise, the estimated cost to DILGEA of this repatriation would be $4500. Any variation would be minimal. The cost would not have been affected by the additional officials travelling.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 18 August 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that 1993 has been designated by the United Nations as International Year of Indigenous People, with an official launch scheduled in New York on 10 December 1992.
(2) What activities have been planned to mark this year which focuses on human rights and social justice for all indigenous people.
(3) Has a departmental officer been nominated to work with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in planning and coordinating activities for International Year of Indigenous People.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) is the coordinating agency in Australia for the International Year for the World's Indigenous Peoples (IYWIP) and for the Year's activities.
The Department of Health, Housing and Community Services is working with ATSIC to develop program activities that support the objectives of the IYWIP.

The Department already has a number of programs with elements that address the needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. Program Managers have been asked, within existing resources, to identify ways in which their program activities can be focused on issues of concern to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in 1993 to give an even greater weight to the Year.

In consultation with ATSIC it is also proposed that a specific project will be undertaken in the context of the International Year of the Family (IYF) 1994 which will be oriented towards the International Year of Indigenous People in 1993. This project will address the special needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander families.

The development of a communications strategy is proposed by the Department with the aim of improving the knowledge of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander families of the services available to them under the Health, Housing and Community Services portfolio.

(3) An Aboriginal officer of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services has been designated to work closely with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in planning and coordinating departmental activities for the IYWIP.
The Department also plans to recruit an Aboriginal Media Liaison Officer. It is planned for this officer to focus a proportion of their time on IYWIP related activities.

(2) Have any similar grants been made for 1992-93; if so, in each case: (a) what is the name of the trade union or community group which received the funds; (b) what was the amount of the grant; (c) what was the purpose of the grant; (d) under what program was the grant made; and (e) was any contribution made by the trade union or community group towards the project and what amounts were involved.

PARA.TAB: 1 (a) Grants have been made to Office of Labour Market Adjustment (OLMA) Regional Committees in 1991/92 and more are planned for 1992/93.
(b) Grants range from $10,000 to $50,000, depending upon the size of the labour market and the extent of the structural change affecting the local labour market.
(c) Grants may be used to fund:
strategies which increase the capacity of a local community to respond to structural change, including the establishment and support of regional employment, education and training (EET) committees;

strategies which improve the understanding of structural and other changes occurring in a regional economy and labour market including the funding of skills audits, industry training needs analyses and associated databases;

strategies which may improve the skills base of a region to support existing enterprises and better meet the skills needs of emerging business and employment opportunities include the development and delivery of education and training responses to meet identified needs; and

strategies which foster local enterprise development and employment growth include grant funding to small business advisory and support agencies, incubators or shared work spaces, alternate employment arrangements such as cooperatives and workpools.
(d) Program 4.3 Labour Adjustment Assistance, Regional Initiatives.
(e) OLMA committee members stand without fee. Some projects are jointly funded by local organisations or State Agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 9 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What action will be taken to achieve the compliance by the Australian Taxation Office with the Privacy Commissioner's Data Matching Guidelines.
(2) Please provide a copy of the submission by the ATO in response to the Revised Draft Guidelines released in September 1991.

(3) Does the Government concur with the Privacy Commissioner's stated opinion that `statutory guidelines binding on all agencies are the best level of protection against the intrusiveness of data matching'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Data Matching Guidelines are voluntary guidelines only. Guidelines 1 states:
`These guidelines are recommended for adoption by agencies in relation to the conduct of certain data-matching programs'.
As compliance with the guidelines is voluntary, compliance with the guidelines is a matter for the ATO.
(2) A copy of the submission has been forwarded to the Honourable Senator.

(3) The Guidelines commenced operation on 1 October 1992. The Privacy Commissioner will monitor their operation for a period of 12 months, after which he will make recommendations to me regarding the possibility of incorporating general guidelines into the Privacy Act and making them binding. I will consider those recommendations when they have been put to me and make a decision when I have all the relevant information on which to base that decision.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Torres Strait Staff

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 9 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many staff are based in Torres Strait.
(2) How many staff are indigenous.
(3) What strategies are being implemented to ensure more Torres Strait Island staff move into senior positions.
(4) How is housing allocated to prevent discrimination against Torres Strait Islanders.
(5) What processes are in place to ensure regular communication and liaison between departments and with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and the Island Coordinating Council.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) On Thursday Island the Department of Employment, Education and Training has an establishment of nine positions. Of these, seven are presently filled and action to staff the remainder is well in hand.
(2) All permanent staff are local Torres Strait residents; six are indigenous.

(3) All staff regularly attend the full range of Departmental operational and developmental training exercises. In addition, the Department is involved in the development of the Australian Public Service Career and Management Development Strategies for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander staff. This scheme offers a number of career development programs to all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander staff. This includes the opportunity for career-related full-time tertiary study or study to obtain a Year 12 Certificate.

Two new programs are being developed by the Department. The National Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Middle Management Bridging Program is aimed at officers at Administrative Service Officer Grades 5 and 6 and Senior Officer Grade C levels. This will provide staff with the skills and knowledge needed at Middle Management level and provide preparation for participation in other departmental Middle Management development programs. The other new program is the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Skills Transfer Program which provides structured staff rotation opportunities.

(4) The Department allocates housing based on an operational needs basis, and uses as its criteria the Commonwealth Public Service guidelines on staff housing. These guidelines allow for accommodation to be provided to staff under the following provisions:
(a) where it is necessary for the proper functioning or safeguarding of an establishment,
(b) there is not an acceptable purchase and/or rental market,
(c) the staff member is in a key position; or,
(d) where the employing department is satisfied that provision of accommodation at a particular location can be justified on economic grounds.
The Department has access to four residences on Thursday Island, all are currently occupied.

(5) The Department is a member of the Local Torres Strait Islands Employment Development Committee which holds monthly meetings. This Committee consists of representatives of Commonwealth and State departments and other agencies which have responsibility for, or interests in, Aboriginal and Torres Strait islander matters. In addition, there is regular formal and informal liaison with all parties, in particular the Island Coordinating Council and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 14 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the explanation for the inconsistency between assertions made by Mr Tony Miller, Consul (Public Affairs) Australian Consulate General, New York, that no koalas captured from the wild are permitted to be exported overseas when the present guidelines for the overseas export of koalas specifically provide for the export of wild-caught koalas provided they have been held in captivity within Australia for 12 months.

(2) With regard to the guidelines for the export of koalas, is there a head of power under the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Imports and Exports) Act 1982 that permits wild-caught koalas to be exported overseas.

(3) With regard to present export guidelines, on whose technical advice were the present guidelines amended to provide for the loan of koalas overseas and their subsequent re-importation into this country, and was the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service asked for its advice in this matter, if so, what was that advice.

(4) What are the arrangements for the progeny of loaned koalas and will the Minister undertake to amend the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Imports and Exports) Act 1982 regulations and guidelines for koalas and other fauna so that export guidelines are made to apply to the progeny of exported animals as well as animals that are the subject of that particular export.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has advised the following. The response prepared by Mr Miller was based upon information received from a variety of sources. Mr Miller was unaware of the situation with regard to the export of wild caught koalas as he did not have available to him at the time a copy of The Conditions For The Overseas Transfer Of Koalas, nor was that information contained in the material that was available to him.

(2) The requirements for the export of live native Australian animals including koalas are defined in sections 12, 13, 21, 25, 26, 27 and 31 of the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982. Essentially these mean that the export of live koalas is restricted to inter zoological gardens transfers under permit where the recipient institution is adequately equipped to provide suitable care for the animals. Provided the exporting zoo does not require the koala for the purposes of breeding, exhibition or research, a captive bred or wild caught koala can be exported.

(3) The Conditions For The Overseas Transfer Of Koalas were revised in 1984, 1986, 1988 and 1990 in consultation with zoo experts and representatives of the State and Territory wildlife conservation authorities experienced in the husbandry and management of koalas.

The most recent revision was initiated on the basis of a decision of the former Council of Nature Conservation Ministers in September 1990 that the current Conditions For The Overseas Transfer Of Koalas should be amended to allow for reimportation of koalas following short term loans. State and Territory wildlife conservation authorities and major Australian zoos were again consulted and the revised conditions address the concerns that were raised.
Condition 23 was included to take into account concerns which may be raised by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service about any koala proposed to be exported and subsequently imported.

Condition 23 states: "Where koalas are to be loaned to an overseas zoo and reimported into Australia, prior approval must be obtained from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and the enclosure in which they are to be held must be, in addition to the conditions stipulated in condition 19: (i) fully rodent proofed; and (ii) fully insect proofed."

(4) The arrangements for progeny of loaned koalas are covered under Regulation 7 to the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982, where the overseas zoo is required to give an undertaking that it will not trade commercially in Australian native fauna. Therefore, this requirement applies to the native fauna exported and any subsequent progeny. There is no intention to change this position.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 14 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to Question on Notice 2092 (Senate Hansard, 19 August 1992, p.286):

(1) In (1) of the answer it is stated that a quotation attributed to Mr Tony Miller (Consul-Public Affairs) New York in which Mr Miller asserts that `the Australian Government introduced legislation many years ago that was designed to protect our native wildlife' is `unclear', will Senator Collins, as the representative of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, instruct Mr Miller to clarify immediately in his correspondence and statements that the primary responsibility for wildlife conservation and management rests with State and Territory Governments.
(2) Which nature conservation reserves in Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia protect substantial areas of koala habitat.

(3) Why does the Federal Government state that draft koala management plans have been completed by Queensland when the Minister for the Environment in that State says that the report is preliminary and does not, in its current form, constitute a departmental management plan for koalas in that State.

(4) The answer states that existing national parks and nature reserves in eastern Australia effectively protect substantial areas of koala habitat and are managed by State and Territory conservation agencies, which existing national parks and nature reserves in eastern Australia effectively protect substantial areas of koala habitat.
(5) How do Save the Bush, One Billion Trees and the States Co-operative Assistance Program maintain and improve koala habitat when these and other land care initiatives lack a fauna component.

(6) (a) What are the details of the exact funds made available through the Koala Conservation Program, launched in 1985 through public contributions, Commonwealth funding and a donation by American Express; (b) how much of these funds have been used to administer and conduct high priority research projects; (c) which projects have been administered through the Research and Surveys, Save the Bush and States Co-operative Assistance Programs for koalas; and (d) please provide the results of these projects.
(7) Please provide the results of the National Koala Survey, particularly the results from New South Wales and Queensland which indicate that the broad historical distribution of the koala is stable.
(8) Has any national koala program identified viable koala colonies in New South Wales, Queensland and Victoria; if so, where and what studies have been undertaken to determine their viability.

(9) Why has the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade recommended to Australian consulates and Embassies in Canada and the United States that they refer queries from the concerned public to the Friends of the Australian Koala Foundation in New York.

(10) Has the Australian Consul-General in New York or the Australian Ambassador in Washington disseminated information on the koala provided by the Australian Koala Foundation; if so, why has the Federal Government not referred interested parties to either the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service or its own Koala Conservation Program.

(11) What steps will the Minister take to correct the impression given by our overseas embassies and consulates that: (a) koala habitat is protected; (b) the Commonwealth Government provides legislation which protects koalas; (c) national parks and reserves have been specially created to protect the koala; (d) management programs to protect koalas are in place and working in New South Wales, Victoria and Queensland; and (e) there are no areas of major koala habitat protected by legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I understand that Mr Miller has undertaken to revise the text of the form letter in question to avoid any possible ambiguities regarding the legislative arrangements relating to wildlife protection in Australia.

(2) The reports of the surveys undertaken as part of the National Koala Survey by the nature conservation agencies of South Australia, Victoria, the Australian Capital Territory, New South Wales and Queensland provide details of those nature conservation reserves where koalas are found. These reports are contained in the document entitled Details of Koala-related Research and Management Projects Administered by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, a copy of which has been forwarded to the honourable senator. Further copies are available from the Senate Table Office.

(3) In my response to your previous question regarding the status of koala management plans I indicated that a "draft" plan had been prepared by Queensland and a copy was forwarded to your office. My use of the word "draft" was intended to convey that the plan was preliminary and had not yet been formally adopted for use in that State.
(4) I refer the honourable senator to the answer to Question 2.

(5) It is inaccurate to say that the Save the Bush, One Billion Trees and States Cooperative Assistance Programs lack a fauna component. In particular, the States Cooperative Assistance Program, since its inception in 1983-84, has provided support for a wide range of fauna-related projects, including koala projects (Refer to Question 6). Similarly, under the Save the Bush and One Billion Trees Programs there have been numerous projects funded which have provided direct benefits for fauna (Refer to Question 6). It is important to note here that these revegetation programs also have major indirect benefits for fauna in general. They are helping to link habitat remnants and overcome the major threat koalas and many other species face, that is,—habitat fragmentation.

(6) (a) (b) (c) and (d) In reference to these questions, I refer the honourable senator to Details of Koala-related Research and Management Projects Administered by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, a copy of which has been forwarded to the honourable senator. Further copies are available from the Senate Table Office.

(7) The results of the National Koala Survey were reported in the publication Koalas: The Little Australians We'd All Hate to Lose published in 1989 by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and available from the AGPS bookshop at a cost of $24.95. Copies of the reports from the Queensland and New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Services summarising their findings as part of the National Koala Survey, and in particular addressing the issue of broad historical distribution of koalas, are included in Details of Koala-related Research and Management Projects Administered by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, a copy of which has been forwarded to the honourable senator. Further copies are available from the Senate Table Office.
(8) I refer the honourable senator to the various reports referred to in the foregoing answers.
(9) and (10) These questions should be directed to my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.
(11) (a) None. Koala habitat is indeed protected within national parks and reserves in eastern Australia.

(11) (b) None. The Commonwealth Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982 is an Act to further the protection and conservation of wildlife by, inter alia, regulating the export of native animals including koalas. Export of koalas is strictly regulated to ensure that the species is not placed at risk by uncontrolled export.

(11) (c) None. Mr Miller's letter states that "areas of major koala habitat are protected by legislation". This is factually correct. The presence of notable wildlife species, including koalas is a factor in assessing areas for inclusion in national parks and reserves. The letter does not imply that national parks and reserves are created solely to protect koalas.

(11) (d) Victoria is not mentioned in Mr Miller's letter. Revision of the text as indicated in my answer to (1) above will remove any possible ambiguity in reference to New South Wales and Queensland.
(11) (e) None. The letter does not give the impression that there are no areas of major koala habitat protected by legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a question without notice asked by Senator Chamarette relating to investigations conducted by the Australian Securities Commission to determine if insider trading laws may have been breached by the extraordinary sale of 1.6 million shares in Jupiters Ltd in the two weeks prior to 26 May 1992, did these events give Jupiters a commercial advantage over other tenders?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)I am advised that on 7 October 1992, the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission, Mr A G Hartnell wrote a letter to Mr D Abbott, Secretary to the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities which responded to information sought by the Committee. That letter sets out the Australian Securities Commission's conclusions in respect of its preliminary enquires into trading in shares of Jupiters Ltd in the two weeks prior to 26 May 1992.
(2)The letter made the following statement:

"Examination of the share trading activity in the two weeks prior to the 26 May announcement, together with other enquiries, has led the ASC to conclude that, based on the information available to the ASC, there was no extraordinary trading activity in the relevant period and there was no evidence or indication of either insider trading or market manipulation in the subject period."

(3)I am advised that Mr Hartnell wrote a further letter on this matter on 12 October to the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, Senator Beahan. This letter elaborated on information provided in the earlier letter and sets out the ASC's conclusion that based on the information available to it there was no breach of insider trading laws during the period in question. The letter made the following relevant statements:

"(a) In the two weeks prior to the announcement of 26 May 1992, total reported trading in Jupiters Limited shares on the Exchange amounted to 1,727,600 shares in 363 transactions which ranged in size from 100 to 675,000 shares. However, the average parcel traded in this period was in the 3,000—10,000 shares range with only two major purchases of 675,000 and 100,000 shares. Given that the issued capital of Jupiters Limited, at 14 January 1992 was, 48,109,319 in 192,437,274 fully paid ordinary shares of 25 cents each, the 1.7 million shares traded represents less than 1% of the issued capital.

(b)The highest daily price of Jupiters Limited shares in the two weeks prior to the announcement ranged from $2.21 (8 May 1992) to $2.43 (26 May 1992) with an average price of $2.35 over the period. Prior to the voluntary suspension of Jupiters Limited at approximately 11.00 am on 26 May 1992 the shares were trading at $2.35 and following reinstatement, at 2.34 pm 26 May, 1992, the share price rose to $2.52 (only one trade of 800 shares) before closing at $2.45.
The above has led the ASC to conclude that:
(a)the sale of 1.7 million Jupiters Limited shares, out of 192.4 million on issue (less than 1% of issued capital), does not represent an extraordinary trading pattern in the circumstances; and

ANSWER.PARA: (b)There is no evidence nor indication of either insider trading or market manipulation in the trading in Jupiters Limited shares in the two weeks prior to 26 May 1992."

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 8 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a question without notice asked by Senator Powell (Senate Hansard, 16 September 1992, p.952) relating to the public radio station 3WRB:
(1) Is the Minister aware that a tape of the program may be in existence; if so, was the Minister misled when briefed on this matter.
(2) Will the Minister take steps to discover the truth regarding the remark about Mrs Val Allen made by Mr Noel Greig.

(3) Is the Minister concerned that subsequent to the complaint being made by Mr and Mrs Allen and the issue being raised in Parliament, both Mr and Mrs Allen are now facing expulsion proceedings initiated by the Board of Management.

(4) Will the Minister request the Australian Broadcasting Authority to inquire into the activities of the board in relation to this matter with a view to ensuring that the station is managed in a manner appropriate to a community-based public radio station.

(5) Can action be taken to prevent the Board of Management from acting precipitately in relation to the membership of the Allens to allow its conduct of the station and dealings with its members and volunteers to be properly scrutinised.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) first became aware that a tape of the program may be in existence when it noticed in its media clips of 10 October 1992, a copy of an article concerning the dispute which appeared in the Williamstown Advertiser on 30 September 1992. The report stated that Mr Greig had supplied the newspaper with a recording of the show during the previous week.

The ABA contacted Mr Grieg that day to confirm whether a tape was available. On 14 October, the ABA formally asked Mr Greig to provide it with the tape of the broadcast relating to the alleged remark about which Mr and Mrs Allen complained.
It is understood that Mr Greig has also written to Senator Powell on this matter.
(2) The ABA has listened to the extract of the tape submitted by Mr Greig, "3WRB March 8, 1992 Grand Ole Opry".

As reported in the Williamstown Advertiser the comments by Mr Greig purportedly repeat those of his co-host referring to why Mrs Allen was not involved in the broadcast that day. These are included in the introductory comments to the program which include "get well" comments to Mrs Allen.

(3) It is of concern that a dispute between members of 3WRB has been raised in Parliament. Under the licensee's internal Rules of Association the Committee of Management of 3WRB can by resolution decide to expel a member on certain grounds such as not complying with those rules of Association. Those rules also allow for the member's right of appeal.
This issue rightly belongs with the members of 3WRB and its management.

(4) The former Australian Broadcasting Tribunal concluded its inquiry into the 3WRB licence in April this year. The Tribunal had been asked by a member of the public to consider whether the licence should be suspended or whether licence conditions should be imposed. The decision was to impose a condition requiring the licensee to hold a general meeting to discuss changes to its rules. This has been done.
The ABA has continued to be informed of the activities of 3WRB by individual members. At this stage the ABA does not consider it necessary to commence an investigation into this matter.
Based on the information available, it is not considered necessary to direct the ABA to investigate this matter.
(5) As noted in (3), the Committee of Management has the power to expel members from the radio station's Member's Association, under its rules.

The Broadcasting Services Act 1992 does not give the Minister or the ABA the power to take steps to prevent the 3WRB committee of management from taking any action in relation to Mr and Mrs Allen's membership of the Association. The committee must comply fully with the licensee's membership rules in taking such action.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 13 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to all residential properties sold by, or on behalf of, the Federal Civil Aviation Authority in Queensland during 1991-92:
(1) What was the location of each sale.
(2) What was the date of each sale.
(3) In each case, what was the price obtained for each property.
(4) Was an independent valuation obtained for each property before it was sold.
(5) In the event of a valuation having been made prior to sale, what was the variation between valuation price and sale price.
(6) In each case, what was the criteria upon which agents or others were chosen to market these properties.
(7) Were any such sales made to real estate franchisees; if so, was commission paid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows :

PARA.TAB: Please refer to the table.

(4) All properties, with the exception of the sale of the property at 213 Merrill Avenue, Rockhampton, were valued independently prior to sale. A real estate agent's market appraisal was obtained prior to the sale of 213 Merrill Avenue.

The sale of Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) houses in Queensland is part of a national program of disposals. The CAA has also taken the opportunity to link a concession on sale of houses to staff with removal of conditions of service rights as a means of achieving substantial reduction in the cost of employing staff at remote locations. Sales to staff are normally made at valuation less any applicable concession. The sliding scale of concessions ranges from $12,000 for staff giving up all term transfer rights to $2,000 in recognition of savings in cost of sale and relocation.

With respect to the variations reported on the table, the majority of the CAA houses sold in Queensland during the 1991-92 financial year were sold to staff most of whom were able to avail themselves of the concessional benefit. This explains the large number of instances where the sale price was below the valuation.

(6) Initially staff of the Authority were offered the opportunity to purchase surplus houses. These sales were handled by the Authority directly with staff without the assistance of real estate agents. Once these sales were completed the Authority commenced selling houses on the open market.

The strategy adopted for the disposal on the open market was to seek the services of a major real estate franchise group covering all the sale locations. This was aimed at reducing CAA administrative costs and maximising the opportunity for bulk discounts.

Approaches were made to eight franchise groups considered to have the infrastructure to handle the project. Several approaches were received from sole traders in all locations. These were not considered because of the strategy adopted of dealing with the one central contact.
Subsequently requests for tender were sought from six companies.
The criteria used to select the preferred service provider were the level of fees, the relevant experience and the quality of the proposal in regard to :
(i) sale of property,
(ii) interim property management pending sale, and
(iii) ongoing property management at Mount Isa and Charleville, where the Authority will retain some housing stock.

Tenders were called on 24 February 1992 and closed at 2.00 pm on 3 March 1992. Conforming tenders were received from the six companies. Raine and Horne was subsequently appointed sole agent to market and sell the Authority's residential property in Queensland.

(7) The property at 12 Manuel Street, Mackay was sold to Stillwind P/L, Raine and Horne Franchisee in Mackay. The beneficial interest of the licensees of this real Estate Agency (D Redford and L Kippin) was noted on the contract.

The property was sold at auction on 16 May 1992 along with three other properties. Completion of sale was effected on 16 June 1992. Conveyancing matters for the sale of this residence were handled by the Australian Government Solicitor on behalf of the CAA. No commission was paid although initially commission was erroneously deducted from the deposit required.

ANSWER.PARA: Location Contract signed Sale price Valuation Variation

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 14 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a National Geoscience Mapping Accord Project being conducted by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in conjunction with the Queensland Government.

(1) Were Bureau of Mineral Resources investigators allowed access to the communities of Lockhart River, Aurukun, Old Mapoon and Cowal Creek, during 1990-91; if not, has access been gained since 1990/91.
(2) If access has not been possible, is it possible without such access to properly and completely undertake the required studies and what effect will this have on the project.
(3) (a) What is the total cost of the project to date; and (b) what are the projected costs for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Staff of the Australian Geological Survey Organisation (AGSO) previously the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics (BMR) seeks the consent of local landowners before undertaking field survey work on privately owned land as a matter of course. Consent is usually given.

In 1990-91 staff sought permission to undertake field survey work for the North Queensland National Geoscience Mapping Accord Project on a range of privately owned land in various tenures. Of the Aboriginal communities listed Old Mapoon agreed to access, Aurukun refused access, Lockhart River agreed to access in April 1990 but later withdrew agreement and Cowal Creek did not respond to correspondence.

(2) AGSO mapping programs are based largely on noninvasive remote sensing methods such as satellite imagery and air borne photographic and low level geophysical surveys. Ground traverses are necessary to validate interpretations of the remotely sensed data, such as recording details of rock type and structure. Ground access is also required for rock and stream sediment geochemical sampling and to take gravity measurements. In the past ground access has also been required to install radio beacons to provide navigation for the airborne surveys but this is no longer necessary.

In view of the relatively small areas concerned, lack of ground access to the specified areas will not have a major impact on the project although documentation of some aspects of the areas where access was not granted will not be at the same level of detail as areas where access was granted. This will affect analysis of surficial (regolith) and basement geology and assessment of resource potential of the areas excluded. Regional synthesis for the entire project area will be only marginally affected.

(3) The National Geoscience Mapping Accord Projects are cooperative Commonwealth-State Projects. AGSO expenditure on the North Queensland Mapping Accord Project, which involves mapping a total area of 388 000 square kilometres, totalled approximately $3.2 million in 1990-91 and 1991-92. Contributions are also made to the Project by the Geological Survey of Queensland, the Australian National University, the United States Geological Survey and the National Resource Information Centre.

Projected expenditure by AGSO until the projects' completion in 1995/96 is expected to be of the order of $2.8 million. Information on other participants' financial contribution to the project is not available but expenditure by the Geological Survey of Queensland is expected to be comparable to that of AGSO.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 4 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the issue of charges for car rental operators at Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) airports been determined; if so; (a) what is the schedule of charges; and (b) how were they calculated.
(2) Will the charges affect the viability of any operators.
(3) Will the results be of benefit to any operator or group of operators; if so, which ones.
(4) What effect will the charges make to the business and tourist users of rental cars.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by the Federal Airports Corporation, is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The issue of charges for car rental operators at FAC airports has not been finally resolved. The consultation process is continuing. This process is aimed at accommodating to the greatest extent possible, the concerns of the Trade Practices Commission, the Corporation's charter, the best interests of the travelling public and the widely varying wishes of the different sectors of the car rental industry. A new discussion paper incorporating most of the suggestions and addressing most of the concerns has been distributed and is receiving greater acceptance. Some further ideas have been suggested, particularly as alternatives for the very small operators who are seeking access to airports. It is expected these ideas will also be incorporated in the agreements finally offered.

(2) The Corporation does not have access to the information on each interested car rental operator to enable the Corporation to assess whether its changes will affect the viability of any operators. It is expected, however, that in an industry where price competition is rife, both on airports and off airports, the Corporation's move to charge all operators a fair and equitable fee for access to airports should improve the viability of those operators both large and small who are currently paying the appropriate fees and who are therefore disadvantaged against those who come onto airports and pay little or nothing.
(3) The proposals currently being discussed appear to give a small overall advantage to very small operators with less than 3% of the market.

(4) Since more than 90% of all cars rented from airports are supplied by companies currently paying to the Corporation fees which are slightly greater than those proposed in the new contract, and since these charges have been in place for many years,

ANSWER.PARA: it is assumed that the rental rates charged already include airport fees, so no increase in the rates charged is envisaged.
